In the original, instead of indicating the territories that serve as setting for the novel as “Zavolzh’e” (Transvolga), the author creates this neologism (Transwolf-river) on the basis of his alternative spelling of the Volga River as “Volch’ia,” Wolf river.

translation location setting Russia
You

The inspector, Sidor Fomich Pozhilykh, to whom Ilya is addressing his letter of complaint.

character explanatory
Beyond the Wolf

In the original, instead of indicating the territories that serve as setting for the novel as “Zavolzh’e” (Transvolga), the author creates this neologism (Transwolf-river) on the basis of his alternative spelling of the Volga River as “Volch’ia,” Wolf river.

translation location setting Russia
water strider

Its movements on top of water recall those of an ice skater. Mentioned three times by Ilya (R210, 221, 254/E105, 126, 185). Animal motif.

motif
the masts are bendin and they creak

A reference to Mikhail Lermontov’s 1832 poem “The Sail.” Read it in the original and in an English translation here.

intertextuality
Itil

The Tatar name of the river Volga. The title of Ilya’s letter “Zaitil’shchina” is derived from this version of the river’s name. Ostanin also suggests a sound link between the rivers Itil’ and Lethe (Leta), the river of oblivion and forgetting, which also plays a major role in Sokolov’s first novel, A School for Fools (10).

location foreign setting language
midges

Animal motif.

motif
moskitos

Animal motif.

motif register/style
scull

Boat motif.

motif
squeakers

Crutches.

explanatory
growth of lilies. I confirm: They toil not, they spin not, and yet they’re dressed spic-and-span

A reference to Matthew 6:28–33.

intertextuality religion bible
You

The inspector, Sidor Fomich Pozhilykh, to whom Ilya is addressing his letter of complaint.

explanatory character
And I cannot, due to the first, whilst they ain’t present

Ilya is alluding to the fact that he has already related how his crutches were stolen. If that’s the case, then how does he have them here? Sokolov describes the situation as follows: “Krylobyl explained to Ilya that the theft of his crutches happened only on this bank, where the time is present, and on the other bank, where the time is past or even the day before last, this theft has not happened yet, So Ilya, not wanting to miss nuts and mushroom season, began to travel to the other side of the river, and as soon as he is there there, on the other bank, that is, in the past, he immediately finds crutches and drags himself on them, on creaky ones, along the river. Ilya writes to the investigator that he understands his perplexity and recognizes his right to protest about this, that is, the investigator has the right to be perplexed: how can Ilya drag himself on squeaky crutches if they were stolen. Understanding the investigator’s bewilderment, Ilya begins explaining his situation with the words: Crutches with crutches, mushrooms with nuts. This phrase can be translated as: Crutches are one thing, and mushrooms and nuts another. Or thus: Do not confuse, mix crutches and gifts of nature. Or: The absence of crutches does not interfere with the collection of mushrooms and nuts. And an explanation why it doesn’t interfere is given below. Because the crutches are still present on the other side, And on this side, where they’re no longer present, there is a corresponding problem: to get to the mooring stakes. Apparently, there is no real pier but stakes hammered into the ground: boats are tied to them. Ilya gets to the shuttle, jumping on one leg along the fences and holding on to them. The fences are second cousins because there is a joking expression: he is my uncle’s second cousin. A varient —a cousin. So they say about some very distant relative. Ilya allows poetic license instead of saying: crutches upon crutches, mushrooms upon mushrooms, and nuts upon nuts, he probably, for the sake of brevity, says: mushrooms upon nuts, which is logically incorrect, but to him, a joker and a jester, this is quite excusable” (personal correspondence, August 4, 2023).

explanatory
havin abandoned the trips for the third and the second, sit like my namesake from Murom without stirrin for thirty years plus three more of travel restrictions

An allusion to Ilya Muromets, a famed bogatyr (epic knight) of bylinas (epic folktales) from Kievan Rus’, who, it is said, was bedridden for 33 years. Read, for instance, “Ilya Muromets and Nightingale the Robber” here.

intertextuality Russia
Murom

Murom — one of the oldest cities in Russia, located in the Vladimir Oblast and along the Oka River.

location Russia
three more of travel restrictions

According to Ostanin, “пять в зубы и три по рогам” means “five years in a camp and three in civil law” in prison jargon (99).

phraseologism
Krylobyl

Krylobyl is a key character dwelling in the world of the dead (living on the other shore of the Itil’ river). It is not surprising given his “speaking name” formed by the words “krylo” (wing) and “byl” (was, used to be). He is a hypostasis of an angelic creature guiding Ilya in his wanderings and suggesting to him ideas and reflections: in chapter 4 it will be Krylobyl who advances the idea of the origin of the “zhe” letter; it is Krylobyl in this chapter who Ilya describes as a “know-it-all” who “instructs,” the one “whom I trust, whom I praise.” In a sense, Krylobyl is Ilya’s Virgil or, even, Beatrice in his wandering across this very special Inferno, Purgatorio, and Paradiso. Toward the end of the novel, he will be addressed by the narrator in chapter 16 (R275/E220) and by Ilya in chapter 17 as “Fedot Fyodorov” (R279/E227).

character intertextuality intratextuality
Ilya

In the original he is here addressed to as Elijah. Ilya is frequently compared—by the narrator and by himself—to the prophet Ilya/Elijah, who is commonly associated with lightning and thunder.

character intertextuality bible religion translation
Petrikeich

Petrikeich is Ilya’s patronymic (“son of Petrik,” although this first name is not common). D.B. Johnson has noted that the patronymic contains an allusion to the folkloric figure of the “lisa Patrikeevna,” a trickster fox present in Slavic culture (“Sokolov’s Between Dog and Wolf and the Modernist Tradition” 211). The reference to a fox is not by chance: Ilya will be transfigured into a fox in Orina’s imagination when tied to a railroad (she had brought the hide of her pet fox to a shoemaker who later took advantage of her). Animal motif.

character motif intertextuality intratextuality folklore
fuctions

Functions.

register/style
Sidor

Sidor (shortened form of Isidor). Pozhilykh, the addressee of Ilya’s letter of complaint.

character
Fatherovich

Boguslawski translates here the humorous patronymic Bat’kovich derived from bat’ka (old man, father), sometimes used when an interlocutor’s actual patronymic isn’t known.

translation explanatory
Look, Krylobyl, this know-it-all, instructs, let’s take not time, but an ordinary river. Well, let’s. And turn your imagination, he pesters, that it practically doesn’t move in the backwater; duckweed and grasses are stranglin it, while at the channel line it rushes; and the time fuctions the same way, he esplained, in Gorodnishche it moves, approximately, like a stroke of a swift’s wing, in Bydogoshch, not too fast and not too slow, and in the woods, a total peace and quiet. For that reason, mind my assurances that the theft, of which you are the victim, took place so far only in our beloved town and nowhere else, and on the other side nobody even heard about it. That means, if you move over there—everythin will be right again

A central passage in the novel. Krylobyl suggests that time functions differently depending on one’s location or perspective. Just as a river flows at different speeds, so does time move differently. In the backwoods, where not much happens, time moves slowly. In the city, where there is action and hustle and bustle, time moves quickly. Thus, if Ilya were to move to the other side of the river, he would be able to recover his crutches, where their theft, allegedly, hasn’t yet occurred. This view of time serves as one explanation for the various contradictions in the novel. For a consideration of Sokolov’s atypical approach to time in his novels, see Boguslawskii 1989.

time explanatory
Krylobyl

Krylobyl is a key character dwelling in the world of the dead (living on the other shore of the Itil’ river). It is not surprising given his “speaking name” formed by the words “krylo” (wing) and “byl” (was, used to be). He is a hypostasis of an angelic creature guiding Ilya in his wanderings and suggesting to him ideas and reflections: in chapter 4 it will be Krylobyl who advances the idea of the origin of the “zhe” letter; it is Krylobyl in this chapter who Ilya describes as a “know-it-all” who “instructs,” the one “whom I trust, whom I praise.” In a sense, Krylobyl is Ilya’s Virgil or, even, Beatrice in his wandering across this very special Inferno, Purgatorio, and Paradiso. Toward the end of the novel, he will be addressed by the narrator in chapter 16 (R275/E220) and by Ilya in chapter 17 as “Fedot Fyodorov” (R279/E227).

character intertextuality intratextuality
duckweed

Plant motif.

motif
grasses

Plant motif.

motif
fuctions

Functions.

register/style
Gorodnishche

The main setting of the novel: a fictional town on the banks of the Volga River. Also called Gorodnishchi. Derived from the words for town (gorod) and beggar (nishchii). It is the “town of beggars.” Olga Matich writes: “If School for Fools was written against the background of youth prose, Sokolov’s next novel Between Dog and Wolf may be read as the author’s response to village prose, the literary rage of the seventies” (“Sasha Sokolov” 310). Vadim Kreid observes that Gorodnishche, a barracks village of beggars and thieves, resembles an “Anti-Kitezh” (Kitezh being the legendary, mythical city in Russian folklore that only the pure-hearted will have the chance to reach). In Gorodnishche, however, thieves rob beggars, while beggars beg thieves (“Zaitil’shchina” 213). According to Johnson, the living dwell Gorodnishche, while the dead reside on the other side of the river, in Bydogoshch (“Sokolov’s Between Dog and Wolf and the Modernist Tradition” 209). Johnson also mentions a statement by Sokolov himself: “Sokolov reports that the name is a blend of the dissolute eighteen-century town of Gorodnya described by A. N. Radishchev in his Journey from Petersburg to Moscow and a nearby town called Gorodishche. Thus the time layers of the sixteenth century, the eighteenth century, and a mythic present are all superimposed upon each other – a characteristic technique in the novel” (217).

location setting intertextuality folklore theme
swift

Rachel Warren Chadd and Marianne Taylor write, “No bird spends more time in the air than the Common Swift, which eats, drinks, sleeps and even mates on the wing; young birds are thought to stay airborne for several years before they nest. While swifts may not consistently live p to their name, flying at around 14mph (23km/h) when twisting in the air to feed on insects, their streamlined bodies and sickle-shaped wings equip them to perform long glides, steady 25mph (40km/h) flight during migration and short, rapid bursts” (243). Animal motif.

motif
Bydogoshch

As Sokolov explains, there is no relation between this location and the Polish town of Bydgoszcz (personal communication, June 7, 2023). It is rather a misspelling of the village (and lake) of Vidogoshch by the Volga River, near Tver’. D.B. Johnson suggests that, while the living dwell in Gorodnishche, Bydogoshch is home for the dead (“Sokolov’s Between Dog and Wolf and the Modernist Tradition” 209).

location Russia theme setting
goin on the future scow to bygone years

As Ilya is in a time-space that is relatively “future” to the other side of the river, according to Krylobyl, he uses his “future scow” to travel to the past.

explanatory time
scow

Boat motif.

motif
Regardless of graphs and paragraphs, around here there was and still is a severe shortage of volunteers to assist the defectives, that’s why we are the chosen ones

Sokolov translated this passage for us: “Despite various official rulings and regulations of state officials on the need to help the disabled, we [Russians] have an acute shortage of people willing to do so, which speaks of our universal cruelty, our inexhaustible sufferings, which is not surprising, because we as a nation are chosen to live in difficult conditions and constantly have problems” (personal communication, July 29, 2023).

explanatory Russia
You

The inspector, Sidor Fomich Pozhilykh, to whom Ilya is addressing his letter of complaint.

explanatory character
thrice-removed relatives

Boguslawski translates a variation of the set expression “нашему забору двоюродный плетень” (literally, a wattle-cousin to our fence) defining a distant relative.

phraseologism translation
havin trampled lameness with lameness

A play on the Paschal troparion: “Christ is risen from the dead, by death trampling death, and to those in the tombs granting life!”

religion bible intertextuality
You

The inspector, Sidor Fomich Pozhilykh, to whom Ilya is addressing his letter of complaint.

explanatory character
You—here, in the present—are studyin this Volapuke

Ilya asks Pozhilykh to read and study closely his letter.

explanatory
Volapuke

Volapük — the first constructed language. Invented by Johann Martin Schleyer between 1879 and 1880 as an international language. The term is now sometimes used to refer to nonsense or incomprehensibility. Martina Napolitano writes: “Searching for such voice, the author has constructed a language, defined by one of the heroes as ‘Volapuke.’ This language apparently looks ‘mysterious’ and inaccessible, yet given a closer examination, it reveals its complex texture of interwoven threads: as any constructed language, its origins are to be found in a spoken, lively idiom. A basic rule in this particular ‘Volapuke’ derives from the chance allowed to any trope, word, expression, and even grapheme to transfigure into its direct, objectified meaning. The novel is thus built upon the unending weaving of linguistic threads that meet their realized metaphor” (“‘Studyin This Volapuke’” 293).

language foreign
You

The inspector, Sidor Fomich Pozhilykh, to whom Ilya is addressing his letter of complaint.

explanatory character
turned Your imagination to me

A variation of “to draw attention on,” here literally “to draw imagination on.”

language
Your

The inspector, Sidor Fomich Pozhilykh, to whom Ilya is addressing his letter of complaint.

explanatory character
You

The inspector, Sidor Fomich Pozhilykh, to whom Ilya is addressing his letter of complaint.

explanatory character
Beyond the Wolf

In the original, instead of indicating the territories that serve as setting for the novel as “Zavolzh’e” (Transvolga), the author creates this neologism (Transwolf-river) on the basis of his alternative spelling of the Volga River as “Volch’ia,” Wolf river.

translation location setting Russia
No, I see You there, ’cuz not I am there but You. In a word, we both are right. After all, since we are on different sides, we also have a different geography: You are Beyond the Wolf and I am too

A reflection of the convoluted nature of the novel’s world. The two banks of the river become interchangeable.

explanatory
You

The inspector, Sidor Fomich Pozhilykh, to whom Ilya is addressing his letter of complaint.

explanatory character
You

The inspector, Sidor Fomich Pozhilykh, to whom Ilya is addressing his letter of complaint.

explanatory character
You

The inspector, Sidor Fomich Pozhilykh, to whom Ilya is addressing his letter of complaint.

explanatory character
Orina

Orina, along with her variants, is the primary female character in the novel. In a sense, she is the only female figure in Between Dog and Wolf. As D.B. Johnson summarizes, the “promiscuous heroine Orina-Mariia is a train dispatcher, a princess in her dispatcher’s tower, who entertains her coworkers in her bed. Some of her orgiastic trysts take place near the train tracks to which her lovers tie her meddling husband Il’ia. Orina, in at least one time dimension, is killed by a train as she belatedly tries to save Il’ia who loses his leg” (“Twilight Cosmos” 647). Ilya is obsessed with this woman, and this passion “is the ultimate source of the woes that befall Il’ia, the itinerant grinder. It is his passion for the faithless slut Orina that brings about his misfortunes: the loss of his leg, his wandering life as a drunken grinder, and the grisly events that lead to his death” (643). Orina, alternatively called Maria, exists in the book also in another version, as ta dama, that dame, “a mysterious woman who appears along the river seeking Il’ia and, failing to find him, takes away a new lover each time […]. Her chance lovers return days later, sexually depleted and without interest in life. They usually die by their own hand” (645). In this figure (which embodies “virtually all female figures in the book,” D.B. Johnson, “Sasha Sokolov’s Between Dog and Wolf and the Modernist Tradition” 211), Sokolov merges two of his major literary themes: sex and death. Thus, Orina, Maria, that dame (ta dama, ta devochka, ta bobylka, ta babulya — all linked by the demonstrative “ta”), “Life Everlastin,” and death in general make up a unique polymorphic character. Smith notices that this female figure “does not appear at all in the verse. The episode of the sexual encounter between this figure and the sailors, which reoccurs obsessively in the prose, is correspondingly absent from the verse passages” (333). Olga Matich suggests the existence of a literary subtext for Sokolov’s novel: “Pilniak’s lesser known story Mother Earth (Mat’ syra zemlia 1927) about the violent confrontation between a naive young Bolshevik and an archaic Volga peasant community at the time of the Civil War. It is a kind of love story between the city-bred Bolshevik and the horse-tanner and young earth mother Arina, impaled by the Cossacks in one of the story’s many violence-ridden episodes. A variation on the Scythian juxtaposition of nature and culture, the story also depicts Arina’s maternal love for a fox cub, whom she tries to tame, thinking it is a wolf” (“Sasha Sokolov and His Literary Context” 312). The name Orina may also carry an echo of Pushkin’s famous nurse Arina Rodionovna (Toker 353). Mario Caramitti proposes three recurring hypostases of ta dama across Sokolov’s novels: a first hypostasis is that of a “mysterious woman carrying an obscure menace and/or sexual temptation”; a second hypostasis is that of an “apparently better defined and concrete woman being the object of desire for the main character”; and the third hypostasis is that of a “child-woman, often mentally retarded, often victim of violences, who touches upon a slightly more sublimated erotic sphere” (“Amore e morte” 114). Caramitti also adds that in the novel one of ta dama’s victims, before or after committing suicide, explicitly calls her “вечная жизнь” (Life Everlastin): “it is precisely in the coitus with eternity, in a region of oblivion that it is most difficult to place on this side or on the other side of the Lethe, that the male protagonist finds the widest surface of contact with this protean female entity of now vast symbolic implications” (118). Among Orina’s many lovers and among the men who take advantage of her, there is also Yakov, her son, who is in a way “re-enacting the role of the lame Oedipus” (Johnson, “Sasha Sokolov’s Between Dog and Wolf and the Modernist Tradition” 212). In chapter 14, Orina’s patronymic is said to be “Ignat’evna” (daughter of Ignatii): the name Ignatii possibly comes from the Latin “ignis” (fire) (R258/E190). Given that Orina is depicted here through her lust, such a patronymic seems apt. Her last name is said to be alternatively Neklina and Paklina (Spacklin, in translation): “You were called around the barracks Orina Neklina, and to whom do you belong now, to what kind of, let’s suppose, Spacklin, ah?” (R246/E169). On the border with Ukraine, close to Mariupol’ and to Chekhov’s hometown Taganrog, there is Rostov district named Neklinovsky. Paklia and paklina are regional terms indicating different things: a left-handed person, an unhandy and clumsy person, a bony hand, a piece of hemp or coarse fiber, messy hair. The terms паклен (paklen) and неклен (neklen) are named for the Tatar maple (note the slight differences in the spelling between the tree names and Orina’s surnames: Neklina, Paklina). As Sokolov explains, “Apparently, the author of the Notes and Ilya know or have heard about a man named Paklin. Ilya says that Arina’s last name was Neklina, probably after one of her men. And now, years later, Ilya assumes, she lives with someone else, whose last name suggests to him the tree’s other name” (personal communication, July 7, 2023).

character theme intertextuality intratextuality
let’s divide our toys in half

She suggest to separate and split their belongings (“toys”).

explanatory
Ilya

Ilya here refers to himself in the third person. Ilya is Between Dog and Wolf’s protagonist and the author of what he calls the Zaitil’shchina, a long letter with epic traits (starting from its title) addressed to Inspector Pozhilykh in which he comments on the theft of his crutches (he has only one leg) and, more generally, describes life along the Volga River. Johnson defines Ilya’s letter as “semiliterate ramblings,” aptly suggesting the style and register the reader will encounter in the novel (“Sokolov’s Between Dog and Wolf and the Modernist Tradition” 212). However, this character expresses at the same time a highly poetic and imaginative gaze. Ilya frequently associates himself with the biblical prophet Elijah, a figure folklorically linked with thunderstorms and which in Slavic tradition acquired some of the characteristics of the pagan God of the sky and thunder, Perun. Ilya is closely related to other key characters of the novel: he describes his troubled relationship with Orina (alternatively called Maria and the Dame) with whom he has a son; in encountering Yakov (the focus of several chapters), he suggests the possibility of being his father. The Oedipal plot resulting from this triangle has been noted by scholars, such as Johnson, who writes that “the game warden Iakov lusts for his mother (reincarnate as a mentally defective girl) and kills his father-all without being aware of the identity of either” (“Twilight Cosmos” 644).

character folklore intertextuality
plates-foot-bindins

Foot wraps traditionally worn before the widespread use of socks in armies. D.B. Johnson has identified more than twenty different types of shoes across Sokolov’s three novels: “bashmaki, botforty, boty, botinki (polubotinki), cheboty, chizmy, chubury, galoshi (kaloshi), gety, ichigi, kedy, klogi, lapti, mokrostupy, obuvi (obuvki), sapogi, sandalii, tapochki (polutapochki), shlepantsy, shtiblety, tapti, tufli, valenki. The list may easily be extended with appurtenances such as socks, stockings, footcloths, gaiters, skates, crutches, and artificial legs” (“The Galoshes Manifesto” 156). Regarding Between Dog and Wolf, he notes that Ilya’s last name immediately evokes Cinderella’s vair slippers. Johnson observes that “the footwear motif is Sokolov’s tribute, both conscious and unconscious, to the tradition in Russian literature represented by his predecessors – Ivan Bunin and Valentin Kataev” (179). In an interview with A. and N. Voronel’, Sokolov calls Bunin, along with Gogol, his “contemporaries, collaborators along a chain, older masters” (Voroneli, “Ia khochu” 184). Shoe motif.

intertextuality motif
ammunition

Here things, belongings are implied.

explanatory
cheater

Orina.

character explanatory
sonny

Yakov.

character explanatory
rolled down the banisters to the basement, and opened under the stairs a kind of a fur-makin workshop, I became a sort of a chillin furrier.

The narrative becomes confused again: This description matches Orina’s description of the furrier she encounters in her youth in chapter 10 (R220/E123).

intratextuality
chillin furrier

A reference to the expression “холодные сапожники” (cold shoemaker) that once described shoemakers working outside with poor tools, but is also figuratively used to mean “a person who is not passionate about what they do.” The etymology of “skornyak” (leather goods manufacturer) links this profession with “boots” (скорьнь).

phraseologism character language translation
actually

Ilya is explaining that he did various activities (rather than shoemaking or treating leather) in order to earn for a living: “paintin and sellin various inflatable balloons from a pharmacy and inventin squeak-squaks.”

explanatory character
inventin squeak-squaks

Sokolov clarifies: “Ilya here uses the word invented in a humorous sense, in the sense of: made, mastered. And God knows who actually invented this silly toy” (personal communication, August 21, 2023).

explanatory character
squeak-squaks

A toy from the early twentieth century that uses a balloon to make noises when air is released similar to “уйди-уйди” (go away, go away).

explanatory
I also became a whiz on a few instruments

Throughout the novel various words are used to describe the instruments Ilya plays, though it’s, of course, unlikely that he’s carrying all of them around.

music
in search of joys

A reference to the 1939 film “In Search of Joy” (watch it here) or the 1957 play of the same name by Viktor Rozov (read the original here).

intertextuality
skylarks

According to popular tradition, the arrival of this bird indicates that winter is over. Rachel Warren Chadd and Marianne Taylor write: “Chirps, trills and whistles, rising and falling in a rhythmic, minutes-long sequence are the hallmark of the Eurasian Skylark […] hearing its song, as the bird flutters high above a flower meadow or grassland, is the most exhilarating summer experience. […] In mythology and literature it is often linked to daybreak, and its exuberant singing also makes the bird a symbol of joy – both ideas captured in Shakespeare’s Sonnet 29 as the despairing subject thinks of his loved one […] ‘To a Skylark’ by Percy Bysshe Shelley similarly reflects its literary image as a blessed, joyful bird.” (236–237). However, despite its appeal and folkloric heritage, the “Eurasian Skylark and its relatives have also suffered horrific abuse,” including widespread hunting and inclusion in cruelly complex recipes such as “lark tongue pie” (237–238). For additional notes on the lark’s literary reputation, see Rowland, Birds 97–101. Animal motif.

motif time
You’ll ascend the garbage mound to get some rest—your spirit will flare up: A tip-top site!

Throughout the novel, the characters feel compelled to move upward and/or are dragged downward.

theme
a three-pawed bitch

Even dogs are invalid in this novel.

explanatory
a man is a man to man

A play on the Latin proverb “Homo homini lupus” (Man is a wolf to man). Ilya suggests here that people here treat each other respectfully. However, we know that is not the case. Animal-human motif. Ostanin also suggests that it’s a reference to the Soviet slogan “Человек человеку — друг, товарищ и брат” (Man is to man a friend, comrade, and brother, 100).

intertextuality foreign motif
smokes of the fatherland

A reference to Soviet-made cigarettes. Ostanin notes several allusions: Homer’s Odyssey (Russian/English), Gavrila Derzhavin’s 1798 poem “Afra” (Russian), and Alexander Griboyedov’s 1823 play Woe from Wit (Russian/English) (100). There is also a 1980 film with with the same name.

foreign phraseologism intertextuality
that uprisin

Sokolov clarifies that “most likely, Ilya is referring to the coup d’état that took place in the year 1917 and was called the Great October Socialist Revolution. Uprisings occurred in other years, but all of them in his imagination merged into one insignificant event. Generally speaking, history is a vague and uninteresting thing for Ilya” (personal communication, August 26, 2023).

explanatory Russia character
he needs nothin else

He does not seek out foreign or alien adventures.

explanatory
In those same quarters I put together a decent lidrary, so to speak, that is, a collection of multicolored tops from various mixtures

These are the bits and pieces Ilya has picked up in the dump.

explanatory
lidrary

Neologism: library of lids.

neologism
You

The inspector, Sidor Fomich Pozhilykh, to whom Ilya is addressing his letter of complaint.

explanatory character
western

Possibly meaning Ukrainian here.

explanatory
she was sixty-plus years old—a delicacy, no more no less

In his third novel, Palisandriia (translated into English as Astrophobia by Michael Henry Heim) Sokolov will recount the life and times of Palinsandr’ Dalberg, a Kremlin orphan with a preference for older women. See Matich “About Palisandriia” for a summary of the text. Read the novel here.

intertextuality
I had a fleetin crush on her, as also happened, incidently, with her grand-ward, or similar to it, for which, of course, in retrospect, I blame myself, if that’s required

The narrative becomes confused again: This description matches Orina’s description of the furrier she encounters in her youth in chapter 10 (R220/E123).

intratextuality
scrape

Ilya cleaned the hide.

explanatory
Fomich

Sidor Pozhilykh’s patronymic. A familiar form of address that uses a shortened version of the patronymic.

register/style character
I deployed myself with the adolescent in excitement and at the heat of the moment

That is, Ilya took advantage of the girl (Orina).

explanatory
under the bowroat

This scene is mentioned by Orina in chapter 8 (R211/E108).

intratextuality
bowroat

Rowboat. Boat motif.

motif register/style
some rivermen secretly cleave my teenager

The narrative becomes confused again: this description matches Orina’s description of the sailors she encounters in her youth in chapter 10 (R220/E124).

intratextuality
doin what the young do, that’s their right

A variation on lines from Soviet Vice-chairman of the Council of People’s Commissar and People’s Commissar for Foreign Affairs Vyacheslav M. Molotov’s June 22, 1941 speech on the occasion of the German invasion: “Our cause is just” (Ostanin 101). Read the original here and an English translation here.

intertextuality
Orina

Orina, along with her variants, is the primary female character in the novel. In a sense, she is the only female figure in Between Dog and Wolf. As D.B. Johnson summarizes, the “promiscuous heroine Orina-Mariia is a train dispatcher, a princess in her dispatcher’s tower, who entertains her coworkers in her bed. Some of her orgiastic trysts take place near the train tracks to which her lovers tie her meddling husband Il’ia. Orina, in at least one time dimension, is killed by a train as she belatedly tries to save Il’ia who loses his leg” (“Twilight Cosmos” 647). Ilya is obsessed with this woman, and this passion “is the ultimate source of the woes that befall Il’ia, the itinerant grinder. It is his passion for the faithless slut Orina that brings about his misfortunes: the loss of his leg, his wandering life as a drunken grinder, and the grisly events that lead to his death” (643). Orina, alternatively called Maria, exists in the book also in another version, as ta dama, that dame, “a mysterious woman who appears along the river seeking Il’ia and, failing to find him, takes away a new lover each time […]. Her chance lovers return days later, sexually depleted and without interest in life. They usually die by their own hand” (645). In this figure (which embodies “virtually all female figures in the book,” D.B. Johnson, “Sasha Sokolov’s Between Dog and Wolf and the Modernist Tradition” 211), Sokolov merges two of his major literary themes: sex and death. Thus, Orina, Maria, that dame (ta dama, ta devochka, ta bobylka, ta babulya — all linked by the demonstrative “ta”), “Life Everlastin,” and death in general make up a unique polymorphic character. Smith notices that this female figure “does not appear at all in the verse. The episode of the sexual encounter between this figure and the sailors, which reoccurs obsessively in the prose, is correspondingly absent from the verse passages” (333). Olga Matich suggests the existence of a literary subtext for Sokolov’s novel: “Pilniak’s lesser known story Mother Earth (Mat’ syra zemlia 1927) about the violent confrontation between a naive young Bolshevik and an archaic Volga peasant community at the time of the Civil War. It is a kind of love story between the city-bred Bolshevik and the horse-tanner and young earth mother Arina, impaled by the Cossacks in one of the story’s many violence-ridden episodes. A variation on the Scythian juxtaposition of nature and culture, the story also depicts Arina’s maternal love for a fox cub, whom she tries to tame, thinking it is a wolf” (“Sasha Sokolov and His Literary Context” 312). The name Orina may also carry an echo of Pushkin’s famous nurse Arina Rodionovna (Toker 353). Mario Caramitti proposes three recurring hypostases of ta dama across Sokolov’s novels: a first hypostasis is that of a “mysterious woman carrying an obscure menace and/or sexual temptation”; a second hypostasis is that of an “apparently better defined and concrete woman being the object of desire for the main character”; and the third hypostasis is that of a “child-woman, often mentally retarded, often victim of violences, who touches upon a slightly more sublimated erotic sphere” (“Amore e morte” 114). Caramitti also adds that in the novel one of ta dama’s victims, before or after committing suicide, explicitly calls her “вечная жизнь” (Life Everlastin): “it is precisely in the coitus with eternity, in a region of oblivion that it is most difficult to place on this side or on the other side of the Lethe, that the male protagonist finds the widest surface of contact with this protean female entity of now vast symbolic implications” (118). Among Orina’s many lovers and among the men who take advantage of her, there is also Yakov, her son, who is in a way “re-enacting the role of the lame Oedipus” (Johnson, “Sasha Sokolov’s Between Dog and Wolf and the Modernist Tradition” 212). In chapter 14, Orina’s patronymic is said to be “Ignat’evna” (daughter of Ignatii): the name Ignatii possibly comes from the Latin “ignis” (fire) (R258/E190). Given that Orina is depicted here through her lust, such a patronymic seems apt. Her last name is said to be alternatively Neklina and Paklina (Spacklin, in translation): “You were called around the barracks Orina Neklina, and to whom do you belong now, to what kind of, let’s suppose, Spacklin, ah?” (R246/E169). On the border with Ukraine, close to Mariupol’ and to Chekhov’s hometown Taganrog, there is Rostov district named Neklinovsky. Paklia and paklina are regional terms indicating different things: a left-handed person, an unhandy and clumsy person, a bony hand, a piece of hemp or coarse fiber, messy hair. The terms паклен (paklen) and неклен (neklen) are named for the Tatar maple (note the slight differences in the spelling between the tree names and Orina’s surnames: Neklina, Paklina). As Sokolov explains, “Apparently, the author of the Notes and Ilya know or have heard about a man named Paklin. Ilya says that Arina’s last name was Neklina, probably after one of her men. And now, years later, Ilya assumes, she lives with someone else, whose last name suggests to him the tree’s other name” (personal communication, July 7, 2023).

character theme intertextuality intratextuality
rails

Railroad theme.

theme
scow

Boat motif.

motif
flies

Animal motif.

motif
over the exposed places

On uncovered parts of his body.

explanatory
Assumption

August 15/28. Celebration of Mary Mother of God’s death and bodily assumption into Heaven.

time religion bible
rowlock

Ilya mentions “rowlocks crying” in chapter 8 (R206/E105). Boat motif.

motif intratextuality
wolf spider

Animal motif.

motif
Pasha

“Spider” (паук, pauk) is sometimes used as a nickname for Pavel/Pasha due to the phonetic similarity. Animal-human motif.

motif explanatory
Pasha, my comin, my Spider, wrote Pyotr to his nephew from the village, I haven’t seen an event more borin than January without yeast, so bring it hook or crook

Here, Ilya returns to the events at the beginning of chapter 4, in which Pavel writes to Pyotr and the latter struggles to find the letter zhe (ж) in the yeast (дрожжи) (R173–174/E43–44).

intratextuality
You will not bring it, after all; woe is us, tipplers, in that case

The characters are hoping to use the yeast to produce alcohol, which explains why they are so desperate in its absence. Alcohol theme.

theme explanatory
Pavel

Foma Pogibel’ is one of the two oarsmen who carry people (dead or alive) across the river (a variation of the Charon Greek myth). The other oarsman is Eryoma (diminutive of Eremei, Jeremiah). However, in Note XXXI the oarsman is called Pavel, just like the character who sends his uncle Pyotr to get yeast in Gorodnishche. As underlined by one of the epigraphs in Sokolov’s first novel, A School for Fools, the biblical name of Pavel is somehow interchangeable: “Saul, who is called Paul” (see Acts 13:9–10). As for Foma, he carries a biblical name, too (Thomas), whose Aramaic origin suggests the idea of the “twin.” This apostle is famous as “Doubting Thomas” due to his denial of the resurrection of Jesus, according to the Gospel of John (see John 20:24–31). In the Orthodox tradition, the Sunday following Easter is called “Thomas Sunday”: the day when Christ appeared to his disciples; it took seeing Jesus’ body for Thomas to name him “My Lord and my God.”

intertextuality religion bible character
Fenist

Here, the Finist substitutes for the common pigeon. See the fairy tale “The Feather of Finist the Falcon” (or “Finist the Falcon”) collected by Aleksandr Afanas’yev. Read the original here and an English translation here. As Margaret Ziolkowski points out, “much as the grinder [Ilya] is crippled by a train because his wife’s lovers tie him to the track, Fenist cuts his wings when his beloved’s jealous sisters fasten knives and needles to her windowstill. Yet Fenist does ultimately find martial bliss, while Il’ia loses his wife when she futilely attempts to rescue him” (414). Animal motif.

intertextuality motif
Ilyusha

Diminutive of Ilya.

character register/style
our prophet

Ilya is frequently compared—by the narrator and by himself—to the prophet Ilya/Elijah, who is commonly associated with lightning and thunder.

character bible religion intertextuality
Pyotr

Pyotr/Fyodor/Yegor. Pyotr, “one smart aleck from Sloboda” (R173/E43), is Pavel’s uncle and is sent by his nephew in Gorodnishche to find yeast (when the story is retold in chapter 14, it is the uncle asking Pavel to get yeast). He is alternatively called Fyodor and Egor: the choice seems to be guided by the presence of the vowels “e/ë” and “o.” The name Pyotr, from Greek, means “stone.” The apostle Peter (Simon Peter), in origin a fisherman, is considered the first Christian Pope. Peter denied Jesus three times during the events of the crucifixion, as Jesus had predicted (see Matthew 26:69–75). Fyodor (Theodore) means “God’s gift.” The name Egor is a variation of the name Georgy (George), from the Greek “farmer.” He was immortalized as a saint through the legend of the Dragon (Saint George the Dragon-slayer). In chapter 10 this character is challenged to hang himself, which results in his suicide.

character intratextuality foreign religion
home brew

Alcohol theme.

theme
helped us with the letter zhe

This refers to the moment at the beginning of chapter 4, in which Ilya’s grinding wheel breaks and consequently presents Pavel and Pyotr with the missing letter zhe (ж) in the form of the broken wheel (R173–174/E43–44).

intratextuality
Beyond the Wolf

In the original, instead of indicating the territories that serve as setting for the novel as “Zavolzh’e” (Transvolga), the author creates this neologism (Transwolf-river) on the basis of his alternative spelling of the Volga River as “Volch’ia,” Wolf river.

translation location setting Russia
marvles

Marvelous.

register/style
boots

D.B. Johnson has identified more than twenty different types of shoes across Sokolov’s three novels: “bashmaki, botforty, boty, botinki (polubotinki), cheboty, chizmy, chubury, galoshi (kaloshi), gety, ichigi, kedy, klogi, lapti, mokrostupy, obuvi (obuvki), sapogi, sandalii, tapochki (polutapochki), shlepantsy, shtiblety, tapti, tufli, valenki. The list may easily be extended with appurtenances such as socks, stockings, footcloths, gaiters, skates, crutches, and artificial legs” (“The Galoshes Manifesto” 156). Regarding Between Dog and Wolf, he notes that Ilya’s last name immediately evokes Cinderella’s vair slippers. Johnson observes that “the footwear motif is Sokolov’s tribute, both conscious and unconscious, to the tradition in Russian literature represented by his predecessors – Ivan Bunin and Valentin Kataev” (179). In an interview with A. and N. Voronel’, Sokolov calls Bunin, along with Gogol, his “contemporaries, collaborators along a chain, older masters” (Voroneli, “Ia khochu” 184). Shoe motif.

intertextuality motif
valenki

Traditional Russian winter felt boots. D.B. Johnson has identified more than twenty different types of shoes across Sokolov’s three novels: “bashmaki, botforty, boty, botinki (polubotinki), cheboty, chizmy, chubury, galoshi (kaloshi), gety, ichigi, kedy, klogi, lapti, mokrostupy, obuvi (obuvki), sapogi, sandalii, tapochki (polutapochki), shlepantsy, shtiblety, tapti, tufli, valenki. The list may easily be extended with appurtenances such as socks, stockings, footcloths, gaiters, skates, crutches, and artificial legs” (“The Galoshes Manifesto” 156). Regarding Between Dog and Wolf, he notes that Ilya’s last name immediately evokes Cinderella’s vair slippers. Johnson observes that “the footwear motif is Sokolov’s tribute, both conscious and unconscious, to the tradition in Russian literature represented by his predecessors – Ivan Bunin and Valentin Kataev” (179). In an interview with A. and N. Voronel’, Sokolov calls Bunin, along with Gogol, his “contemporaries, collaborators along a chain, older masters” (Voroneli, “Ia khochu” 184). Shoe motif.

intertextuality motif Russia
will be the flutterin above us

The subject is winter, which is approaching “like a dreadful nightmare” while they still have no yeast.

explanatory
sand

As at the end of the chapter, Ilya refers to sand used to seal ink on paper to avoid smears.

explanatory
lonesome snowbabe

She will make several appearances throughout the novel and is associated with Orina. Here, the word play is built on the expression “snowman/snowwoman.”

character intratextuality language translation
broke into a serious drip

That is, as Ostanin notes, she has caught a cold and begun to drip from her nose (101).

explanatory
side-warmer

As Boguslawski translates it, “side-warmer,” meaning a shift in weather that will warm your sides. A reference to St. Sidor Bokogrei, whose day is celebrated on May 14/27. He was given this name, because it was said that bitterly cold northern winds would stop blowing on this date. Likewise, swifts and swallows would fly to Sidor with the approach of warm weather. However, people caution against taking the appearance of the first bird as a sure sign of the cold’s departure, similar to the following clause. Read his saint’s life here. The addressee of Ilya’s letter is, of course, Sidor Fomich Pozhilykh. Animal motif.

time translation religion motif intertextuality character
March may still force you to sell your last shirt

The meaning is that March, as a transitional month between winter and spring, brings with it some challenges: occasional unexpected shifts in weather, low resources before the harvest.

explanatory
Fenist

Here, the Finist substitutes for the common pigeon. See the fairy tale “The Feather of Finist the Falcon” (or “Finist the Falcon”) collected by Aleksandr Afanas’yev. Read the original here and an English translation here. As Margaret Ziolkowski points out, “much as the grinder [Ilya] is crippled by a train because his wife’s lovers tie him to the track, Fenist cuts his wings when his beloved’s jealous sisters fasten knives and needles to her windowstill. Yet Fenist does ultimately find martial bliss, while Il’ia loses his wife when she futilely attempts to rescue him” (414). Animal motif.

intertextuality motif
Pavel

Foma Pogibel’ is one of the two oarsmen who carry people (dead or alive) across the river (a variation of the Charon Greek myth). The other oarsman is Eryoma (diminutive of Eremei, Jeremiah). However, in Note XXXI the oarsman is called Pavel, just like the character who sends his uncle Pyotr to get yeast in Gorodnishche. As underlined by one of the epigraphs in Sokolov’s first novel, A School for Fools, the biblical name of Pavel is somehow interchangeable: “Saul, who is called Paul” (see Acts 13:9–10). As for Foma, he carries a biblical name, too (Thomas), whose Aramaic origin suggests the idea of the “twin.” This apostle is famous as “Doubting Thomas” due to his denial of the resurrection of Jesus, according to the Gospel of John (see John 20:24–31). In the Orthodox tradition, the Sunday following Easter is called “Thomas Sunday”: the day when Christ appeared to his disciples; it took seeing Jesus’ body for Thomas to name him “My Lord and my God.”

intertextuality religion bible character
uncle

Pyotr/Fyodor/Yegor. Pyotr, “one smart aleck from Sloboda” (R173/E43), is Pavel’s uncle and is sent by his nephew in Gorodnishche to find yeast (when the story is retold in chapter 14, it is the uncle asking Pavel to get yeast). He is alternatively called Fyodor and Egor: the choice seems to be guided by the presence of the vowels “e/ë” and “o.” The name Pyotr, from Greek, means “stone.” The apostle Peter (Simon Peter), in origin a fisherman, is considered the first Christian Pope. Peter denied Jesus three times during the events of the crucifixion, as Jesus had predicted (see Matthew 26:69–75). Fyodor (Theodore) means “God’s gift.” The name Egor is a variation of the name Georgy (George), from the Greek “farmer.” He was immortalized as a saint through the legend of the Dragon (Saint George the Dragon-slayer). In chapter 10 this character is challenged to hang himself, which results in his suicide.

character intertextuality foreign religion
Ilya

Ilya here refers to himself in the third person. Ilya is Between Dog and Wolf’s protagonist and the author of what he calls the Zaitil’shchina, a long letter with epic traits (starting from its title) addressed to Inspector Pozhilykh in which he comments on the theft of his crutches (he has only one leg) and, more generally, describes life along the Volga River. Johnson defines Ilya’s letter as “semiliterate ramblings,” aptly suggesting the style and register the reader will encounter in the novel (“Sokolov’s Between Dog and Wolf and the Modernist Tradition” 212). However, this character expresses at the same time a highly poetic and imaginative gaze. Ilya frequently associates himself with the biblical prophet Elijah, a figure folklorically linked with thunderstorms and which in Slavic tradition acquired some of the characteristics of the pagan God of the sky and thunder, Perun. Ilya is closely related to other key characters of the novel: he describes his troubled relationship with Orina (alternatively called Maria and the Dame) with whom he has a son; in encountering Yakov (the focus of several chapters), he suggests the possibility of being his father. The Oedipal plot resulting from this triangle has been noted by scholars, such as Johnson, who writes that “the game warden Iakov lusts for his mother (reincarnate as a mentally defective girl) and kills his father-all without being aware of the identity of either” (“Twilight Cosmos” 644).

intertextuality folklore character
I’m not dispensin money but healins

Ilya grinds not for money but rather for “healing” (i.e., alcohol). Alcohol theme.

explanatory theme
guzzled

Alcohol theme.

theme
accessories

That is, his crutches. Ilya accuses Pavel and the other hunters of stealing his crutches.

explanatory
you and the saints like you

Ilya refers to the fact that Pavel, like many of the other hunters, share names with saints.

religion bible
blizzie

Boguslawski explains it as “the endearing diminutive form of the word ‘blizzard’” (“Annotations” 253).

register/style
whipper-in

Yakov.

character
ultimat

Neologism: ультиматум (ultimatum) + мат (obscenity).

neologism translation
in secrecy

Ilya invites him not to wash dirty linen in public.

explanatory
without proclaimin it from the housetops

A reference to Luke 12:3 (Boguslawski, “Annotations” 253).

intertextuality religion bible
neither the wolf nor the hound

Between dog and wolf. Animal motif.

theme motif
I, bein amenable, would hope for the return of one instead of two

Ilya is ready to accept also only one of his crutches instead of both.

explanatory
your bodily beacons

The eyes. A reference to Matthew 6:22.

religion bible intertextuality
watch out so you won’t get tossed accidentally into the outside darkness

A death threat.

explanatory
tossed accidentally into the outside darkness

A reference to Matthew 8:12. “Outer darkness” refers to the space into which nonbelievers will be cast out from the kingdom of Heaven.

intertextuality religion bible
You

The inspector, Sidor Fomich Pozhilykh, to whom Ilya is addressing his letter of complaint.

explanatory character
Spider

That is, Pavel/Pyotr/Fyodor. Animal-human motif.

motif character
chill rebuff

Allusion to a line from Tatiana’s letter to Onegin, in Pushkin’s Eugene Onegin, chapter 3 (Boguslawski “Annotations” 253).

intertextuality
how with his trunk he kept takin out the souls of the flies under the boat

As Sokolov explains, “Ilya observes the spider’s actions toward the insects. In telling about the spider, Ilya associatively recalls the correspondence between Paul and Peter about yeast,” since “a person named Pavel may receive the nickname Spider: this is probably due to the spelling of the foreign variant of this name: Paul” (personal communication, July 29, 2023). Animal motif.

motif explanatory character
Orya

Orina, along with her variants, is the primary female character in the novel. In a sense, she is the only female figure in Between Dog and Wolf. As D.B. Johnson summarizes, the “promiscuous heroine Orina-Mariia is a train dispatcher, a princess in her dispatcher’s tower, who entertains her coworkers in her bed. Some of her orgiastic trysts take place near the train tracks to which her lovers tie her meddling husband Il’ia. Orina, in at least one time dimension, is killed by a train as she belatedly tries to save Il’ia who loses his leg” (“Twilight Cosmos” 647). Ilya is obsessed with this woman, and this passion “is the ultimate source of the woes that befall Il’ia, the itinerant grinder. It is his passion for the faithless slut Orina that brings about his misfortunes: the loss of his leg, his wandering life as a drunken grinder, and the grisly events that lead to his death” (643). Orina, alternatively called Maria, exists in the book also in another version, as ta dama, that dame, “a mysterious woman who appears along the river seeking Il’ia and, failing to find him, takes away a new lover each time […]. Her chance lovers return days later, sexually depleted and without interest in life. They usually die by their own hand” (645). In this figure (which embodies “virtually all female figures in the book,” D.B. Johnson, “Sasha Sokolov’s Between Dog and Wolf and the Modernist Tradition” 211), Sokolov merges two of his major literary themes: sex and death. Thus, Orina, Maria, that dame (ta dama, ta devochka, ta bobylka, ta babulya — all linked by the demonstrative “ta”), “Life Everlastin,” and death in general make up a unique polymorphic character. Smith notices that this female figure “does not appear at all in the verse. The episode of the sexual encounter between this figure and the sailors, which reoccurs obsessively in the prose, is correspondingly absent from the verse passages” (333). Olga Matich suggests the existence of a literary subtext for Sokolov’s novel: “Pilniak’s lesser known story Mother Earth (Mat’ syra zemlia 1927) about the violent confrontation between a naive young Bolshevik and an archaic Volga peasant community at the time of the Civil War. It is a kind of love story between the city-bred Bolshevik and the horse-tanner and young earth mother Arina, impaled by the Cossacks in one of the story’s many violence-ridden episodes. A variation on the Scythian juxtaposition of nature and culture, the story also depicts Arina’s maternal love for a fox cub, whom she tries to tame, thinking it is a wolf” (“Sasha Sokolov and His Literary Context” 312). The name Orina may also carry an echo of Pushkin’s famous nurse Arina Rodionovna (Toker 353). Mario Caramitti proposes three recurring hypostases of ta dama across Sokolov’s novels: a first hypostasis is that of a “mysterious woman carrying an obscure menace and/or sexual temptation”; a second hypostasis is that of an “apparently better defined and concrete woman being the object of desire for the main character”; and the third hypostasis is that of a “child-woman, often mentally retarded, often victim of violences, who touches upon a slightly more sublimated erotic sphere” (“Amore e morte” 114). Caramitti also adds that in the novel one of ta dama’s victims, before or after committing suicide, explicitly calls her “вечная жизнь” (Life Everlastin): “it is precisely in the coitus with eternity, in a region of oblivion that it is most difficult to place on this side or on the other side of the Lethe, that the male protagonist finds the widest surface of contact with this protean female entity of now vast symbolic implications” (118). Among Orina’s many lovers and among the men who take advantage of her, there is also Yakov, her son, who is in a way “re-enacting the role of the lame Oedipus” (Johnson, “Sasha Sokolov’s Between Dog and Wolf and the Modernist Tradition” 212). In chapter 14, Orina’s patronymic is said to be “Ignat’evna” (daughter of Ignatii): the name Ignatii possibly comes from the Latin “ignis” (fire) (R258/E190). Given that Orina is depicted here through her lust, such a patronymic seems apt. Her last name is said to be alternatively Neklina and Paklina (Spacklin, in translation): “You were called around the barracks Orina Neklina, and to whom do you belong now, to what kind of, let’s suppose, Spacklin, ah?” (R246/E169). On the border with Ukraine, close to Mariupol’ and to Chekhov’s hometown Taganrog, there is Rostov district named Neklinovsky. Paklia and paklina are regional terms indicating different things: a left-handed person, an unhandy and clumsy person, a bony hand, a piece of hemp or coarse fiber, messy hair. The terms паклен (paklen) and неклен (neklen) are named for the Tatar maple (note the slight differences in the spelling between the tree names and Orina’s surnames: Neklina, Paklina). As Sokolov explains, “Apparently, the author of the Notes and Ilya know or have heard about a man named Paklin. Ilya says that Arina’s last name was Neklina, probably after one of her men. And now, years later, Ilya assumes, she lives with someone else, whose last name suggests to him the tree’s other name” (personal communication, July 7, 2023).

intertextuality intratextuality theme character
Orya

Orina, along with her variants, is the primary female character in the novel. In a sense, she is the only female figure in Between Dog and Wolf. As D.B. Johnson summarizes, the “promiscuous heroine Orina-Mariia is a train dispatcher, a princess in her dispatcher’s tower, who entertains her coworkers in her bed. Some of her orgiastic trysts take place near the train tracks to which her lovers tie her meddling husband Il’ia. Orina, in at least one time dimension, is killed by a train as she belatedly tries to save Il’ia who loses his leg” (“Twilight Cosmos” 647). Ilya is obsessed with this woman, and this passion “is the ultimate source of the woes that befall Il’ia, the itinerant grinder. It is his passion for the faithless slut Orina that brings about his misfortunes: the loss of his leg, his wandering life as a drunken grinder, and the grisly events that lead to his death” (643). Orina, alternatively called Maria, exists in the book also in another version, as ta dama, that dame, “a mysterious woman who appears along the river seeking Il’ia and, failing to find him, takes away a new lover each time […]. Her chance lovers return days later, sexually depleted and without interest in life. They usually die by their own hand” (645). In this figure (which embodies “virtually all female figures in the book,” D.B. Johnson, “Sasha Sokolov’s Between Dog and Wolf and the Modernist Tradition” 211), Sokolov merges two of his major literary themes: sex and death. Thus, Orina, Maria, that dame (ta dama, ta devochka, ta bobylka, ta babulya — all linked by the demonstrative “ta”), “Life Everlastin,” and death in general make up a unique polymorphic character. Smith notices that this female figure “does not appear at all in the verse. The episode of the sexual encounter between this figure and the sailors, which reoccurs obsessively in the prose, is correspondingly absent from the verse passages” (333). Olga Matich suggests the existence of a literary subtext for Sokolov’s novel: “Pilniak’s lesser known story Mother Earth (Mat’ syra zemlia 1927) about the violent confrontation between a naive young Bolshevik and an archaic Volga peasant community at the time of the Civil War. It is a kind of love story between the city-bred Bolshevik and the horse-tanner and young earth mother Arina, impaled by the Cossacks in one of the story’s many violence-ridden episodes. A variation on the Scythian juxtaposition of nature and culture, the story also depicts Arina’s maternal love for a fox cub, whom she tries to tame, thinking it is a wolf” (“Sasha Sokolov and His Literary Context” 312). The name Orina may also carry an echo of Pushkin’s famous nurse Arina Rodionovna (Toker 353). Mario Caramitti proposes three recurring hypostases of ta dama across Sokolov’s novels: a first hypostasis is that of a “mysterious woman carrying an obscure menace and/or sexual temptation”; a second hypostasis is that of an “apparently better defined and concrete woman being the object of desire for the main character”; and the third hypostasis is that of a “child-woman, often mentally retarded, often victim of violences, who touches upon a slightly more sublimated erotic sphere” (“Amore e morte” 114). Caramitti also adds that in the novel one of ta dama’s victims, before or after committing suicide, explicitly calls her “вечная жизнь” (Life Everlastin): “it is precisely in the coitus with eternity, in a region of oblivion that it is most difficult to place on this side or on the other side of the Lethe, that the male protagonist finds the widest surface of contact with this protean female entity of now vast symbolic implications” (118). Among Orina’s many lovers and among the men who take advantage of her, there is also Yakov, her son, who is in a way “re-enacting the role of the lame Oedipus” (Johnson, “Sasha Sokolov’s Between Dog and Wolf and the Modernist Tradition” 212). In chapter 14, Orina’s patronymic is said to be “Ignat’evna” (daughter of Ignatii): the name Ignatii possibly comes from the Latin “ignis” (fire) (R258/E190). Given that Orina is depicted here through her lust, such a patronymic seems apt. Her last name is said to be alternatively Neklina and Paklina (Spacklin, in translation): “You were called around the barracks Orina Neklina, and to whom do you belong now, to what kind of, let’s suppose, Spacklin, ah?” (R246/E169). On the border with Ukraine, close to Mariupol’ and to Chekhov’s hometown Taganrog, there is Rostov district named Neklinovsky. Paklia and paklina are regional terms indicating different things: a left-handed person, an unhandy and clumsy person, a bony hand, a piece of hemp or coarse fiber, messy hair. The terms паклен (paklen) and неклен (neklen) are named for the Tatar maple (note the slight differences in the spelling between the tree names and Orina’s surnames: Neklina, Paklina). As Sokolov explains, “Apparently, the author of the Notes and Ilya know or have heard about a man named Paklin. Ilya says that Arina’s last name was Neklina, probably after one of her men. And now, years later, Ilya assumes, she lives with someone else, whose last name suggests to him the tree’s other name” (personal communication, July 7, 2023).

character theme intertextuality intratextuality
On weekdays of the paycheck or on Fridays of the advance

These words will be repeated shortly below in modified form. This episode is also mentioned in chapter 8 (R211/E107).

intratextuality
in the famed alders beyond the tracks

These words will be repeated shortly below.

intratextuality
alders

Plant motif.

motif
Orina

Orina, along with her variants, is the primary female character in the novel. In a sense, she is the only female figure in Between Dog and Wolf. As D.B. Johnson summarizes, the “promiscuous heroine Orina-Mariia is a train dispatcher, a princess in her dispatcher’s tower, who entertains her coworkers in her bed. Some of her orgiastic trysts take place near the train tracks to which her lovers tie her meddling husband Il’ia. Orina, in at least one time dimension, is killed by a train as she belatedly tries to save Il’ia who loses his leg” (“Twilight Cosmos” 647). Ilya is obsessed with this woman, and this passion “is the ultimate source of the woes that befall Il’ia, the itinerant grinder. It is his passion for the faithless slut Orina that brings about his misfortunes: the loss of his leg, his wandering life as a drunken grinder, and the grisly events that lead to his death” (643). Orina, alternatively called Maria, exists in the book also in another version, as ta dama, that dame, “a mysterious woman who appears along the river seeking Il’ia and, failing to find him, takes away a new lover each time […]. Her chance lovers return days later, sexually depleted and without interest in life. They usually die by their own hand” (645). In this figure (which embodies “virtually all female figures in the book,” D.B. Johnson, “Sasha Sokolov’s Between Dog and Wolf and the Modernist Tradition” 211), Sokolov merges two of his major literary themes: sex and death. Thus, Orina, Maria, that dame (ta dama, ta devochka, ta bobylka, ta babulya — all linked by the demonstrative “ta”), “Life Everlastin,” and death in general make up a unique polymorphic character. Smith notices that this female figure “does not appear at all in the verse. The episode of the sexual encounter between this figure and the sailors, which reoccurs obsessively in the prose, is correspondingly absent from the verse passages” (333). Olga Matich suggests the existence of a literary subtext for Sokolov’s novel: “Pilniak’s lesser known story Mother Earth (Mat’ syra zemlia 1927) about the violent confrontation between a naive young Bolshevik and an archaic Volga peasant community at the time of the Civil War. It is a kind of love story between the city-bred Bolshevik and the horse-tanner and young earth mother Arina, impaled by the Cossacks in one of the story’s many violence-ridden episodes. A variation on the Scythian juxtaposition of nature and culture, the story also depicts Arina’s maternal love for a fox cub, whom she tries to tame, thinking it is a wolf” (“Sasha Sokolov and His Literary Context” 312). The name Orina may also carry an echo of Pushkin’s famous nurse Arina Rodionovna (Toker 353). Mario Caramitti proposes three recurring hypostases of ta dama across Sokolov’s novels: a first hypostasis is that of a “mysterious woman carrying an obscure menace and/or sexual temptation”; a second hypostasis is that of an “apparently better defined and concrete woman being the object of desire for the main character”; and the third hypostasis is that of a “child-woman, often mentally retarded, often victim of violences, who touches upon a slightly more sublimated erotic sphere” (“Amore e morte” 114). Caramitti also adds that in the novel one of ta dama’s victims, before or after committing suicide, explicitly calls her “вечная жизнь” (Life Everlastin): “it is precisely in the coitus with eternity, in a region of oblivion that it is most difficult to place on this side or on the other side of the Lethe, that the male protagonist finds the widest surface of contact with this protean female entity of now vast symbolic implications” (118). Among Orina’s many lovers and among the men who take advantage of her, there is also Yakov, her son, who is in a way “re-enacting the role of the lame Oedipus” (Johnson, “Sasha Sokolov’s Between Dog and Wolf and the Modernist Tradition” 212). In chapter 14, Orina’s patronymic is said to be “Ignat’evna” (daughter of Ignatii): the name Ignatii possibly comes from the Latin “ignis” (fire) (R258/E190). Given that Orina is depicted here through her lust, such a patronymic seems apt. Her last name is said to be alternatively Neklina and Paklina (Spacklin, in translation): “You were called around the barracks Orina Neklina, and to whom do you belong now, to what kind of, let’s suppose, Spacklin, ah?” (R246/E169). On the border with Ukraine, close to Mariupol’ and to Chekhov’s hometown Taganrog, there is Rostov district named Neklinovsky. Paklia and paklina are regional terms indicating different things: a left-handed person, an unhandy and clumsy person, a bony hand, a piece of hemp or coarse fiber, messy hair. The terms паклен (paklen) and неклен (neklen) are named for the Tatar maple (note the slight differences in the spelling between the tree names and Orina’s surnames: Neklina, Paklina). As Sokolov explains, “Apparently, the author of the Notes and Ilya know or have heard about a man named Paklin. Ilya says that Arina’s last name was Neklina, probably after one of her men. And now, years later, Ilya assumes, she lives with someone else, whose last name suggests to him the tree’s other name” (personal communication, July 7, 2023).

intertextuality intratextuality character theme
Ignatyevna

This is the only mention in the book of Orina’s patronymic (daughter of Ignatii). A certain Ignatii Vartolomeich is mentioned in chapter 5 in the historical “Gogolian” scenes.

character
hair pick

A key image in Ilya and Orina’s relationship. He gives it to her, and she lies about losing it on the train tracks. Introduced in chapter 1 (R156/E12). Comb motif.

motif intratextuality
Kashin

Kashin — a town in the Tver Oblast on the Kashinka River (a tributary of the Volga). As Ostanin explains, Ilya here refers to a vodka created in 1898 by a liquor-vodka factory in Kashin (102). Boguslawski adds: “According to a popular belief, even the greatest drunk wouldn’t drink that vodka without saying ‘God save us’” (“Annotations” 253). Alcohol theme.

location Russia theme
Ilya

Ilya here refers to himself in the third person. Ilya is Between Dog and Wolf’s protagonist and the author of what he calls the Zaitil’shchina, a long letter with epic traits (starting from its title) addressed to Inspector Pozhilykh in which he comments on the theft of his crutches (he has only one leg) and, more generally, describes life along the Volga River. Johnson defines Ilya’s letter as “semiliterate ramblings,” aptly suggesting the style and register the reader will encounter in the novel (“Sokolov’s Between Dog and Wolf and the Modernist Tradition” 212). However, this character expresses at the same time a highly poetic and imaginative gaze. Ilya frequently associates himself with the biblical prophet Elijah, a figure folklorically linked with thunderstorms and which in Slavic tradition acquired some of the characteristics of the pagan God of the sky and thunder, Perun. Ilya is closely related to other key characters of the novel: he describes his troubled relationship with Orina (alternatively called Maria and the Dame) with whom he has a son; in encountering Yakov (the focus of several chapters), he suggests the possibility of being his father. The Oedipal plot resulting from this triangle has been noted by scholars, such as Johnson, who writes that “the game warden Iakov lusts for his mother (reincarnate as a mentally defective girl) and kills his father-all without being aware of the identity of either” (“Twilight Cosmos” 644).

intertextuality folklore character
twilights

Between dog and wolf.

theme
On the weekday of railroad paycheck or on Friday of the advance

A repetition of a few lines above.

intratextuality
knocked back

Alcohol theme.

theme
picked up a piece of iron by the depot, and I’m waitin in the famous alders beyond the tracks

Ilya picks up a piece of iron in order to ambush the men that Orina has been sleeping with.

explanatory
alders

Plant motif.

motif
shorties sixteen boyish years old

According to Ostanin, a reference to Yakov Shvedov’s 1936 song “The Eaglet” (102). Read the lyrics here. Listen to a recording here.

music intertextuality
execution meadow of love

Death and sex are associated.

theme
kurgan

A tumulus or burial mound that covers a grave.

explanatory
started doin what each was good at

Sex theme.

theme
8,420

Ostanin suggests that Ilya’s train ticket number calls to mind both George Orwell’s 1984 (1948) and the number of letters in the Jewish alphabet (103). However, Sokolov says: “This figure does not correlate with anything. It only hints at how dear the memory of Meadow Saturday is to Ilya: he has forever memorized the relatively complex number of that ticket” (personal communication, July 29, 2023). Railroad theme.

intertextuality theme
Meadow Saturday

Emblematic of paradise. There is a Meadow Saturday located off the Irtysh River. A reference to Gennady Karpunin’s 1975 Meadow Saturday, or, The Believable and Unbelieable Adventures of Vasya Morkovkin. This book, a sort of modern fable, is the only one addressed to children written by the Siberian poet and literary critic Gennady Karpunin (1939-1998), famous for his works devoted to The Tale of Igor’s Campaign. The story, full of curious characters such as its hero Vasya, concentrates on the theme of nature, whose beauty must be preserved by humans, and it addresses issues of scientific and technological progress (placed in the Soviet context) and its interaction with nature and human beings. Karpunin’s education as physicist emerges in the scientific humor contained in the book. A character in the novel defines Meadow Saturday as follows: “It’s a major holiday of flowers and grass, a honey-harvest day. Do you hear bumblebees and bees buzzing? That means the clover has bloomed. Honey collected on this day is the best. It will cure any cold. This is the day of flood-meadows, the celebration of pastures. Take a look at the modest shepherd’s purse growing along the roadside, even it blooms on this wonderful day. This is a day of warm earth, fragrant chernozem, a field road, and a ringing lark. That’s what a Meadow Saturday is!” Read the original here.

intertextuality location Russia
cardboard piece

According to Ostanin, Ilya’s reserved-seat ticket (104).

explanatory
Ilya

Ilya here refers to himself in the third person. Ilya is Between Dog and Wolf’s protagonist and the author of what he calls the Zaitil’shchina, a long letter with epic traits (starting from its title) addressed to Inspector Pozhilykh in which he comments on the theft of his crutches (he has only one leg) and, more generally, describes life along the Volga River. Johnson defines Ilya’s letter as “semiliterate ramblings,” aptly suggesting the style and register the reader will encounter in the novel (“Sokolov’s Between Dog and Wolf and the Modernist Tradition” 212). However, this character expresses at the same time a highly poetic and imaginative gaze. Ilya frequently associates himself with the biblical prophet Elijah, a figure folklorically linked with thunderstorms and which in Slavic tradition acquired some of the characteristics of the pagan God of the sky and thunder, Perun. Ilya is closely related to other key characters of the novel: he describes his troubled relationship with Orina (alternatively called Maria and the Dame) with whom he has a son; in encountering Yakov (the focus of several chapters), he suggests the possibility of being his father. The Oedipal plot resulting from this triangle has been noted by scholars, such as Johnson, who writes that “the game warden Iakov lusts for his mother (reincarnate as a mentally defective girl) and kills his father-all without being aware of the identity of either” (“Twilight Cosmos” 644).

intertextuality folklore character
Fomich

Sidor Pozhilykh’s patronymic. A familiar form of address that uses a shortened version of the patronymic.

register/style character
Meadow Saturday.

Emblematic of paradise. There is a Meadow Saturday located off the Irtysh River. A reference to Gennady Karpunin’s 1975 Meadow Saturday, or, The Believable and Unbelieable Adventures of Vasya Morkovkin. This book, a sort of modern fable, is the only one addressed to children written by the Siberian poet and literary critic Gennady Karpunin (1939-1998), famous for his works devoted to The Tale of Igor’s Campaign. The story, full of curious characters such as its hero Vasya, concentrates on the theme of nature, whose beauty must be preserved by humans, and it addresses issues of scientific and technological progress (placed in the Soviet context) and its interaction with nature and human beings. Karpunin’s education as physicist emerges in the scientific humor contained in the book. A character in the novel defines Meadow Saturday as follows: “It’s a major holiday of flowers and grass, a honey-harvest day. Do you hear bumblebees and bees buzzing? That means the clover has bloomed. Honey collected on this day is the best. It will cure any cold. This is the day of flood-meadows, the celebration of pastures. Take a look at the modest shepherd’s purse growing along the roadside, even it blooms on this wonderful day. This is a day of warm earth, fragrant chernozem, a field road, and a ringing lark. That’s what a Meadow Saturday is!” Read the original here.

intertextuality location Russia
Meadow Saturday

Emblematic of paradise. There is a Meadow Saturday located off the Irtysh River. A reference to Gennady Karpunin’s 1975 Meadow Saturday, or, The Believable and Unbelieable Adventures of Vasya Morkovkin. This book, a sort of modern fable, is the only one addressed to children written by the Siberian poet and literary critic Gennady Karpunin (1939-1998), famous for his works devoted to The Tale of Igor’s Campaign. The story, full of curious characters such as its hero Vasya, concentrates on the theme of nature, whose beauty must be preserved by humans, and it addresses issues of scientific and technological progress (placed in the Soviet context) and its interaction with nature and human beings. Karpunin’s education as physicist emerges in the scientific humor contained in the book. A character in the novel defines Meadow Saturday as follows: “It’s a major holiday of flowers and grass, a honey-harvest day. Do you hear bumblebees and bees buzzing? That means the clover has bloomed. Honey collected on this day is the best. It will cure any cold. This is the day of flood-meadows, the celebration of pastures. Take a look at the modest shepherd’s purse growing along the roadside, even it blooms on this wonderful day. This is a day of warm earth, fragrant chernozem, a field road, and a ringing lark. That’s what a Meadow Saturday is!” Read the original here.

intertextuality location Russia
in the future existence

Time flows unnaturally in the novel. One possible implication here is that Ilya has or will experience(d) other existences. Ashcheulova, linking Sokolov’s writing to that of Valentin Kataev (1897–1986), comments on this theme of “transformations and displacements in time and space” that “create an image of life and death that endlessly repeat” (“Tvorchestvo” 137). For more on Sokolov and Kataev, see Borden’s “Time, Backward!: Sasha Sokolov and Valentin Kataev” and “Toward a Postmodern ‘Bad’: Sasha Sokolov.”

time intertextuality
And I tied a knot. On my necktie

The reference to Albatrasov the sailor in the next sentence brings to mind Coleridge’s The Rime of the Ancient Mariner (read it here), in which a sailor is compelled to wear an albatross he has killed around his neck in penance. Addressing the latter subtext’s image of a bird wrapped around a sailor’s neck in penance, José Vergara writes, “Albatrosov is an embodiment of Ilya’s perceived betrayal by Orina, who it is said, sleeps with a number of sailors under the aforementioned overturned boat on the banks of the Volga, as well as guilt over his own actions. Ilya takes on his sorrow when he meets Albatrosov on a train after his separation from Orina. The avian-sailor thus serves to remind Ilya of the past he cannot escape. […] The anthropomorphized bird imagery, in this way, underscores Ilya’s lingering psychological trauma, both that which he himself caused and that which he received” (“Flap” 372). Animal-human motif.

motif intertextuality character
Albatrosov

This name calls to mind two famous poetic “albatrosses”: Baudelaire’s (read it here) and Coleridge’s from The Rime of the Ancient Mariner (read it here). Addressing the latter subtext’s image of a bird wrapped around a sailor’s neck in penance, José Vergara writes, “Albatrosov is an embodiment of Ilya’s perceived betrayal by Orina, who it is said, sleeps with a number of sailors under the aforementioned overturned boat on the banks of the Volga, as well as guilt over his own actions. Ilya takes on his sorrow when he meets Albatrosov on a train after his separation from Orina. The avian-sailor thus serves to remind Ilya of the past he cannot escape. […] The anthropomorphized bird imagery, in this way, underscores Ilya’s lingering psychological trauma, both that which he himself caused and that which he received” (“Flap” 372). Animal-human motif. In a 2004 interview with Mario Caramitti, Sokolov comments on the suggestion of art predicting life in mysterious ways mentioning this specific character: “In the winter of 1978 I was living in Michigan and working on my second novel. One of the characters in the book, named Al’batrosov, has a background as a stoker on a ship. I was outlining the character by modeling him on my half-brother, a sailor, who was aboard a freighter at the time. Without thinking about the possible consequences, I made Albatrosov’s fate take a turn for the worse: an explosion in the engine room takes off his arm. When the book came out, I learned that in the same days that I was writing that episode my brother lost an arm to an accident. This is, I would say, the cruelest and most disconcerting example in my practice as a writer. But on the whole what I write often comes true. More often, unfortunately, than I would like, since I generally write about unpleasant things” (“Sokolov, il fabbro pellegrino della prosa russa” 12). The same concept is described by the author in his 1981 essay On Secret Tablets: “things described in fiction come true; fate suggests to the neglected in spirit solutions that it has already found.
