And it does not make any difference whether the master creates life myths or they create him: the text has been recorded in the same place, on secret tablets. And nothing else but fate will answer all the questions and decide what will remain – silence or the word. And, if necessary, it’ll rip out our sinful tongues” (7).

character intertextuality motif self-reference author
foksel

Forecastle.

register/style
steamboat

Boat motif.

motif
embarcadero

Spanish: embarkment. Boat motif.

foreign motif
jerboas

Animal motif.

motif
Meadow Saturday

Emblematic of paradise. There is a Meadow Saturday located off the Irtysh River. A reference to Gennady Karpunin’s 1975 Meadow Saturday, or, The Believable and Unbelieable Adventures of Vasya Morkovkin. This book, a sort of modern fable, is the only one addressed to children written by the Siberian poet and literary critic Gennady Karpunin (1939-1998), famous for his works devoted to The Tale of Igor’s Campaign. The story, full of curious characters such as its hero Vasya, concentrates on the theme of nature, whose beauty must be preserved by humans, and it addresses issues of scientific and technological progress (placed in the Soviet context) and its interaction with nature and human beings. Karpunin’s education as physicist emerges in the scientific humor contained in the book. A character in the novel defines Meadow Saturday as follows: “It’s a major holiday of flowers and grass, a honey-harvest day. Do you hear bumblebees and bees buzzing? That means the clover has bloomed. Honey collected on this day is the best. It will cure any cold. This is the day of flood-meadows, the celebration of pastures. Take a look at the modest shepherd’s purse growing along the roadside, even it blooms on this wonderful day. This is a day of warm earth, fragrant chernozem, a field road, and a ringing lark. That’s what a Meadow Saturday is!” Read the original here.

intertextuality location Russia
Gorodnishche

The main setting of the novel: a fictional town on the banks of the Volga River. Also called Gorodnishchi. Derived from the words for town (gorod) and beggar (nishchii). It is the “town of beggars.” Olga Matich writes: “If School for Fools was written against the background of youth prose, Sokolov’s next novel Between Dog and Wolf may be read as the author’s response to village prose, the literary rage of the seventies” (“Sasha Sokolov” 310). Vadim Kreid observes that Gorodnishche, a barracks village of beggars and thieves, resembles an “Anti-Kitezh” (Kitezh being the legendary, mythical city in Russian folklore that only the pure-hearted will have the chance to reach). In Gorodnishche, however, thieves rob beggars, while beggars beg thieves (“Zaitil’shchina” 213). According to Johnson, the living dwell Gorodnishche, while the dead reside on the other side of the river, in Bydogoshch (“Sokolov’s Between Dog and Wolf and the Modernist Tradition” 209). Johnson also mentions a statement by Sokolov himself: “Sokolov reports that the name is a blend of the dissolute eighteen-century town of Gorodnya described by A. N. Radishchev in his Journey from Petersburg to Moscow and a nearby town called Gorodishche. Thus the time layers of the sixteenth century, the eighteenth century, and a mythic present are all superimposed upon each other – a characteristic technique in the novel” (217).

location setting intertextuality folklore theme
On the day of railroad paycheck or the day of the advance

These words appear in a slightly different form above. Alexander Boguslawski explains: “This almost obsessive return to the story is not surprising — its continuation describes one of the most important events in the novel: Il’ia is caught and tied to the rails like Orina’s fox before; in an attempt to save him, Orina loses her life, while he loses his leg” (“How Sokolov’s 219).

intratextuality
had a gulp

Alcohol theme.

theme
tipplers

Alcohol theme.

theme
and I stand jealous in the bush with the danglin iron

Ilya returns to his narrative about waiting in the bushes with a piece of iron to ambush Orina’s lovers.

intratextuality
How I jumped out, how I leaped out

A reference to the folk tale “The Fox, the Hare, and the Rooster.” Read the original here and an English translation here. Animal motif.

intertextuality motif
cap-bands

Ilya refers to the sailors/hunters metonymically.

explanatory
hammers in button loops

Sokolov explains: “Orina’s comrades, with whom she has a kind of relationship, are, in Ilya’s words, students of railroad craft schools,” who “wore and still wear a specific uniform. On the cockades of their caps and on the button loops of their coats there is a technical emblem, a sign: a crossed hammer and a French wrench, which, if you do not look closely, may appear to be a second hammer” (personal communication, August 25, 2023). Railroad theme.

explanatory theme
like Sidor’s goat

Set expression: драть как Сидорову козу (to beat like Sidor’s goat, whip someone’s ass, beat mercilessly). Of course, the phrase draws a direct link to Sidor Fomich Pozhilykh. Boguslawski adds: “Some scholars derive the origin of this phraseological expression from the Arabic “sadar kaza (perhaps brought to Russia by the Mongols), a sentence that often involved punishment by beating with clubs” (“Annotations” 253). Animal motif.

translation phraseologism foreign motif
gray slag

This gray slag is also mentioned in Orina’s account of this event (R219/E121–122).

intratextuality
spiders

Animal motif.

motif
Why do it, kiddos, I agonized, am I some kind of a fox cub to you?

Blurred narratives: Here, Ilya is tied to the tracks and will lose his leg. Elsewhere, in chapter 10, it is Orina’s fox who is tied to the rails and killed (R219/E121–122). Animal-human motif.

intratextuality motif
fox

Olga Matich reads Sokolov’s novel as an extended response to Boris Pilnyak’s short story “Mother Earth” (1927), as it shares confusion between a wolf and a fox, a character name Arina, and a setting on the Upper Volga, among other similarities (“Sasha Sokolov” 312–313). Read the original here. D. Barton Johnson adds: “The prose models that served for Shkola dlia durakov were obviously unsuitable for the setting and events of Mezhdu sobakoi i volkom. Apart from the obvious sections of literary parody in which Gogol’ is flagrantly apparent, it is difficult to point to direct stylistic sources. The first that comes to mind is the Andrei Belyi of Serebrianyi golub’ (The Silver Dove) with its (partial) peasant setting and its elaborate sound instrumentation. Sokolov, however, denies having read Belyi at this point. A more likely literary context is afforded by modernist Boris Pilniak […] Pilniak had recently been rehabilitated and his work was easily available. Sokolov recalls reading his work in 1975. Something of the same dark violence and fractured language is also to be found in the work of Pilniak’s adherent Andrei Platonov whose work was being rediscovered and republished in the late 1960s” (“Background Notes” (336–337).

intertextuality motif
valenok

Traditional Russian winter felt boots. D.B. Johnson has identified more than twenty different types of shoes across Sokolov’s three novels: “bashmaki, botforty, boty, botinki (polubotinki), cheboty, chizmy, chubury, galoshi (kaloshi), gety, ichigi, kedy, klogi, lapti, mokrostupy, obuvi (obuvki), sapogi, sandalii, tapochki (polutapochki), shlepantsy, shtiblety, tapti, tufli, valenki. The list may easily be extended with appurtenances such as socks, stockings, footcloths, gaiters, skates, crutches, and artificial legs” (“The Galoshes Manifesto” 156). Regarding Between Dog and Wolf, he notes that Ilya’s last name immediately evokes Cinderella’s vair slippers. Johnson observes that “the footwear motif is Sokolov’s tribute, both conscious and unconscious, to the tradition in Russian literature represented by his predecessors – Ivan Bunin and Valentin Kataev” (179). In an interview with A. and N. Voronel’, Sokolov calls Bunin, along with Gogol, his “contemporaries, collaborators along a chain, older masters” (Voroneli, “Ia khochu” 184). Shoe motif.

intertextuality motif Russia
express

Express train. Railroad theme. Alternatively, this may be interpreted as an ellipsis for “konets”: жду скорого конца (i.e., death).

language theme
I started refreshin my past

Ilya begins to “refresh his past,” meaning his life flashes before his eyes and he considers what he’s done with his life.

explanatory
this time

Again, the implication here is that Ilya has or will experience(d) other lives.

time theme
I reckoned this and that, and the characteristic turned out mostly not bad

Ilya reckons that he’s lived an ordinary life and been a decent man.

explanatory
when the embers of the heavenly matters were already pourin down from above

When it was already dark, under the stars.

time
Orya

Orina, along with her variants, is the primary female character in the novel. In a sense, she is the only female figure in Between Dog and Wolf. As D.B. Johnson summarizes, the “promiscuous heroine Orina-Mariia is a train dispatcher, a princess in her dispatcher’s tower, who entertains her coworkers in her bed. Some of her orgiastic trysts take place near the train tracks to which her lovers tie her meddling husband Il’ia. Orina, in at least one time dimension, is killed by a train as she belatedly tries to save Il’ia who loses his leg” (“Twilight Cosmos” 647). Ilya is obsessed with this woman, and this passion “is the ultimate source of the woes that befall Il’ia, the itinerant grinder. It is his passion for the faithless slut Orina that brings about his misfortunes: the loss of his leg, his wandering life as a drunken grinder, and the grisly events that lead to his death” (643). Orina, alternatively called Maria, exists in the book also in another version, as ta dama, that dame, “a mysterious woman who appears along the river seeking Il’ia and, failing to find him, takes away a new lover each time […]. Her chance lovers return days later, sexually depleted and without interest in life. They usually die by their own hand” (645). In this figure (which embodies “virtually all female figures in the book,” D.B. Johnson, “Sasha Sokolov’s Between Dog and Wolf and the Modernist Tradition” 211), Sokolov merges two of his major literary themes: sex and death. Thus, Orina, Maria, that dame (ta dama, ta devochka, ta bobylka, ta babulya — all linked by the demonstrative “ta”), “Life Everlastin,” and death in general make up a unique polymorphic character. Smith notices that this female figure “does not appear at all in the verse. The episode of the sexual encounter between this figure and the sailors, which reoccurs obsessively in the prose, is correspondingly absent from the verse passages” (333). Olga Matich suggests the existence of a literary subtext for Sokolov’s novel: “Pilniak’s lesser known story Mother Earth (Mat’ syra zemlia 1927) about the violent confrontation between a naive young Bolshevik and an archaic Volga peasant community at the time of the Civil War. It is a kind of love story between the city-bred Bolshevik and the horse-tanner and young earth mother Arina, impaled by the Cossacks in one of the story’s many violence-ridden episodes. A variation on the Scythian juxtaposition of nature and culture, the story also depicts Arina’s maternal love for a fox cub, whom she tries to tame, thinking it is a wolf” (“Sasha Sokolov and His Literary Context” 312). The name Orina may also carry an echo of Pushkin’s famous nurse Arina Rodionovna (Toker 353). Mario Caramitti proposes three recurring hypostases of ta dama across Sokolov’s novels: a first hypostasis is that of a “mysterious woman carrying an obscure menace and/or sexual temptation”; a second hypostasis is that of an “apparently better defined and concrete woman being the object of desire for the main character”; and the third hypostasis is that of a “child-woman, often mentally retarded, often victim of violences, who touches upon a slightly more sublimated erotic sphere” (“Amore e morte” 114). Caramitti also adds that in the novel one of ta dama’s victims, before or after committing suicide, explicitly calls her “вечная жизнь” (Life Everlastin): “it is precisely in the coitus with eternity, in a region of oblivion that it is most difficult to place on this side or on the other side of the Lethe, that the male protagonist finds the widest surface of contact with this protean female entity of now vast symbolic implications” (118). Among Orina’s many lovers and among the men who take advantage of her, there is also Yakov, her son, who is in a way “re-enacting the role of the lame Oedipus” (Johnson, “Sasha Sokolov’s Between Dog and Wolf and the Modernist Tradition” 212). In chapter 14, Orina’s patronymic is said to be “Ignat’evna” (daughter of Ignatii): the name Ignatii possibly comes from the Latin “ignis” (fire) (R258/E190). Given that Orina is depicted here through her lust, such a patronymic seems apt. Her last name is said to be alternatively Neklina and Paklina (Spacklin, in translation): “You were called around the barracks Orina Neklina, and to whom do you belong now, to what kind of, let’s suppose, Spacklin, ah?” (R246/E169). On the border with Ukraine, close to Mariupol’ and to Chekhov’s hometown Taganrog, there is Rostov district named Neklinovsky. Paklia and paklina are regional terms indicating different things: a left-handed person, an unhandy and clumsy person, a bony hand, a piece of hemp or coarse fiber, messy hair. The terms паклен (paklen) and неклен (neklen) are named for the Tatar maple (note the slight differences in the spelling between the tree names and Orina’s surnames: Neklina, Paklina). As Sokolov explains, “Apparently, the author of the Notes and Ilya know or have heard about a man named Paklin. Ilya says that Arina’s last name was Neklina, probably after one of her men. And now, years later, Ilya assumes, she lives with someone else, whose last name suggests to him the tree’s other name” (personal communication, July 7, 2023).

character theme intertextuality intratextuality
She kept callin the obnoxious Ilya a poor fox, started to unwind the wires—and was shakin like a leaf

Blurred narratives: Here, Ilya is tied to the tracks and will lose his leg. Elsewhere, in chapter 10, it is Orina’s fox who is tied to the rails and killed (R219/E121–122). Animal-human motif.

intratextuality motif
Ilya

Ilya here refers to himself in the third person. Ilya is Between Dog and Wolf’s protagonist and the author of what he calls the Zaitil’shchina, a long letter with epic traits (starting from its title) addressed to Inspector Pozhilykh in which he comments on the theft of his crutches (he has only one leg) and, more generally, describes life along the Volga River. Johnson defines Ilya’s letter as “semiliterate ramblings,” aptly suggesting the style and register the reader will encounter in the novel (“Sokolov’s Between Dog and Wolf and the Modernist Tradition” 212). However, this character expresses at the same time a highly poetic and imaginative gaze. Ilya frequently associates himself with the biblical prophet Elijah, a figure folklorically linked with thunderstorms and which in Slavic tradition acquired some of the characteristics of the pagan God of the sky and thunder, Perun. Ilya is closely related to other key characters of the novel: he describes his troubled relationship with Orina (alternatively called Maria and the Dame) with whom he has a son; in encountering Yakov (the focus of several chapters), he suggests the possibility of being his father. The Oedipal plot resulting from this triangle has been noted by scholars, such as Johnson, who writes that “the game warden Iakov lusts for his mother (reincarnate as a mentally defective girl) and kills his father-all without being aware of the identity of either” (“Twilight Cosmos” 644).

character intertextuality folklore
fox

Animal motif.

motif
express

Express train. Railroad theme. Alternatively, this may be interpreted as an ellipsis for “konets”: жду скорого конца (i.e., death).

language theme
Orya

Orina, along with her variants, is the primary female character in the novel. In a sense, she is the only female figure in Between Dog and Wolf. As D.B. Johnson summarizes, the “promiscuous heroine Orina-Mariia is a train dispatcher, a princess in her dispatcher’s tower, who entertains her coworkers in her bed. Some of her orgiastic trysts take place near the train tracks to which her lovers tie her meddling husband Il’ia. Orina, in at least one time dimension, is killed by a train as she belatedly tries to save Il’ia who loses his leg” (“Twilight Cosmos” 647). Ilya is obsessed with this woman, and this passion “is the ultimate source of the woes that befall Il’ia, the itinerant grinder. It is his passion for the faithless slut Orina that brings about his misfortunes: the loss of his leg, his wandering life as a drunken grinder, and the grisly events that lead to his death” (643). Orina, alternatively called Maria, exists in the book also in another version, as ta dama, that dame, “a mysterious woman who appears along the river seeking Il’ia and, failing to find him, takes away a new lover each time […]. Her chance lovers return days later, sexually depleted and without interest in life. They usually die by their own hand” (645). Johnson, “Sasha Sokolov’s Between Dog and Wolf and the Modernist Tradition” 211), Sokolov merges two of his major literary themes: sex and death. Thus, Orina, Maria, that dame (ta dama, ta devochka, ta bobylka, ta babulya — all linked by the demonstrative “ta”), “Life Everlastin,” and death in general make up a unique polymorphic character. The episode of the sexual encounter between this figure and the sailors, which reoccurs obsessively in the prose, is correspondingly absent from the verse passages” (333). It is a kind of love story between the city-bred Bolshevik and the horse-tanner and young earth mother Arina, impaled by the Cossacks in one of the story’s many violence-ridden episodes. A variation on the Scythian juxtaposition of nature and culture, the story also depicts Arina’s maternal love for a fox cub, whom she tries to tame, thinking it is a wolf” (“Sasha Sokolov and His Literary Context” 312). Caramitti also adds that in the novel one of ta dama’s victims, before or after committing suicide, explicitly calls her “вечная жизнь” (Life Everlastin): “it is precisely in the coitus with eternity, in a region of oblivion that it is most difficult to place on this side or on the other side of the Lethe, that the male protagonist finds the widest surface of contact with this protean female entity of now vast symbolic implications” (118). In chapter 14, Orina’s patronymic is said to be “Ignat’evna” (daughter of Ignatii): the name Ignatii possibly comes from the Latin “ignis” (fire) (R258/E190). Given that Orina is depicted here through her lust, such a patronymic seems apt. Her last name is said to be alternatively Neklina and Paklina (Spacklin, in translation): “You were called around the barracks Orina Neklina, and to whom do you belong now, to what kind of, let’s suppose, Spacklin, ah?” (R246/E169). On the border with Ukraine, close to Mariupol’ and to Chekhov’s hometown Taganrog, there is Rostov district named Neklinovsky. Paklia and paklina are regional terms indicating different things: a left-handed person, an unhandy and clumsy person, a bony hand, a piece of hemp or coarse fiber, messy hair. The terms паклен (paklen) and неклен (neklen) are named for the Tatar maple (note the slight differences in the spelling between the tree names and Orina’s surnames: Neklina, Paklina). As Sokolov explains, “Apparently, the author of the Notes and Ilya know or have heard about a man named Paklin. Ilya says that Arina’s last name was Neklina, probably after one of her men. And now, years later, Ilya assumes, she lives with someone else, whose last name suggests to him the tree’s other name” (personal communication, July 7, 2023).

theme character intertextuality intratextuality
cap-bands

Ilya refers to the sailors/hunters metonymically.

explanatory
I felt with you like earth with grass

Sokolov points out that “that is my phrase, stylized as a saying” (personal communication, July 29, 2023).

language
sharp teeth, long tail

Barbara Heldt observes of this scene in chapters 10 and 14: “The words about teeth and tail are repeated with the different that predlinnyi becoms dolgii, like the long memory of the event” (281). Orina likens her alleged bad behavior and excesses to animal qualities: sharp teeth and a long tail. On memory, D. Barton Johnson writes, “Since all times seem to exist more or less concurrently and variant versions of events exist both in fact and in potentia, memory in Sokolov’s works merges with imagination. The first person narrators not so much retell the past but imagine at different times variant pasts and futures. For Sokolov’s characters, memory is imagination, and imagination, the only reality” (“Sasha Sokolov’s Twilight Cosmos” 643). Animal-human motif.

motif explanatory theme intratextuality
fox

Animal motif.

motif
The magpie is sick, she claims, the crow is sick too, she says, and Ilya is healthy and glad, she casts the spell

A reference to the expression “У сороки боли, у вороны боли, а у (имя) всё заживи” (“The magpie is hurt, the crow is hurt, but (name) will feel all better”), used to comfort children who have hurt themselves. See also Korovashko. This reference also appears in Note XI (R196-197/E84–86), which begs the question: which came first — Yakov’s poem or Ilya’s letter? According to Edward Armstrong’s The Folklore of Birds, “magpie lore seems to be dependent upon, or derive from, raven traditions to a considerable extent and the folklore of the crow is confused with that of the raven” (72). Crows, like ravens, are often associated with death (Armstrong 75). José Vergara writes, “As for the crow, so consistently paired with the magpie, there is the story of Coronis, whose adultery is revealed by a tattling crow. After Apollo condemns her to death, he feels remorse and turns the crow’s white feathers black as punishment. Here, again, we note the theme of transformations and the unfaithful woman, who, in the form of Orina, would make the crow Ilya” (“Flap 369). Animal motif.

motif intratextuality phraseologism structure
magpie

The magpie is traditionally known as a thieving bird: “Regarded almost universally as a symbol of ill-omen,” the “magpie’s incorrigible addiction to pilfering has no doubt contributed to its unpopularity” (Rowland, Birds 103–104). Animal motif.

motif folklore
crow

Crows, like ravens, are often associated with death. Animal motif.

motif
Ilya

Ilya here refers to himself in the third person. Ilya is Between Dog and Wolf’s protagonist and the author of what he calls the Zaitil’shchina, a long letter with epic traits (starting from its title) addressed to Inspector Pozhilykh in which he comments on the theft of his crutches (he has only one leg) and, more generally, describes life along the Volga River. Johnson defines Ilya’s letter as “semiliterate ramblings,” aptly suggesting the style and register the reader will encounter in the novel (“Sokolov’s Between Dog and Wolf and the Modernist Tradition” 212). However, this character expresses at the same time a highly poetic and imaginative gaze. Ilya frequently associates himself with the biblical prophet Elijah, a figure folklorically linked with thunderstorms and which in Slavic tradition acquired some of the characteristics of the pagan God of the sky and thunder, Perun. Ilya is closely related to other key characters of the novel: he describes his troubled relationship with Orina (alternatively called Maria and the Dame) with whom he has a son; in encountering Yakov (the focus of several chapters), he suggests the possibility of being his father. The Oedipal plot resulting from this triangle has been noted by scholars, such as Johnson, who writes that “the game warden Iakov lusts for his mother (reincarnate as a mentally defective girl) and kills his father-all without being aware of the identity of either” (“Twilight Cosmos” 644).

intertextuality character folklore
It swooped, mangled, hot, and my hands-legs scattered all over

The train runs over Ilya and cuts off his leg. Railroad theme.

theme explanatory
The battalion of about-goners grew larger

According to Boguslawski, a paraphrase of a line from the folk song “A my proso seiali” (We were sowing millet) (“Annotations” 254). Read it here. Listen it here.

intertextuality music
The battalion of about-goners grew larger; commander, receive the reinforcements

That is, there’s another person close to death who needs medical attention. Prepare the hospital.

explanatory
A hulk of a doc in a cap floats in

A narrative inversion: Ilya is now back at the hospital.

explanatory
friend

That is, Orina.

explanatory character
She’s done for

The doctor claims that Orina has died.

explanatory
To the bonesetter: Go, heal Thyself

A reference to Luke 4:23 (Boguslawski, “Annotations” 4:23).

bible intertextuality religion
slippers

D.B. Johnson has identified more than twenty different types of shoes across Sokolov’s three novels: “bashmaki, botforty, boty, botinki (polubotinki), cheboty, chizmy, chubury, galoshi (kaloshi), gety, ichigi, kedy, klogi, lapti, mokrostupy, obuvi (obuvki), sapogi, sandalii, tapochki (polutapochki), shlepantsy, shtiblety, tapti, tufli, valenki. The list may easily be extended with appurtenances such as socks, stockings, footcloths, gaiters, skates, crutches, and artificial legs” (“The Galoshes Manifesto” 156). Regarding Between Dog and Wolf, he notes that Ilya’s last name immediately evokes Cinderella’s vair slippers. Johnson observes that “the footwear motif is Sokolov’s tribute, both conscious and unconscious, to the tradition in Russian literature represented by his predecessors – Ivan Bunin and Valentin Kataev” (179). In an interview with A. and N. Voronel’, Sokolov calls Bunin, along with Gogol, his “contemporaries, collaborators along a chain, older masters” (Voroneli, “Ia khochu” 184). Shoe motif.

intertextuality motif
Gury

Gury is one of the hunters living by the river. His death is described in detail in chapter 14: during an ice race, “a few verstas before the turn, Gury began gainin and the whipper-in fallin behind, but Gury aimed slightly more to the right than he should and fell into a polynya, an ice hole in the area of the fairway. […] he plopped in and right away got sucked under the ice.” Since his body cannot be found until spring, his funeral is organized “without his factual presence” (R260/E196). This episode is already briefly alluded to in chapter 1: “He was the one that adored scrapin and rollin over the slick on his sharps, which additionally resulted in us losin a client, and the undertakers, in contrast, findin one” (R150/E3).

character intratextuality
put wine in the kitty

The hunters start arguing and set up a bet with alcohol as the prize. Alcohol theme.

theme explanatory
possessin the mental hypervision

Ilya claims he can see this race in his mind clear as day.

explanatory
one in clothes patched, the other in mismatched

Their clothes are patched and mismatched, in general disarray. Clothing motif.

motif explanatory
Sloboda

In ancient Russia, a sloboda referred to a settlement found in Povolzhye, Central Russia, Belarus, or Ukraine. The term is derived from the word for freedom. These tax-free settlements came to an end in the early eighteenth century when the practice was abolished and the settlements became regular villages. Often these suburbs were eventually subsumed by nearby cities. Today, sloboda refers to a rural locality in various oblasts. Sokolov attests that a Sloboda can be found by the Volga River in Konakovskii raion (personal communication, June 7, 2023).

Russia location
Tavern Island

In the original, Kabatskaya zarya. An island named Kabatsky exists by Dudinka on the Enisey river, while Zarya is a peninsula in Arctic Siberia. It could be a generic reference to Siberia. The former is mentioned in chapter 10 (R223/E128).

intratextuality location Russia
And they rushed along, cuttin the ice with their skates

A reference to chapter 4 line 42 of Alexander Pushkin’s novel-in-verse Eugene Onegin (Ostanin 107). Read the original here and an English translation here.

intertextuality
they’ll have a chance to taste one of the participants

Indeed, in the next line, Gury will fall into an ice hole and become food for the fish.

explanatory
come and pray, large and small fishie

A variation on a line from the folktale “Sister Fox and Gray Wolf”: “Ловись, рыбка, большая и маленькая!” (Catch, little fish, big and small!” Read the original here and an English translation here. Animal motif.

intertextuality motif
verstas

An obsolete Russian unit of length equal to approximately .66 miles or 1.07 km.

explanatory Russia
Gury

Gury is one of the hunters living by the river. His death is described in detail in chapter 14: during an ice race, “a few verstas before the turn, Gury began gainin and the whipper-in fallin behind, but Gury aimed slightly more to the right than he should and fell into a polynya, an ice hole in the area of the fairway. […] he plopped in and right away got sucked under the ice.” Since his body cannot be found until spring, his funeral is organized “without his factual presence” (R260/E196). This episode is already briefly alluded to in chapter 1: “He was the one that adored scrapin and rollin over the slick on his sharps, which additionally resulted in us losin a client, and the undertakers, in contrast, findin one” (R150/E3).

character intratextuality
Gury

Gury is one of the hunters living by the river. His death is described in detail in chapter 14: during an ice race, “a few verstas before the turn, Gury began gainin and the whipper-in fallin behind, but Gury aimed slightly more to the right than he should and fell into a polynya, an ice hole in the area of the fairway. […] he plopped in and right away got sucked under the ice.” Since his body cannot be found until spring, his funeral is organized “without his factual presence” (R260/E196). This episode is already briefly alluded to in chapter 1: “He was the one that adored scrapin and rollin over the slick on his sharps, which additionally resulted in us losin a client, and the undertakers, in contrast, findin one” (R150/E3).

character intratextuality
Gury aimed slightly more to the right than he should and fell into a polynya, an ice hole in the area of the fairway

In Note XXXI, Yakov reports that Gury dies from grief (R269/E209).

intratextuality
Gury

Gury is one of the hunters living by the river. His death is described in detail in chapter 14: during an ice race, “a few verstas before the turn, Gury began gainin and the whipper-in fallin behind, but Gury aimed slightly more to the right than he should and fell into a polynya, an ice hole in the area of the fairway. […] he plopped in and right away got sucked under the ice.” Since his body cannot be found until spring, his funeral is organized “without his factual presence” (R260/E196). This episode is already briefly alluded to in chapter 1: “He was the one that adored scrapin and rollin over the slick on his sharps, which additionally resulted in us losin a client, and the undertakers, in contrast, findin one” (R150/E3).

character intratextuality
without his factual presence

That is, with his body missing.

explanatory
until the kiddos pull him out with a dragnet

Ostanin notes a connection to Alexander Pushkin’s 1828 poem “The Drowned Man” (107). Read the original here and an English translation here.

intertextuality
thoroughly beautiful madame

Orina, the Dame. A reference to Alexander Blok’s 1901–1902 Verses on a Beautiful Lady. Read the original collection of poems here.

intertextuality character
Vasily Karaban

Vasily Karaban appears as the messenger who brings news of the phenomenon of Orina in the form of Everlastin’ Life or that Dame to the Volga community in which the novel is set. He is her first victim and, while he remains alive, he has shriveled up. His occupation, as Sokolov confirms, is unclear (personal communication, July 7, 2023). The name Karaban is of Turkic origin and can either be a surname or a nickname, a shortened version of Karabanov. It means “black mole” from “kara” (black) and “ban” (mole, birthmark). According to Turkic folklore, a black mole is a sign of happiness. Therefore, in the context of Between Dog and Wolf, it may be an ironic marker given Karaban’s fate (“Proiskhozhdenie familii Karabanova”).

character folklore foreign
Everlastin Existens

Orina, the Dame.

explanatory character register/style
pas

French: not.

foreign
You

The inspector, Sidor Fomich Pozhilykh, to whom Ilya is addressing his letter of complaint.

character explanatory
You

The inspector, Sidor Fomich Pozhilykh, to whom Ilya is addressing his letter of complaint.

character explanatory
Ilya

Ilya here refers to himself in the third person. Ilya is Between Dog and Wolf’s protagonist and the author of what he calls the Zaitil’shchina, a long letter with epic traits (starting from its title) addressed to Inspector Pozhilykh in which he comments on the theft of his crutches (he has only one leg) and, more generally, describes life along the Volga River. Johnson defines Ilya’s letter as “semiliterate ramblings,” aptly suggesting the style and register the reader will encounter in the novel (“Sokolov’s Between Dog and Wolf and the Modernist Tradition” 212). However, this character expresses at the same time a highly poetic and imaginative gaze. Ilya frequently associates himself with the biblical prophet Elijah, a figure folklorically linked with thunderstorms and which in Slavic tradition acquired some of the characteristics of the pagan God of the sky and thunder, Perun. Ilya is closely related to other key characters of the novel: he describes his troubled relationship with Orina (alternatively called Maria and the Dame) with whom he has a son; in encountering Yakov (the focus of several chapters), he suggests the possibility of being his father. The Oedipal plot resulting from this triangle has been noted by scholars, such as Johnson, who writes that “the game warden Iakov lusts for his mother (reincarnate as a mentally defective girl) and kills his father-all without being aware of the identity of either” (“Twilight Cosmos” 644).

character intertextuality folklore
ain’t there among you the one, you know, who

The Dame (Orina) is searching for Ilya.

explanatory
all of us wouldn’t mind bein with you

A reference to Nikolai Nekrasov’s 1848 poem “Troika” (Boguslawski, “Annotations” 254). Read the original here and an English translation here.

intertextuality
Gury

Gury is one of the hunters living by the river. His death is described in detail in chapter 14: during an ice race, “a few verstas before the turn, Gury began gainin and the whipper-in fallin behind, but Gury aimed slightly more to the right than he should and fell into a polynya, an ice hole in the area of the fairway. […] he plopped in and right away got sucked under the ice.” Since his body cannot be found until spring, his funeral is organized “without his factual presence” (R260/E196). This episode is already briefly alluded to in chapter 1: “He was the one that adored scrapin and rollin over the slick on his sharps, which additionally resulted in us losin a client, and the undertakers, in contrast, findin one” (R150/E3).

character intratextuality
like them

It means that he is dead.

explanatory
Chud

A historical term used to describe Estonians and Finnish peoples.

explanatory
Orya

Orina, along with her variants, is the primary female character in the novel. In a sense, she is the only female figure in Between Dog and Wolf. As D.B. Johnson summarizes, the “promiscuous heroine Orina-Mariia is a train dispatcher, a princess in her dispatcher’s tower, who entertains her coworkers in her bed. Some of her orgiastic trysts take place near the train tracks to which her lovers tie her meddling husband Il’ia. Orina, in at least one time dimension, is killed by a train as she belatedly tries to save Il’ia who loses his leg” (“Twilight Cosmos” 647). Ilya is obsessed with this woman, and this passion “is the ultimate source of the woes that befall Il’ia, the itinerant grinder. It is his passion for the faithless slut Orina that brings about his misfortunes: the loss of his leg, his wandering life as a drunken grinder, and the grisly events that lead to his death” (643). Orina, alternatively called Maria, exists in the book also in another version, as ta dama, that dame, “a mysterious woman who appears along the river seeking Il’ia and, failing to find him, takes away a new lover each time […]. Her chance lovers return days later, sexually depleted and without interest in life. They usually die by their own hand” (645). In this figure (which embodies “virtually all female figures in the book,” D.B. Johnson, “Sasha Sokolov’s Between Dog and Wolf and the Modernist Tradition” 211), Sokolov merges two of his major literary themes: sex and death. Thus, Orina, Maria, that dame (ta dama, ta devochka, ta bobylka, ta babulya — all linked by the demonstrative “ta”), “Life Everlastin,” and death in general make up a unique polymorphic character. Smith notices that this female figure “does not appear at all in the verse. The episode of the sexual encounter between this figure and the sailors, which reoccurs obsessively in the prose, is correspondingly absent from the verse passages” (333). Olga Matich suggests the existence of a literary subtext for Sokolov’s novel: “Pilniak’s lesser known story Mother Earth (Mat’ syra zemlia 1927) about the violent confrontation between a naive young Bolshevik and an archaic Volga peasant community at the time of the Civil War. It is a kind of love story between the city-bred Bolshevik and the horse-tanner and young earth mother Arina, impaled by the Cossacks in one of the story’s many violence-ridden episodes. A variation on the Scythian juxtaposition of nature and culture, the story also depicts Arina’s maternal love for a fox cub, whom she tries to tame, thinking it is a wolf” (“Sasha Sokolov and His Literary Context” 312). The name Orina may also carry an echo of Pushkin’s famous nurse Arina Rodionovna (Toker 353). Mario Caramitti proposes three recurring hypostases of ta dama across Sokolov’s novels: a first hypostasis is that of a “mysterious woman carrying an obscure menace and/or sexual temptation”; a second hypostasis is that of an “apparently better defined and concrete woman being the object of desire for the main character”; and the third hypostasis is that of a “child-woman, often mentally retarded, often victim of violences, who touches upon a slightly more sublimated erotic sphere” (“Amore e morte” 114). Caramitti also adds that in the novel one of ta dama’s victims, before or after committing suicide, explicitly calls her “вечная жизнь” (Life Everlastin): “it is precisely in the coitus with eternity, in a region of oblivion that it is most difficult to place on this side or on the other side of the Lethe, that the male protagonist finds the widest surface of contact with this protean female entity of now vast symbolic implications” (118). Among Orina’s many lovers and among the men who take advantage of her, there is also Yakov, her son, who is in a way “re-enacting the role of the lame Oedipus” (Johnson, “Sasha Sokolov’s Between Dog and Wolf and the Modernist Tradition” 212). In chapter 14, Orina’s patronymic is said to be “Ignat’evna” (daughter of Ignatii): the name Ignatii possibly comes from the Latin “ignis” (fire) (R258/E190). Given that Orina is depicted here through her lust, such a patronymic seems apt. Her last name is said to be alternatively Neklina and Paklina (Spacklin, in translation): “You were called around the barracks Orina Neklina, and to whom do you belong now, to what kind of, let’s suppose, Spacklin, ah?” (R246/E169). On the border with Ukraine, close to Mariupol’ and to Chekhov’s hometown Taganrog, there is Rostov district named Neklinovsky. Paklia and paklina are regional terms indicating different things: a left-handed person, an unhandy and clumsy person, a bony hand, a piece of hemp or coarse fiber, messy hair. The terms паклен (paklen) and неклен (neklen) are named for the Tatar maple (note the slight differences in the spelling between the tree names and Orina’s surnames: Neklina, Paklina). As Sokolov explains, “Apparently, the author of the Notes and Ilya know or have heard about a man named Paklin. Ilya says that Arina’s last name was Neklina, probably after one of her men. And now, years later, Ilya assumes, she lives with someone else, whose last name suggests to him the tree’s other name” (personal communication, July 7, 2023).

theme character intertextuality intratextuality
Fomich

Sidor Pozhilykh’s patronymic. A familiar form of address that uses a shortened version of the patronymic.

register/style character
hobble

Ilya is missing a leg.

explanatory
Krylobyl

Krylobyl is a key character dwelling in the world of the dead (living on the other shore of the Itil’ river). It is not surprising given his “speaking name” formed by the words “krylo” (wing) and “byl” (was, used to be). He is a hypostasis of an angelic creature guiding Ilya in his wanderings and suggesting to him ideas and reflections: in chapter 4 it will be Krylobyl who advances the idea of the origin of the “zhe” letter; it is Krylobyl in this chapter who Ilya describes as a “know-it-all” who “instructs,” the one “whom I trust, whom I praise.” In a sense, Krylobyl is Ilya’s Virgil or, even, Beatrice in his wandering across this very special Inferno, Purgatorio, and Paradiso. Toward the end of the novel, he will be addressed by the narrator in chapter 16 (R275/E220) and by Ilya in chapter 17 as “Fedot Fyodorov” (R279/E227).

character intertextuality intratextuality
Krylobyl

Krylobyl is a key character dwelling in the world of the dead (living on the other shore of the Itil’ river). It is not surprising given his “speaking name” formed by the words “krylo” (wing) and “byl” (was, used to be). He is a hypostasis of an angelic creature guiding Ilya in his wanderings and suggesting to him ideas and reflections: in chapter 4 it will be Krylobyl who advances the idea of the origin of the “zhe” letter; it is Krylobyl in this chapter who Ilya describes as a “know-it-all” who “instructs,” the one “whom I trust, whom I praise.” In a sense, Krylobyl is Ilya’s Virgil or, even, Beatrice in his wandering across this very special Inferno, Purgatorio, and Paradiso. Toward the end of the novel, he will be addressed by the narrator in chapter 16 (R275/E220) and by Ilya in chapter 17 as “Fedot Fyodorov” (R279/E227).

character intertextuality intratextuality
light of your own eyes

A variation on Psalm 13:3 — a call for understanding.

intertextuality bible religion
return to the cripple what’s the cripple’s

Krylobyl commands the hunters to return Ilya’s crutches to him. A reference to Matthew 22:21 (Ostanin 107).

explanatory religion bible intertextuality
cripple

The word used in the original, kalika, indicates blind wanderers who sing spiritual poems. Originally, the word did not refer to disabled or crippled beggars, as it does now, but rather to wanderers who visited holy places and sang songs. The term is derived from the Latin caligae, Since these wanderers often lived off of alms in the towns they visited (and occasionally settled in), the term took on the meaning of a disabled person who does the same in its modern usage. (Miller 27–28). Also mentioned in chapter 8 (R209/E103), chapter 9 (R214/E112), and chapter 10 (R223/E129). D.B. Johnson has identified more than twenty different types of shoes across Sokolov’s three novels: “bashmaki, botforty, boty, botinki (polubotinki), cheboty, chizmy, chubury, galoshi (kaloshi), gety, ichigi, kedy, klogi, lapti, mokrostupy, obuvi (obuvki), sapogi, sandalii, tapochki (polutapochki), shlepantsy, shtiblety, tapti, tufli, valenki. The list may easily be extended with appurtenances such as socks, stockings, footcloths, gaiters, skates, crutches, and artificial legs” (“The Galoshes Manifesto” 156). Regarding Between Dog and Wolf, he notes that Ilya’s last name immediately evokes Cinderella’s vair slippers. Johnson observes that “the footwear motif is Sokolov’s tribute, both conscious and unconscious, to the tradition in Russian literature represented by his predecessors – Ivan Bunin and Valentin Kataev” (179). In an interview with A. and N. Voronel’, Sokolov calls Bunin, along with Gogol, his “contemporaries, collaborators along a chain, older masters” (Voroneli, “Ia khochu” 184). Shoe motif.

intertextuality intratextuality foreign motif Russia
the sought for completely vanished

The crutches can’t be found.

explanatory
thrown behind a bush of brittle willow

Ostanin notes this is a reference to the Russian epic tale “Volga and Mikula Selyaninovich,” in which the hero discards his plow behind a willow (107). Read the original here.

intertextuality
Ilya

Ilya here refers to himself in the third person. Ilya is Between Dog and Wolf’s protagonist and the author of what he calls the Zaitil’shchina, a long letter with epic traits (starting from its title) addressed to Inspector Pozhilykh in which he comments on the theft of his crutches (he has only one leg) and, more generally, describes life along the Volga River. Johnson defines Ilya’s letter as “semiliterate ramblings,” aptly suggesting the style and register the reader will encounter in the novel (“Sokolov’s Between Dog and Wolf and the Modernist Tradition” 212). However, this character expresses at the same time a highly poetic and imaginative gaze. Ilya frequently associates himself with the biblical prophet Elijah, a figure folklorically linked with thunderstorms and which in Slavic tradition acquired some of the characteristics of the pagan God of the sky and thunder, Perun. Ilya is closely related to other key characters of the novel: he describes his troubled relationship with Orina (alternatively called Maria and the Dame) with whom he has a son; in encountering Yakov (the focus of several chapters), he suggests the possibility of being his father. The Oedipal plot resulting from this triangle has been noted by scholars, such as Johnson, who writes that “the game warden Iakov lusts for his mother (reincarnate as a mentally defective girl) and kills his father-all without being aware of the identity of either” (“Twilight Cosmos” 644).

character intertextuality folklore
Ilya

Ilya here refers to himself in the third person. Ilya is Between Dog and Wolf’s protagonist and the author of what he calls the Zaitil’shchina, a long letter with epic traits (starting from its title) addressed to Inspector Pozhilykh in which he comments on the theft of his crutches (he has only one leg) and, more generally, describes life along the Volga River. intertextuality character folklore
Sloboda

In ancient Russia, a sloboda referred to a settlement found in Povolzhye, Central Russia, Belarus, or Ukraine. The term is derived from the word for freedom. These tax-free settlements came to an end in the early eighteenth century when the practice was abolished and the settlements became regular villages. Often these suburbs were eventually subsumed by nearby cities. Today, sloboda refers to a rural locality in various oblasts. Sokolov attests that a Sloboda can be found by the Volga River in Konakovskii raion (personal communication, June 7, 2023).

Russia location
Overbrowears

A reference to the Russian expression “Выше лба уши не растут” meaning that one has limits to what they can do. First mentioned in chapter 8 (R207/E101).

phraseologism translation intratextuality
Gorodnishche

The main setting of the novel: a fictional town on the banks of the Volga River. Also called Gorodnishchi. Derived from the words for town (gorod) and beggar (nishchii). It is the “town of beggars.” Olga Matich writes: “If School for Fools was written against the background of youth prose, Sokolov’s next novel Between Dog and Wolf may be read as the author’s response to village prose, the literary rage of the seventies” (“Sasha Sokolov” 310). Vadim Kreid observes that Gorodnishche, a barracks village of beggars and thieves, resembles an “Anti-Kitezh” (Kitezh being the legendary, mythical city in Russian folklore that only the pure-hearted will have the chance to reach). In Gorodnishche, however, thieves rob beggars, while beggars beg thieves (“Zaitil’shchina” 213). According to Johnson, the living dwell Gorodnishche, while the dead reside on the other side of the river, in Bydogoshch (“Sokolov’s Between Dog and Wolf and the Modernist Tradition” 209). Johnson also mentions a statement by Sokolov himself: “Sokolov reports that the name is a blend of the dissolute eighteen-century town of Gorodnya described by A. N. Radishchev in his Journey from Petersburg to Moscow and a nearby town called Gorodishche. Thus the time layers of the sixteenth century, the eighteenth century, and a mythic present are all superimposed upon each other – a characteristic technique in the novel” (217).

location setting intertextuality folklore theme
like a dog on vomit

An allusion to 2 Peter 2:22 or Proverbs 26:11. The meaning is that the unfaithful will return to their sinful life. Animal motif.

motif intertextuality religion bible
Just look, as long as we’re talkin about it, how many of them hold a watch in a circle around our establishment

Elena Kravchenko writes: “[W. H.] Auden’s ekphrasis, especially his references to The Census and The Slaughter, is scattered throughout Sokolov’s text. Shimmering through its portrayal of the desolate state of humanity, its images of frozen river and skating, the ekphrasis re-emerges in Il’ia’s ‘allegory’ of existence: in what appears to be an elaboration of Auden’s dogs that ‘go on with their doggy life’” (The Prose 63).

intertextuality
who celebrate their promotions

Alcohol theme.

theme
these doggish mutts begin to swallow their frozen turds and show their tongues

That is, the hunters begin behaving like dogs. Animal-human motif.

motif explanatory
macaroni à la fleet

“Macaroni Navy-style” — a dish made of pasta (usually macaroni), stewed ground meet, onions, salt, and pepper. Served in the navy but also became very popular after WWII during times of poverty.

explanatory
get drunk

Alcohol theme

theme
sickler

A tavern or bar where customers drink to excess, resulting in sickness. Gerald Smith appropriately calls Between Dog and Wolf “one of the most sustained and elaborated drinking songs in the whole of Russian literature” (“The Verse” 330). Alcohol theme.

theme setting location
knockin down a shot

Alcohol theme.

theme
Ilya

Ilya here refers to himself in the third person. Ilya is Between Dog and Wolf’s protagonist and the author of what he calls the Zaitil’shchina, a long letter with epic traits (starting from its title) addressed to Inspector Pozhilykh in which he comments on the theft of his crutches (he has only one leg) and, more generally, describes life along the Volga River. Johnson defines Ilya’s letter as “semiliterate ramblings,” aptly suggesting the style and register the reader will encounter in the novel (“Sokolov’s Between Dog and Wolf and the Modernist Tradition” 212). However, this character expresses at the same time a highly poetic and imaginative gaze. Ilya frequently associates himself with the biblical prophet Elijah, a figure folklorically linked with thunderstorms and which in Slavic tradition acquired some of the characteristics of the pagan God of the sky and thunder, Perun. Ilya is closely related to other key characters of the novel: he describes his troubled relationship with Orina (alternatively called Maria and the Dame) with whom he has a son; in encountering Yakov (the focus of several chapters), he suggests the possibility of being his father. The Oedipal plot resulting from this triangle has been noted by scholars, such as Johnson, who writes that “the game warden Iakov lusts for his mother (reincarnate as a mentally defective girl) and kills his father-all without being aware of the identity of either” (“Twilight Cosmos” 644).

intertextuality character folklore
pines

Plant motif.

motif
forhead

Forehead.

register/style
woodpecker

The woodpecker has traditionally played roles “as the god-sent bird in the ancient sacred grove; as the bird who […] cared for Romulus and Remus, and as the oracular bird of Mars, god of war” (Rowland, Birds 180). It is also said that the woodpecker can knock out anything blocking its nest in a tree. While there doesn’t seem to be any such obstruction here, Ilya implies that the bird has knocked down the snow that falls on his head. Animal motif.

motif explanatory symbol
hoopoe

The hoopoe appears several times throughout the novel, mostly in Yakov’s poems (R167, 168, 169, 233, 236, 262, 280/E31, 32, 33, 34, 35, 145, 149, 199). José Vergara writes: “the hoopoe plays a key role in the story of Tereus in Ovid’s Metamorphoses. In this myth, the Thracian king rapes Philomela, his wife Procne’s sister, and cuts out her tongue to keep the secret. After Philomela manages to convey to Procne what happened, the sisters conspire to kill the latter’s son, Itys, and feed him to Tereus. Upon learning of their actions, Tereus in turn seeks them out, but before he can enact his revenge, the gods transform them all into birds: Procne into a swallow, Philomela into a nightingale, Tereus into a hoopoe. According to the folklore, the hoopoe’s hooting call is said to mean “where, where” in Greek – Tereus’s plea as he searches for his displaced family” (“Flap” 364–365). Throughout the novel, Ilya is associated with the hoopoe in that he also looks for his missing family. Therefore, Ilya reenacts this plot as he seeks out Orina and their son, Yakov. “He is displaced, like Tereus, in his various transformations and peregrinations, pursuing his idealized family,” Vergara continues, “but constantly mired by the imagery he uses and that is used to describe him” (“Flap” 366). Animal-human motif.

motif intertextuality intratextuality foreign
Ilya

Ilya here refers to himself in the third person. Ilya is Between Dog and Wolf’s protagonist and the author of what he calls the Zaitil’shchina, a long letter with epic traits (starting from its title) addressed to Inspector Pozhilykh in which he comments on the theft of his crutches (he has only one leg) and, more generally, describes life along the Volga River. Johnson defines Ilya’s letter as “semiliterate ramblings,” aptly suggesting the style and register the reader will encounter in the novel (“Sokolov’s Between Dog and Wolf and the Modernist Tradition” 212). However, this character expresses at the same time a highly poetic and imaginative gaze. Ilya frequently associates himself with the biblical prophet Elijah, a figure folklorically linked with thunderstorms and which in Slavic tradition acquired some of the characteristics of the pagan God of the sky and thunder, Perun. Ilya is closely related to other key characters of the novel: he describes his troubled relationship with Orina (alternatively called Maria and the Dame) with whom he has a son; in encountering Yakov (the focus of several chapters), he suggests the possibility of being his father. The Oedipal plot resulting from this triangle has been noted by scholars, such as Johnson, who writes that “the game warden Iakov lusts for his mother (reincarnate as a mentally defective girl) and kills his father-all without being aware of the identity of either” (“Twilight Cosmos” 644).

intertextuality character folklore
Saturdays

Ilya’s fascination with Meadow Saturday (above). Emblematic of paradise.

location explanatory
Fomich

Sidor Pozhilykh’s patronymic. A familiar form of address that uses a shortened version of the patronymic.

register/style character
we cannot wait to taste the nonexistence

Ilya longes for death.

explanatory
We’ll get milled over

From the expression “Всё перемелется — мука будет” (Everything will get milled over; there will be flour). An expression of the milling theme in the novel. Sokolov will play with this expression and the difference between му́ка (torment) and мукá (flour) several times.

theme phraseologism intratextuality language
Itil

The Tatar name of the river Volga. The title of Ilya’s letter “Zaitil’shchina” is derived from this version of the river’s name. Ostanin also suggests a sound link between the rivers Itil’ and Lethe (Leta), the river of oblivion and forgetting, which also plays a major role in Sokolov’s first novel, A School for Fools (10).

location setting foreign language
Dzhinzherela

Another variation on Ilya’s unusual last name, which is printed in more than ten different versions in the book. It carries allusions to Cinderella (see L. Toker’s essay, “Gamesman’s Sketches (Found in a Bottle),” CASS 21.3-4: 356).

intertextuality character
vino

Italian: wine. Alcohol theme.

foreign theme
lonesome babes

She will make several appearances throughout the novel and is associated with Orina.

intratextuality character
seasonal work

Perhaps a reference to Mikhail Zoshchenko’s 1924 story “Seasonal Work.” Read the original here.

intertextuality
Krylobyl

Krylobyl is a key character dwelling in the world of the dead (living on the other shore of the Itil’ river). It is not surprising given his “speaking name” formed by the words “krylo” (wing) and “byl” (was, used to be). He is a hypostasis of an angelic creature guiding Ilya in his wanderings and suggesting to him ideas and reflections: in chapter 4 it will be Krylobyl who advances the idea of the origin of the “zhe” letter; it is Krylobyl in this chapter who Ilya describes as a “know-it-all” who “instructs,” the one “whom I trust, whom I praise.” In a sense, Krylobyl is Ilya’s Virgil or, even, Beatrice in his wandering across this very special Inferno, Purgatorio, and Paradiso. Toward the end of the novel, he will be addressed by the narrator in chapter 16 (R275/E220) and by Ilya in chapter 17 as “Fedot Fyodorov” (R279/E227).

character intertextuality intratextuality
everyone comes drunk and leaves drunk

A play on Ecclesiastes 1-4 (Ostanin 108). Alcohol theme.

intertextuality bible religion theme
crashbaret

A drinking establishment. Original Russia: кубаре (kubare). A mixture of kubarem (to fall head over heels) and the French “cabaret.” Customers, of course, will fall over and crash to the floor if they drink too much. The name of the establishment is literalized in this way. On Sokolov’s use of neologisms, see Brainina.

neologism setting location language
our life is eternal

Biblical phrasing, for example, John 10:28–30. Also, an allusion to Life Everlastin, that is one more hypostasis of Orina.

bible religion intertextuality explanatory character
You

The inspector, Sidor Fomich Pozhilykh, to whom Ilya is addressing his letter of complaint.

explanatory character
candy wrappers

Candy wrappers appear three times in the novel (R160, 248, 262/E 19, 174, 199).

intratextuality motif
I also took a little bit of medicine thanks to my merciful hostess

That is, Ilya drank. Alcohol theme.

explanatory theme
where in the world did I find such a last name, where did I snag it?

On one level, Ilya here suggests that he “picked up” his surname in the sense that it’s not really his name. It’s an adopted identity, a mask. Indeed, he just admitted loving collecting things: “I’m a fan, I possess a passion for collectin” (R262/E196).

explanatory character
Gypsy baron

A reference to Johann Strauss II’s operetta The Gypsy Baron (1885), which also deals with a hidden identity. Listen here.

intertextuality music foreign
pour some sand on it

Ilya refers to sand used to seal ink on paper to avoid smears.

explanatory
Клеши

Bellbottoms, a style of pants popular in the 1960s. Clothing motif.

motif
мичманка

The peaked hat of a sailor. Clothing motif.

motif
бушлат

A pea jacket or sailor jacket. Worn by the sailor who visits Orina in chapter 10 (R220/E123).

intratextuality motif
матрос Альбатросов

Alliteration.

Аллитерация.

sound stylistic device
Альбатросов

This name calls to mind two famous poetic “albatrosses”: Baudelaire’s (read it here) and Coleridge’s from The Rime of the Ancient Mariner (read it here). Addressing the latter subtext’s image of a bird wrapped around a sailor’s neck in penance, José Vergara writes, “Albatrosov is an embodiment of Ilya’s perceived betrayal by Orina, who it is said, sleeps with a number of sailors under the aforementioned overturned boat on the banks of the Volga, as well as guilt over his own actions. Ilya takes on his sorrow when he meets Albatrosov on a train after his separation from Orina. The avian-sailor thus serves to remind Ilya of the past he cannot escape. […] The anthropomorphized bird imagery, in this way, underscores Ilya’s lingering psychological trauma, both that which he himself caused and that which he received” (“Flap” 372). Animal-human motif. In a 2004 interview with Mario Caramitti, Sokolov comments on the suggestion of art predicting life in mysterious ways mentioning this specific character: “In the winter of 1978 I was living in Michigan and working on my second novel. One of the characters in the book, named Al’batrosov, has a background as a stoker on a ship. I was outlining the character by modeling him on my half-brother, a sailor, who was aboard a freighter at the time. Without thinking about the possible consequences, I made Albatrosov’s fate take a turn for the worse: an explosion in the engine room takes off his arm. When the book came out, I learned that in the same days that I was writing that episode my brother lost an arm to an accident. This is, I would say, the cruelest and most disconcerting example in my practice as a writer. But on the whole what I write often comes true. More often, unfortunately, than I would like, since I generally write about unpleasant things” (“Sokolov, il fabbro pellegrino della prosa russa” 12). The same concept is described by the author in his 1981 essay On Secret Tablets: “things described in fiction come true; fate suggests to the neglected in spirit solutions that it has already found. And it does not make any difference whether the master creates life myths or they create him: the text has been recorded in the same place, on secret tablets. And nothing else but fate will answer all the questions and decide what will remain – silence or the word. And, if necessary, it’ll rip out our sinful tongues” (7).

motif intertextuality character author self-reference
Альбатросов, списан без рук

The opening of this chapter draws a direct continuation with the ending of ch. 12 by using the same words: “матрос Альбатросов, и списан вчистую.”

intratextuality structure
списан без рук с сухогруза на бал сухопутной участи; а сам-то с

Alliteration (s).

Аллитерация (с).

sound stylistic device
с сухогруза на бал

Set expression: с корабля на бал (to dash from one place to another, a sudden shift in conditions). Beside the specific use of this set expression in this sea scene, it is also worth noting that this character dashes from his sailor world (sukhogruz) to mainland life (sukhoputnaia uchast’) through linguistic play. Boguslawski notes that the expression is used in Pushkin’s Eugene Onegin, chapter 8” (“Annotations” 252).

phraseologism language intertextuality
сухогруза

Dry cargo ship. Boat motif.

motif
В нашу гавань, говорит, заходили корабли, большие, говорю, корабли из океана, в таверне, говорит, веселились моряки и пили, говорю, за здоровье атамана

Ilya and Al’batrasov sing the famous sailing song “To Our Harbor Ships Came.” Listen to a recording here. Read the lyrics here.

intertextuality music
говорит, заходили корабли, большие, говорю, корабли из океана, в таверне, говорит, веселились моряки и пили, говорю

Rhythm through repetition.

Ритм через повтор.

rhythm
корабли

Ship motif.

motif
черноморец

Al’batrasov serves on the Black Sea,

location
ка

Colloquial: suffix added to imperatives to express urgency.

register/style
чуток

Low: a tiny bit.

register/style
песнь

Dated/high/poetic: same as песня (song).

register/style
Отцвели во саду хризантемы давно, а тоска все цветет в моем сердце родном

Modified lyrics from the romance song “Chrysanthemums Long Ago Stopped Blooming in the Garden.” Read the lyrics here. Listen to a recording here.

music intertextuality
Отцвели во саду хризантемы давно, а тоска все цветет в моем сердце родном

An4*2.

Ан4*2.

metrical pattern
во с

An outdated form/use of the preposition.

language explanatory
хризантемы

Chrysanthemums. Plant motif.

motif
Свесил румпель на квинту

Set expression: вешать нос на квинту (to be upset).

phraseologism
румпель

Tiller — the device used to steer a boat. Boat motif.

motif
Альбатрос

This name calls to mind two famous poetic “albatrosses”: Baudelaire’s (read it here) and Coleridge’s from The Rime of the Ancient Mariner (read it here). Addressing the latter subtext’s image of a bird wrapped around a sailor’s neck in penance, José Vergara writes, “Albatrosov is an embodiment of Ilya’s perceived betrayal by Orina, who it is said, sleeps with a number of sailors under the aforementioned overturned boat on the banks of the Volga, as well as guilt over his own actions. Ilya takes on his sorrow when he meets Albatrosov on a train after his separation from Orina. The avian-sailor thus serves to remind Ilya of the past he cannot escape. […] The anthropomorphized bird imagery, in this way, underscores Ilya’s lingering psychological trauma, both that which he himself caused and that which he received” (“Flap” 372). Animal-human motif. In a 2004 interview with Mario Caramitti, Sokolov comments on the suggestion of art predicting life in mysterious ways mentioning this specific character: “In the winter of 1978 I was living in Michigan and working on my second novel. One of the characters in the book, named Al’batrosov, has a background as a stoker on a ship. I was outlining the character by modeling him on my half-brother, a sailor, who was aboard a freighter at the time. Without thinking about the possible consequences, I made Albatrosov’s fate take a turn for the worse: an explosion in the engine room takes off his arm. When the book came out, I learned that in the same days that I was writing that episode my brother lost an arm to an accident. This is, I would say, the cruelest and most disconcerting example in my practice as a writer. But on the whole what I write often comes true. More often, unfortunately, than I would like, since I generally write about unpleasant things” (“Sokolov, il fabbro pellegrino della prosa russa” 12). The same concept is described by the author in his 1981 essay On Secret Tablets: “things described in fiction come true; fate suggests to the neglected in spirit solutions that it has already found. And it does not make any difference whether the master creates life myths or they create him: the text has been recorded in the same place, on secret tablets. And nothing else but fate will answer all the questions and decide what will remain – silence or the word. And, if necessary, it’ll rip out our sinful tongues” (7).

intertextuality character motif author self-reference
запершил

Colloquial: to get a frog in one’s throat.

register/style
запершил, кашель

Alliteration (sh, l).

Аллитерация (ш, л).

sound stylistic device
полустанок

A small train station. Railroad theme.

theme
рохля

Colloquial: ditherer, dawdler.

register/style
рохля хохлатская жмыхами

Alliteration (kh, khl).

Аллитерация (х, хл).

sound stylistic device
хохлатская

A derogatory (or at least ironic) term to define Ukrainians.

register/style
жмыхами

Oil cake (also known as press and mill cake).

explanatory
окраина

A possible pun between okraina (periphery) and Ukraina (Ukraine), the setting of the episode.

pun language setting
Дверь рванул и ору: товарка, тоби зуби трэба

Alliteration (v, r, t, b).

Аллитерация (в, р, т, б).

sound stylistic device
товарка

Dated: comrade, partner.

register/style
тоби зуби трэба

Ukrainian: Do you need teeth?

foreign
а то поиздержался в пути

Ilya offers to sell his dentures, which he acquired in chapter 12 (R247/E171), to make up for all the money he’s spent on alcohol.

intratextuality explanatory
трэба, трэба, бэз ных зажурылась

Ukrainian: I need them, I need them, without them I’m at a loss.

foreign
зажурылась

Dialectical/Ukrainian: to lament.

register/style foreign
трояк

Colloquial: three rubles, a three-ruble note. Used in pre-revolutionary and Soviet Russia.

Russia register/style
подывысь, яки били — як кисть

Ukrainian: Look at how white they are — like a bone.

foreign
сызнова

Colloquial: again.

register/style
закадыки

Low: real friend.

register/style
Скорый

Скорый поезд — express train. Railroad theme.

explanatory theme
ресторацию

Dated: restaurant. This might also be a Polish influence since the characters are traveling through Ukraine.

register/style foreign
кушай с голоду, лечись смолоду

As Boguslawski notes, this is a playful paraphrase of the proverb “Береги платье снову, а честь смолоду” (Take care of your clothes when they’re new and your honor from youth) (“Annotations” 252). Here, the suggestion is that one should start drinking early. Alcohol theme.

theme phraseologism
кушай с голоду, лечись смолоду

Rhyme.

Рифма.

rhyme
на абордаж

Abordage. A naval term used to describe capturing a ship by boarding over the side.

explanatory
головизны

A fish product made from the head of large red fish, for example, sturgeon. Animal motif.

motif
хризантемами

Chrysanthemums. Plant motif.

motif
щукой

Pike. Animal motif.

motif
щукой быть

Sokolov explains that this is a more acceptable version of the rude expression “sukoi byt’” (to be an asshole) (personal communication, July 29, 2023).

Соколов объясняет, что это более приличная версия выражения “сукой быть”, так как “в хорошем обществе следует заменять суку на щуку” (личная переписка, 29 июля 2023).

language register/style phraseologism
салагой

Colloquial: rookie, noob.

register/style
плашкоуте

Pontoon or scow. Boat motif.

motif
баржé

Hopper barge — a non-self-propelled barge that is carried by other ships. Boat motif.

motif
плешатине

Low: a place where no plant has grown.

register/style
замаячила

Colloquial: to start to loom, appear in the distance.

register/style
мамзель

Dated/low/poetic: girl. From the French “mademoiselle.”

foreign register/style
пацанка

Colloquial: tomboy.

register/style
Поначалу один с ней цацкался, а потом корешей свободных от вахт прихватывал, и как раз она все песенкой этой мучилась

Orina presents her version of these events in chapter 10 (R220/E124).

intratextuality
цацкался

Colloquial: to make a fuss over, play with.

register/style
корешей

Low: buddy, chum, crony.

register/style
от вахт прихватывал

Alliteration.

Аллитерация.

sound stylistic device
от аврала оторвался

Paronomasia.

Парономазия.

sound stylistic device
аврала

Sail work. Boat motif.

motif
Дескать

Colloquial particle used to introduce reported speech, allegedly.

register/style
на поруки

Set expression: under someone else’s guarantee.

phraseologism
не до

Set expression: there are other things to worry about.

phraseologism
времени — полный обрез

A variation of the set expression “vremeni v obrez”: almost complete lack of time, very little time.

phraseologism
то губа, то приборка, то переборки зубришь, а то

Alliteration and synctactic repetition.

Аллитерация и синтаксический параллелизм.

sound rhythm stylistic device
губа

Military slang: detention.

register/style
то переборки зубришь

In previous editions, prior to 2006, instead of “Morze” here we read “pereborki” (a boat’s bulkhead).

edition
шмар

Colloquial: girl, skank.

register/style
кроме шуток

Set expression: jokes aside, seriously.

phraseologism
Нет, морская душа, моя адреса не оставила, уехала просто неизвестно куда, и попробуй взыщи

Ilya responds that his lover (also Orina) did not leave him an address.

explanatory
Пробедовали

Low: to scrape a living for a while, be in dire straits.

register/style
хавере

Neologism: a place where it is possible to eat (from the verb khavat’; slang: to eat).

Неологизм: место, где можно есть (от глагола хавать).

register/style neologism
не нажили ничего, кроме Якова

They didn’t make a real living, only had a son together.

explanatory
Якова

Ilya names Yakov as his son. Although appearing first only in chapter 4, this polymorphic character occupies a central role in the novel, being at once a dogkeeper, a hunter, a poet, a painter, and possibly the fictional author of the entire book. The ambiguity of his character is rooted in the similarity of his name with the word якобы (allegedly, supposedly). In a reply to Smith, published in a 1987 article (“The Verse in Sasha Sokolov’s Between Dog and Wolf”), Sokolov himself stated that: “the verse chapters are written by Iakov. He has nothing to do with me, but he has to be and is ‘sophisticated’, because he is that same painter who is discussed in the prose chapters (not the ones from Il’ia) ‘The Hunter’s Tale’, where he is the youth living in his mother’s house; the boy in love with the simple-minded girl whom the sailors take under the boat; the sketcher, the author of the Self-Portrait in Uniform and so forth; (And, of course, here, in this chapter, he is the hunter and poet who is ‘not fresh and not young’); ‘The Hunter’s Tale, or Pictures from an Exhibition’, where he is Iakov Il’ich Palamakhterov, ‘the incorruptible witness who is journeying towards the end of his practical and pitiless time,’ and imagines the scene from nineteenth-century ethnography in which his greatgrandfather takes part; ‘Pictures from an Exhibition’ (9), where he observes street scenes from the window of a cadet school; see also the other similar parts of the book, 13 and 16. They are written (all of them) from the point of view of an author, but that of a stylized author, i.e., once again, not directly from myself. Iakov is a poet, a painter, a dreamer, a member of the intelligentsia, who was born and grew up in the city. He is already grown up when he comes to the Itil” (327). Yakov is likewise crucial to the structuring of the plot, as it is he who kills Ilya in revenge for the latter’s attack on his dogs.

character structure
умненького, а все-таки дурачка

Antithesis, sarcasm.

Антитеза, сарказм.

register/style
стрелочника

Switchman — a railway worker who manages rail switches (to direct trains) and the movement of trains in a yard or station. Railroad theme.

theme
залетела

Colloquial: to get pregnant.

register/style
якобы

The phonetic resonance to Yakov (Яков) is intentional.

language
при стрелке она состояла, сутками дежурила на первых порах

Ilya describes Orina’s time working at a railroad station at the beginning of the novel (R155-156/E12).

intratextuality
дресвы

Grus — the build-up of tiny fragments of sand and gravel from the breakdown of crystalline rocks.

explanatory
подсобки

Low: storeroom.

register/style
ужинали. Ужинали

Anadiplosis.

Анадиплосис.

sound rhythm stylistic device
поди

Colloquial: just try.

register/style
Оря

Diminutive form of Orina. Orina, along with her variants, is the primary female character in the novel. In a sense, she is the only female figure in Between Dog and Wolf. As D.B. Johnson summarizes, the “promiscuous heroine Orina-Mariia is a train dispatcher, a princess in her dispatcher’s tower, who entertains her coworkers in her bed. Some of her orgiastic trysts take place near the train tracks to which her lovers tie her meddling husband Il’ia. Orina, in at least one time dimension, is killed by a train as she belatedly tries to save Il’ia who loses his leg” (“Twilight Cosmos” 647). Ilya is obsessed with this woman, and this passion “is the ultimate source of the woes that befall Il’ia, the itinerant grinder. It is his passion for the faithless slut Orina that brings about his misfortunes: the loss of his leg, his wandering life as a drunken grinder, and the grisly events that lead to his death” (643). Orina, alternatively called Maria, exists in the book also in another version, as ta dama, that dame, “a mysterious woman who appears along the river seeking Il’ia and, failing to find him, takes away a new lover each time […]. Her chance lovers return days later, sexually depleted and without interest in life. They usually die by their own hand” (645). In this figure (which embodies “virtually all female figures in the book,” D.B. Johnson, “Sasha Sokolov’s Between Dog and Wolf and the Modernist Tradition” 211), Sokolov merges two of his major literary themes: sex and death. Thus, Orina, Maria, that dame (ta dama, ta devochka, ta bobylka, ta babulya — all linked by the demonstrative “ta”), “Life Everlastin,” and death in general make up a unique polymorphic character. Smith notices that this female figure “does not appear at all in the verse. The episode of the sexual encounter between this figure and the sailors, which reoccurs obsessively in the prose, is correspondingly absent from the verse passages” (333). Olga Matich suggests the existence of a literary subtext for Sokolov’s novel: “Pilniak’s lesser known story Mother Earth (Mat’ syra zemlia 1927) about the violent confrontation between a naive young Bolshevik and an archaic Volga peasant community at the time of the Civil War. It is a kind of love story between the city-bred Bolshevik and the horse-tanner and young earth mother Arina, impaled by the Cossacks in one of the story’s many violence-ridden episodes. A variation on the Scythian juxtaposition of nature and culture, the story also depicts Arina’s maternal love for a fox cub, whom she tries to tame, thinking it is a wolf” (“Sasha Sokolov and His Literary Context” 312). The name Orina may also carry an echo of Pushkin’s famous nurse Arina Rodionovna (Toker 353). Mario Caramitti proposes three recurring hypostases of ta dama across Sokolov’s novels: a first hypostasis is that of a “mysterious woman carrying an obscure menace and/or sexual temptation”; a second hypostasis is that of an “apparently better defined and concrete woman being the object of desire for the main character”; and the third hypostasis is that of a “child-woman, often mentally retarded, often victim of violences, who touches upon a slightly more sublimated erotic sphere” (“Amore e morte” 114). Caramitti also adds that in the novel one of ta dama’s victims, before or after committing suicide, explicitly calls her “вечная жизнь” (Life Everlastin): “it is precisely in the coitus with eternity, in a region of oblivion that it is most difficult to place on this side or on the other side of the Lethe, that the male protagonist finds the widest surface of contact with this protean female entity of now vast symbolic implications” (118). Among Orina’s many lovers and among the men who take advantage of her, there is also Yakov, her son, who is in a way “re-enacting the role of the lame Oedipus” (Johnson, “Sasha Sokolov’s Between Dog and Wolf and the Modernist Tradition” 212). In chapter 14, Orina’s patronymic is said to be “Ignat’evna” (daughter of Ignatii): the name Ignatii possibly comes from the Latin “ignis” (fire) (R258/E190). Given that Orina is depicted here through her lust, such a patronymic seems apt.
