Her last name is said to be alternatively Neklina and Paklina (Spacklin, in translation): “You were called around the barracks Orina Neklina, and to whom do you belong now, to what kind of, let’s suppose, Spacklin, ah?” (R246/E169). On the border with Ukraine, close to Mariupol’ and to Chekhov’s hometown Taganrog, there is Rostov district named Neklinovsky. Paklia and paklina are regional terms indicating different things: a left-handed person, an unhandy and clumsy person, a bony hand, a piece of hemp or coarse fiber, messy hair. The terms паклен and неклен are named for the Tatar maple (note the slight differences in the spelling between the tree names and Orina’s surnames: Неклина, Паклина). As Sokolov explains, “Apparently, the author of the Notes and Ilya know or have heard about a man named Paklin. Ilya says that Arina’s last name was Neklina, probably after one of her men. And now, years later, Ilya assumes, she lives with someone else, whose last name suggests to him the tree’s other name” (personal communication, July 7, 2023).

character intertextuality intratextuality theme
без ножа

In chapter 1 she was compared to a sabre, though: “стояла Орина бела да ясна, словно шашка в сияньи месяца” (Orina stood there white and shiny, like a saber in the moonlight) (R157/E14).

intratextuality character
втерпеж

Typically only used in the negative: невтерпеж (low: to be unbearable). So, here: bearable. Alexander Boguslawski notes that variations on this word are used in four key moments in the novel (R155, 157, 225, 254/E12, 14–15, 132, 185) and that the “close parallels between the first and last use of the phrase should be noted — this is the frame within which two other versions of the expression exist. These two framing elements are built around the word nevterpezh, a colloquial adverb, usually used after a noun or pronoun in dative case and often with auxiliary verbs to be or to become. Thus, the expression “mne stalo nevterpezh” [it became unbearable to me; I could not stand it any longer], [sic] is common. However, Sokolov makes some important alterations to the expression — first, he discards the dative government and substitutes another verb for the auxiliary” (“How Sokolov’s” 218).

register/style language
втерпеж, а невтерпеж

Figura etymologica.

Этимологическая фигура речи.

sound stylistic device
невтерпеж

Low: to be unbearable.

register/style
бестактничала

Neologism: a verbal form of бестактный (tactless).

neologism
бестактничала вообще беспримерно

Alliteration (bes).

Аллитерация (бес).

sound stylistic device
Гребень как гребень

A key image in Ilya and Orina’s relationship. He gives it to her, and she lies about losing it on the train tracks. Introduced in chapter 1 (R156/E12). Comb motif.

motif intratextuality
Гребень как гребень, а твой, черепаховый, на путях утеряла

The scene was depicted already in ch. 1: “и гребень — однажды я пригляделся — не тот, я который на Воздвиженье презентовал. […] Что это, Орюшка, за гребень особенный такой у тебя? Гребень как гребень […]. На путях, лукавит, утратила гребень тот” (and the hair pick—once I looked more carefully—was not the one I presented to her on Ascension. […] What kind of a special hair pick, Oryushka, have you got? A hair pick like any other […]. On the rails, she stretches the truth, I lost that hair pick) (R156/E13). Comb motif.

intratextuality motif
барышей

Dated, low: profit.

register/style
Отбояривалась

This verb is used in chapter 1 twice in relation to Orina (R156/E12).

intratextuality
Юдоль

Dated: vale. A reference to the “vale of tears,” a term used to describe the daily, worldly tribulations that humanity experiences until its ascendence to Heaven. See Psalm 86:4.

register/style bible religion intertextuality
путевая, мыслилось, сама же ты — непутевая

Figura etymologica.

Этимологическая фигура речи.

sound stylistic device
непутевая

Colloquial: flighty, frivolous.

register/style
не моя, не со мною

Syntactic repetition.

Синтаксический параллелизм.

rhythm
главнеющая

Mispelling of “glavneishii,” superlative of “glavny,” main, principal.

register/style
не в этой вот конуре, не на этой лежачей возможности

Syntactic repetition.

Синтаксический параллелизм.

rhythm
конуре

A small dwelling or hovel but also a doghouse. Animal-human motif.

motif
на этой лежачей возможности

Bed.

explanatory
Яшку

Diminutive of Yakov, their son.

character register/style
шпалах

Railroad tie. Railroad theme.

explanatory theme
сварганили

Colloquial: to make, dash off, toss off.

register/style
А заря, скажу откровенно, занимается в зеркале

Ilya goes back to a fragment he already mentioned in chapter 1 when he depicted Orina swimming: “А заря, замечаю вскользь, занимается и в окне, и в зеркале” (And the dawn, I note in passin, is breakin in the window and in the mirror) (R156/E13).

intratextuality
А заря, скажу откровенно, занимается в зеркале похлеще любой заволческой, хотя Вам, наверное, малопонятно, что́ мы, которые население, Заволчьем зовем.

Alliteration (z, l).

Аллитерация (з, л).

sound stylistic device
похлеще

Colloquial: extreme state.

register/style
заволческой

Instead of indicating the territories that serve as setting for the novel as “Zavolzh’e” (Transvolga), the author creates this neologism (Transwolf-river) on the basis of his alternative spelling of the Volga River as “Volch’ia,” Wolf river.

location setting Russia
Вам

The inspector, Sidor Fomich Pozhilykh, to whom Ilya is addressing his letter of complaint.

explanatory character
Заволчьем

Instead of indicating the territories that serve as setting for the novel as “Zavolzh’e” (Transvolga), the author creates this neologism (Transwolf-river) on the basis of his alternative spelling of the Volga River as “Volch’ia,” Wolf river.

location setting Russia
водомер

A water-strider. Its movements on top of water recall those of an ice skater. Mentioned three times by Ilya (R210, 221, 254/E105, 126, 185). Animal motif.

motif intratextuality
Резко-резко

Repetition.

Повтор.

sound
споро-споро

Repetition.

Повтор.

sound
мачты гнутся и скрипят

A reference to Mikhail Lermontov’s 1832 poem “The Sail.” Read it in the original and in an English translation here.

intertextuality
Итиль

The Tatar name of the river Volga. The title of Ilya’s letter “Zaitil’shchina” is derived from this version of the river’s name. Ostanin also suggests a sound link between the rivers Itil’ and Lethe (Leta), the river of oblivion and forgetting, which also plays a major role in Sokolov’s first novel, A School for Fools (10).

location foreign language setting
тощанка

Ensign wasps, nightshade wasps, hatchet wasps, or cockroach egg parasitoid wasps. Animal motif.

motif
комариному

Mosquito. Animal motif.

motif
толкуну

Insect.

explanatory
на ходу подметки срезает

Set expression: на ходу подмётки рвать / на ходу подмётки резать (to cut corners, make one’s way to the top).

phraseologism
ялик

A yawl or dinghy. Boat motif.

motif
с размаху

Set expression: full force, with all one’s might.

phraseologism
дукатиной

Ostanin: “a papyrosa from the tabacco factory “Dukat” (98).

explanatory
скрипучих

Crutches.

explanatory
как лилеи растут. Подтверждаю: не трудятся, не прядут, но одеты с иголочки

A reference to Matthew 6:28–33.

bible religion intertextuality
лилеи

Lilies. According to Ernst and Johanna Lehner, the lily has long been “the sacred flower of motherhood,” and in “ancient Semitic legend, the lily sprang from the tears of Eve, when expelled from the Garden of Eden she found she was approaching motherhood. In later Christian lore it was said that the lily had been yellow until the day the Virgin Mary stooped to pick it. IN Christian symbolism the lily represented purity, chastity and innocence, and is the symbol of resurrection and Easter” (32). Plant motif.

motif religion
с иголочки

Set expression: dressed to kill, dressed to the nines.

phraseologism
Вы

The inspector, Sidor Fomich Pozhilykh, to whom Ilya is addressing his letter of complaint.

explanatory character
не дышлом кроен

Ostanin suggests that this is a variation on the expression “не лыком шит” (no slouch, no worse than) or лаптем щи хлебать (to live in ignorance, poverty) (99). With regard to the latter, note Sokolov’s use of negation.

phraseologism
гондрыбат

According to Ostanin, a variant of “гандрыватый” (slang for “humpback”). Sokolov confirms that this word is absent from Dal’’s dictionary but affirms having heard it from his Siberian relatives, who ‘used it in the sense: monstrous, absurd,’ and must therefore be intended as ‘very local, evidently vernacular as for style’ (personal communication, July 29, 2023).

Согласно Останину, вариант “гандрыватый.” Соколов признает, что слово отсутствует в словаре Даля, однако утверждает, что “слышал это речение от своих сибирских родственников, они его употребляли в значении - уродливый, нелепый” и поэтому “надо полагать, что оно очень местное, а по стилю явно просторечное” (личная переписка, 29 июля 2023).

explanatory register/style
костыли — костылями

Figura etymologica.

Этимологическая фигура речи.

sound stylistic device
Не могу же я из-за первых, по мере их неприсутствия

Ilya is alluding to the fact that he has already related how his crutches were stolen. If that’s the case, then how does he have them here? Sokolov describes the situation as follows: “Krylobyl explained to Ilya that the theft of his crutches happened only on this bank, where the time is present, and on the other bank, where the time is past or even the day before last, this theft has not happened yet, So Ilya, not wanting to miss nuts and mushroom season, began to travel to the other side of the river, and as soon as he is there there, on the other bank, that is, in the past, he immediately finds crutches and drags himself on them, on creaky ones, along the river. Ilya writes to the investigator that he understands his perplexity and recognizes his right to protest about this, that is, the investigator has the right to be perplexed: how can Ilya drag himself on squeaky crutches if they were stolen. Understanding the investigator’s bewilderment, Ilya begins explaining his situation with the words: Crutches with crutches, mushrooms with nuts. This phrase can be translated as: Crutches are one thing, and mushrooms and nuts another. Or thus: Do not confuse, mix crutches and gifts of nature. Or: The absence of crutches does not interfere with the collection of mushrooms and nuts. And an explanation why it doesn’t interfere is given below. Because the crutches are still present on the other side, And on this side, where they’re no longer present, there is a corresponding problem: to get to the mooring stakes. Apparently, there is no real pier but stakes hammered into the ground: boats are tied to them. Ilya gets to the shuttle, jumping on one leg along the fences and holding on to them. The fences are second cousins because there is a joking expression: he is my uncle’s second cousin. A varient —a cousin. So they say about some very distant relative. Ilya allows poetic license instead of saying: crutches upon crutches, mushrooms upon mushrooms, and nuts upon nuts, he probably, for the sake of brevity, says: mushrooms upon nuts, which is logically incorrect, but to him, a joker and a jester, this is quite excusable” (personal correspondence, August 4, 2023).

Илья намекает на факт, что он уже говорил о краже его костылей. Тогда, почему у него сейчас есть свои “скрипучие”? Соколов так объясняет ситуацию: “Крылобыл объяснил Илье, что кража его костылей случилась лишь на этом берегу, где время настоящее, а на другом берегу, где время прошлое или даже позапрошлое, этой кражи еще не было Поэтому Илья, не желая пропустить сезон орехов и грибов, стал ездить на ту сторону реки, и как только он там оказывается, там, на том берегу, то есть в прошлом, так сразу обретает костыли и тащится на них, на скрипучих, вдоль реки Илья пишет следователю, что понимает его недоумение и признает его право на протест по этому поводу, то есть следователь вправе испытывать недоумение: как же Илья может тащиться на скрипучих, если их украли Понимая недоумение следователя, Илья начинает объяснение своей ситуации словами: Костыли костылями, грибы орехами Эту фразу можно перевести так: Одно дело костыли, а другое дело грибы и орехи Или так: Не надо путать, смешивать костыли и дары природы Или: Отсутствие костылей не мешает сбору грибов и орехов И ниже дается объяснение, почему не мешает Потому что на другом берегу костыли еще присутствуют А на этом, где их уже нет, имеется соответствующая проблема: добраться до причальных колов Видимо, настоящего причала нет, но есть колы, вбитые в грунт: к ним привязывают лодки Илья добирается до челнока, прыгая на одной ноге вдоль плетней и держась за них Плетни троюродные потому, что есть шутливое выражение: он моему дяде троюродный плетень Вариант - двоюродный Так говорят о каком-нибудь очень дальнем родственнике Илья допускает поэтическую вольность Вместо того, чтобы сказать: костыли костылями, грибы грибами и орехи орехами, он, вероятно, ради краткости, говорит: грибы - орехами, что с точки зрения логики неверно, но ему, шутнику и балагуру, вполне простительно” (личная переписка, 4 августа 2023).

explanatory
тридцать лет, как тезка из Мурома, сиднем сидеть, оставив поездки по третьи и по вторые да три

An allusion to Ilya Muromets, a famed bogatyr (epic knight) of bylinas (epic folktales) from Kievan Rus’, who, it is said, was bedridden for 33 years. Read, for instance, “Ilya Muromets and Nightingale the Robber” here.

intertextuality Russia
Мурома

Murom — one of the oldest cities in Russia, located in the Vladimir Oblast and along the Oka River.

location Russia
сиднем

Colloquial: couch potato, lazy-bones.

Разговорное: лентяй, бездельник.

register/style
сиднем сидеть

Figura etymologica.

Этимологическая фигура речи.

sound stylistic device
да три по рогам

According to Ostanin, “пять в зубы и три по рогам” means “five years in a camp and three in civil law” in prison jargon (99).

phraseologism
по рогам

Set expression: получить по рогам (to get one’s butt handed to).

phraseologism
Крылобыл

Krylobyl is a key character dwelling in the world of the dead (living on the other shore of the Itil’ river). It is not surprising given his “speaking name” formed by the words “krylo” (wing) and “byl” (was, used to be). He is a hypostasis of an angelic creature guiding Ilya in his wanderings and suggesting to him ideas and reflections: in chapter 4 it will be Krylobyl who advances the idea of the origin of the “zhe” letter; it is Krylobyl in this chapter who Ilya describes as a “know-it-all” who “instructs,” the one “whom I trust, whom I praise.” In a sense, Krylobyl is Ilya’s Virgil or, even, Beatrice in his wandering across this very special Inferno, Purgatorio, and Paradiso. Toward the end of the novel, he will be addressed by the narrator in chapter 16 (R275/E220) and by Ilya in chapter 17 as “Fedot Fyodorov” (R279/E227).

character intertextuality intratextuality
надоумил

Colloquial: to put somebody wise to something, advise.

register/style
Илия

Elijah. Ilya is frequently compared—by the narrator and by himself—to the prophet Ilya/Elijah, who is commonly associated with lightning and thunder.

intertextuality bible character religion
мудрит

Colloquial: to get fancy, philosophize, overcomplicate things.

register/style
Петрикеич

Petrikeich is Ilya’s patronymic (“son of Petrik,” although this first name is not common). D.B. Johnson has noted that the patronymic contains an allusion to the folkloric figure of the “lisa Patrikeevna,” a trickster fox present in Slavic culture (“Sokolov’s Between Dog and Wolf and the Modernist Tradition” 211). The reference to a fox is not by chance: Ilya will be transfigured into a fox in Orina’s imagination when tied to a railroad (she had brought the hide of her pet fox to a shoemaker who later took advantage of her). Animal motif.

character motif intertextuality intratextuality folklore
время единовременно

Figura etymologica.

Этимологическая фигура речи.

sound stylistic device
фукцирует

Literary: to function.

register/style
Сидор

Sidor (shortened form of Isidor). Pozhilykh, the addressee of Ilya’s letter of complaint.

character
Батькович

A humorous patronymic derived from батька (old man, father), sometimes used when an interlocutor’s actual patronymic isn’t known.

explanatory
если настаиваю — то настаиваю

Rhythm through repetition.

Ритм через повтор.

rhythm
баста

Italian: basta, that’s all, that’s enough.

foreign
серчать

Low: to be angry.

register/style
Смотри, Крылобыл, этот умняга, учит, давай с тобой не время возьмем, а воду обычную. А давай. И останови впечатление, тормошит, в заводи она практически не идет, ее ряска душит, трава, а на стрежне — стремглав; так и время фукцирует, объяснял, в Городнище шустрит, махом крыла стрижа приблизительно, в Быдогоще — ни шатко ни валко, в лесах — совсем тишь да гладь. Потому и пойми уверенье, что кража, которой ты — жертва, случилась пока что лишь в нашем любимом городе, и больше нигде, и на той стороне о ней и не слыхивали. Стоит, значит, тебе туда переехать — все ходом и образуется.

A central passage in the novel. Krylobyl suggests that time functions differently depending on one’s location or perspective. Just as a river flows at different speeds, so does time move differently. In the backwoods, where not much happens, time moves slowly. In the city, where there is action and hustle and bustle, time moves quickly. Thus, if Ilya were to move to the other side of the river, he would be able to recover his crutches, where their theft, allegedly, hasn’t yet occurred. This view of time serves as one explanation for the various contradictions in the novel. For a consideration of Sokolov’s atypical approach to time in his novels, see Boguslawskii 1989.

explanatory time
Крылобыл

Krylobyl is a key character dwelling in the world of the dead (living on the other shore of the Itil’ river). It is not surprising given his “speaking name” formed by the words “krylo” (wing) and “byl” (was, used to be). He is a hypostasis of an angelic creature guiding Ilya in his wanderings and suggesting to him ideas and reflections: in chapter 4 it will be Krylobyl who advances the idea of the origin of the “zhe” letter; it is Krylobyl in this chapter who Ilya describes as a “know-it-all” who “instructs,” the one “whom I trust, whom I praise.” In a sense, Krylobyl is Ilya’s Virgil or, even, Beatrice in his wandering across this very special Inferno, Purgatorio, and Paradiso. Toward the end of the novel, he will be addressed by the narrator in chapter 16 (R275/E220) and by Ilya in chapter 17 as “Fedot Fyodorov” (R279/E227).

character intertextuality intratextuality
умняга

Colloquial: know-it-all.

register/style
воду обычную

Here: river.

explanatory
тормошит

Colloquial: to be, pester, bother.

register/style
ряска

Duckweed. Plant motif.

motif
трава

Grasses. Plant motif.

motif
стрежне

The fastest part of a river.

explanatory
фукцирует

Literary: to function.

register/style
Городнище

The main setting of the novel: a fictional town on the banks of the Volga River. Also called Gorodnishchi. Derived from the words for town (gorod) and beggar (nishchii). It is the “town of beggars.” Olga Matich writes: “If School for Fools was written against the background of youth prose, Sokolov’s next novel Between Dog and Wolf may be read as the author’s response to village prose, the literary rage of the seventies” (“Sasha Sokolov” 310). Vadim Kreid observes that Gorodnishche, a barracks village of beggars and thieves, resembles an “Anti-Kitezh” (Kitezh being the legendary, mythical city in Russian folklore that only the pure-hearted will have the chance to reach). In Gorodnishche, however, thieves rob beggars, while beggars beg thieves (“Zaitil’shchina” 213). According to Johnson, the living dwell Gorodnishche, while the dead reside on the other side of the river, in Bydogoshch (“Sokolov’s Between Dog and Wolf and the Modernist Tradition” 209). Johnson also mentions a statement by Sokolov himself: “Sokolov reports that the name is a blend of the dissolute eighteen-century town of Gorodnya described by A. N. Radishchev in his Journey from Petersburg to Moscow and a nearby town called Gorodishche. Thus the time layers of the sixteenth century, the eighteenth century, and a mythic present are all superimposed upon each other – a characteristic technique in the novel” (217).

location theme intertextuality setting folklore
стрижа

Swift. Rachel Warren Chadd and Marianne Taylor write, “No bird spends more time in the air than the Common Swift, which eats, drinks, sleeps and even mates on the wing; young birds are thought to stay airborne for several years before they nest. While swifts may not consistently live p to their name, flying at around 14mph (23km/h) when twisting in the air to feed on insects, their streamlined bodies and sickle-shaped wings equip them to perform long glides, steady 25mph (40km/h) flight during migration and short, rapid bursts” (243). Animal motif.

motif
Быдогоще

As Sokolov explains, there is no relation between this location and the Polish town of Bydgoszcz (personal communication, June 7, 2023). It is rather a misspelling of the village (and lake) of Vidogoshch by the Volga River, near Tver’. D.B. Johnson suggests that, while the living dwell in Gorodnishche, Bydogoshch is home for the dead (“Sokolov’s Between Dog and Wolf and the Modernist Tradition” 209).

location Russia theme setting
ни шатко ни валко

Set expression: middling, halfheartedly.

phraseologism
ни шатко ни валко

Alliteration.

Аллитерация.

sound stylistic device
тишь да гладь

Set expression: peace and quiet.

phraseologism
слыхивали

Colloquial: to hear.

register/style
будущем челноке в позапрошлое

As Ilya is in a time-space that is relatively “future” to the other side of the river, according to Krylobyl, he uses his “future scow” to travel to the past.

explanatory time
челноке

A dugout canoe. Boat motif.

motif
Несмотря на графы, параграфы волонтеров ущербным способствовать, недостаток у нас остреющий был и будет, на то мы и избраны

Sokolov translated this passage for us: “Despite various official rulings and regulations of state officials on the need to help the disabled, we [Russians] have an acute shortage of people willing to do so, which speaks of our universal cruelty, our inexhaustible sufferings, which is not surprising, because we as a nation are chosen to live in difficult conditions and constantly have problems” (personal communication, July 29, 2023).

Соколов “перевел” этот пассаж для нас: “Несмотря на различные официальные постановления и предписания государственных чиновников о необходимости помогать инвалидам, желающих это делать у нас острый недостаток, что говорит о нашей всеобщей жестокости, о наших неизбывных страданиях, что и не удивительно, ведь мы как народ избраны жить в тяжелых условиях и постоянно иметь проблемы” (личная переписка, 29 июля 2023).

Russia explanatory
графы, параграфы

Pseudo figura etymologica.

Квази-этимологическая фигура речи.

sound
Посему

Dated: therefore, thence.

register/style
похождениях

Dated: adventure.

register/style
толка

Dated: sort, kind.

register/style
Вам

The inspector, Sidor Fomich Pozhilykh, to whom Ilya is addressing his letter of complaint.

explanatory character
троюродные плетни

A variation of the set expression “нашему забору двоюродный плетень” (literally, a wattle-cousin to our fence) defining a distant relative.

phraseologism
Перегреб

Colloquial: to get across by rowing.

register/style
Лазаря

In the Bible, Jesus raises Lazarus from the dead four days after his death. See John 11:1-44.

bible religion intertextuality
Лазаря наобум

Set expression: at random, without thinking.

phraseologism
хромотой хромоту

Figura etymologica.

Этимологическая фигура речи.

sound stylistic device
хромотой хромоту поправ

A play on the Paschal troparion: “Christ is risen from the dead, by death trampling death, and to those in the tombs granting life!”

religion bible intertextuality
Вы

The inspector, Sidor Fomich Pozhilykh, to whom Ilya is addressing his letter of complaint.

explanatory
изучаете сей волапюк

Ilya asks Pozhilykh to read and study closely his letter.

explanatory
сей

Archaism: this.

archaism register/style
волапюк

Volapük — the first constructed language. Invented by Johann Martin Schleyer between 1879 and 1880 as an international language. The term is now sometimes used to refer to nonsense or incomprehensibility. Martina Napolitano writes: “Searching for such voice, the author has constructed a language, defined by one of the heroes as ‘Volapuke.’ This language apparently looks ‘mysterious’ and inaccessible, yet given a closer examination, it reveals its complex texture of interwoven threads: as any constructed language, its origins are to be found in a spoken, lively idiom. A basic rule in this particular ‘Volapuke’ derives from the chance allowed to any trope, word, expression, and even grapheme to transfigure into its direct, objectified meaning. The novel is thus built upon the unending weaving of linguistic threads that meet their realized metaphor” (“‘Studyin This Volapuke’” 293).

language foreign
обратили воображение на меня

A variation of “to draw attention on,” here literally “to draw imagination on.”

language
наш пострел-то, заститесь, всюду поспел

Set expression: Наш пострел всюду поспел (Our scamp has a finger in every pie).

phraseologism
пострел

Colloquial: scamp, rouge.

register/style
пострел-то, заститесь, всюду поспел

Paronomasia.

Парономазия.

sound stylistic device
заститесь

Low/colloquial: to block (light).

register/style
Заволчье

Instead of indicating the territories that serve as setting for the novel as “Zavolzh’e” (Transvolga), the author creates this neologism (Transwolf-river) on the basis of his alternative spelling of the Volga River as “Volch’ia,” Wolf river.

location setting Russia
зрю

Dated: to see.

register/style
Нет, это я Вас там вижу, ибо не я там, а Вы. Словом, оба мы правы. Ведь поскольку на разных мы сторонах, то и различная у нас география: Вы за Волчьей и я же.

A reflection of the convoluted nature of the novel’s world. The two banks of the river become interchangeable.

explanatory
Вас

The inspector, Sidor Fomich Pozhilykh, to whom Ilya is addressing his letter of complaint.

explanatory
ибо

Literary/dated: because, for.

register/style
Вы

The inspector, Sidor Fomich Pozhilykh, to whom Ilya is addressing his letter of complaint.

explanatory
Вы

The inspector, Sidor Fomich Pozhilykh, to whom Ilya is addressing his letter of complaint.

explanatory
дитя

Dated: kid. The use of the colloquial “napryamik” (straight) and the term “igrushki” (toys) further below stresses the infantile register used here.

register/style
Орина

Orina, along with her variants, is the primary female character in the novel. In a sense, she is the only female figure in Between Dog and Wolf. As D.B. Johnson summarizes, the “promiscuous heroine Orina-Mariia is a train dispatcher, a princess in her dispatcher’s tower, who entertains her coworkers in her bed. Some of her orgiastic trysts take place near the train tracks to which her lovers tie her meddling husband Il’ia. Orina, in at least one time dimension, is killed by a train as she belatedly tries to save Il’ia who loses his leg” (“Twilight Cosmos” 647). Ilya is obsessed with this woman, and this passion “is the ultimate source of the woes that befall Il’ia, the itinerant grinder. It is his passion for the faithless slut Orina that brings about his misfortunes: the loss of his leg, his wandering life as a drunken grinder, and the grisly events that lead to his death” (643). Orina, alternatively called Maria, exists in the book also in another version, as ta dama, that dame, “a mysterious woman who appears along the river seeking Il’ia and, failing to find him, takes away a new lover each time […]. Her chance lovers return days later, sexually depleted and without interest in life. They usually die by their own hand” (645). In this figure (which embodies “virtually all female figures in the book,” D.B. Johnson, “Sasha Sokolov’s Between Dog and Wolf and the Modernist Tradition” 211), Sokolov merges two of his major literary themes: sex and death. Thus, Orina, Maria, that dame (ta dama, ta devochka, ta bobylka, ta babulya — all linked by the demonstrative “ta”), “Life Everlastin,” and death in general make up a unique polymorphic character. Smith notices that this female figure “does not appear at all in the verse. The episode of the sexual encounter between this figure and the sailors, which reoccurs obsessively in the prose, is correspondingly absent from the verse passages” (333). Olga Matich suggests the existence of a literary subtext for Sokolov’s novel: “Pilniak’s lesser known story Mother Earth (Mat’ syra zemlia 1927) about the violent confrontation between a naive young Bolshevik and an archaic Volga peasant community at the time of the Civil War. It is a kind of love story between the city-bred Bolshevik and the horse-tanner and young earth mother Arina, impaled by the Cossacks in one of the story’s many violence-ridden episodes. A variation on the Scythian juxtaposition of nature and culture, the story also depicts Arina’s maternal love for a fox cub, whom she tries to tame, thinking it is a wolf” (“Sasha Sokolov and His Literary Context” 312). The name Orina may also carry an echo of Pushkin’s famous nurse Arina Rodionovna (Toker 353). Mario Caramitti proposes three recurring hypostases of ta dama across Sokolov’s novels: a first hypostasis is that of a “mysterious woman carrying an obscure menace and/or sexual temptation”; a second hypostasis is that of an “apparently better defined and concrete woman being the object of desire for the main character”; and the third hypostasis is that of a “child-woman, often mentally retarded, often victim of violences, who touches upon a slightly more sublimated erotic sphere” (“Amore e morte” 114). Caramitti also adds that in the novel one of ta dama’s victims, before or after committing suicide, explicitly calls her “вечная жизнь” (Life Everlastin): “it is precisely in the coitus with eternity, in a region of oblivion that it is most difficult to place on this side or on the other side of the Lethe, that the male protagonist finds the widest surface of contact with this protean female entity of now vast symbolic implications” (118). Among Orina’s many lovers and among the men who take advantage of her, there is also Yakov, her son, who is in a way “re-enacting the role of the lame Oedipus” (Johnson, “Sasha Sokolov’s Between Dog and Wolf and the Modernist Tradition” 212). In chapter 14, Orina’s patronymic is said to be “Ignat’evna” (daughter of Ignatii): the name Ignatii possibly comes from the Latin “ignis” (fire) (R258/E190). Given that Orina is depicted here through her lust, such a patronymic seems apt. Her last name is said to be alternatively Neklina and Paklina (Spacklin, in translation): “You were called around the barracks Orina Neklina, and to whom do you belong now, to what kind of, let’s suppose, Spacklin, ah?” (R246/E169). On the border with Ukraine, close to Mariupol’ and to Chekhov’s hometown Taganrog, there is Rostov district named Neklinovsky. Paklia and paklina are regional terms indicating different things: a left-handed person, an unhandy and clumsy person, a bony hand, a piece of hemp or coarse fiber, messy hair. The terms паклен and неклен are named for the Tatar maple (note the slight differences in the spelling between the tree names and Orina’s surnames: Неклина, Паклина). As Sokolov explains, “Apparently, the author of the Notes and Ilya know or have heard about a man named Paklin. Ilya says that Arina’s last name was Neklina, probably after one of her men. And now, years later, Ilya assumes, she lives with someone else, whose last name suggests to him the tree’s other name” (personal communication, July 7, 2023).

character theme intertextuality intratextuality
напрямик

Colloquial: plain as plain can be, straight on.

register/style
ка

Colloquial: suffix added to imperatives to express urgency.

register/style
игрушки мы пополам

She suggest to separate and split their belongings (“toys”).

explanatory
Илье

Ilya here refers to himself in the third person. Ilya is Between Dog and Wolf’s protagonist and the author of what he calls the Zaitil’shchina, a long letter with epic traits (starting from its title) addressed to Inspector Pozhilykh in which he comments on the theft of his crutches (he has only one leg) and, more generally, describes life along the Volga River. Johnson defines Ilya’s letter as “semiliterate ramblings,” aptly suggesting the style and register the reader will encounter in the novel (“Sokolov’s Between Dog and Wolf and the Modernist Tradition” 212). However, this character expresses at the same time a highly poetic and imaginative gaze. Ilya frequently associates himself with the biblical prophet Elijah, a figure folklorically linked with thunderstorms and which in Slavic tradition acquired some of the characteristics of the pagan God of the sky and thunder, Perun. Ilya is closely related to other key characters of the novel: he describes his troubled relationship with Orina (alternatively called Maria and the Dame) with whom he has a son; in encountering Yakov (the focus of several chapters), he suggests the possibility of being his father. The Oedipal plot resulting from this triangle has been noted by scholars, such as Johnson, who writes that “the game warden Iakov lusts for his mother (reincarnate as a mentally defective girl) and kills his father-all without being aware of the identity of either” (“Twilight Cosmos” 644).

explanatory character folklore intertextuality
скарба

Low: old household items.

register/style
портянок

Foot wraps traditionally worn before the widespread use of socks in armies. D.B. Johnson has identified more than twenty different types of shoes across Sokolov’s three novels: “bashmaki, botforty, boty, botinki (polubotinki), cheboty, chizmy, chubury, galoshi (kaloshi), gety, ichigi, kedy, klogi, lapti, mokrostupy, obuvi (obuvki), sapogi, sandalii, tapochki (polutapochki), shlepantsy, shtiblety, tapti, tufli, valenki. The list may easily be extended with appurtenances such as socks, stockings, footcloths, gaiters, skates, crutches, and artificial legs” (“The Galoshes Manifesto” 156). Regarding Between Dog and Wolf, he notes that Ilya’s last name immediately evokes Cinderella’s vair slippers. Johnson observes that “the footwear motif is Sokolov’s tribute, both conscious and unconscious, to the tradition in Russian literature represented by his predecessors – Ivan Bunin and Valentin Kataev” (179). In an interview with A. and N. Voronel’, Sokolov calls Bunin, along with Gogol, his “contemporaries, collaborators along a chain, older masters” (Voroneli, “Ia khochu” 184). Shoe motif.

motif intertextuality
умылся

Colloquial: to win, defeat.

register/style
амуницию

Soldier equipment; here things, belongings are implied.

explanatory
во влагалище неветшающее

A reference to Luke 12:33.

intertextuality bible religion
влагалище

Vagina. Here, it refers to some sort of container.

explanatory
изменнице

Orina.

character
сынулю

Yakov.

explanatory character
съехал по перилам на нулевой этаж и открыл под лестницей как бы скорняжный цех, как бы прохладным заделался скорняком

The narrative becomes confused again: This description matches Orina’s description of the furrier she encounters in her youth in chapter 10 (R220/E123).

intratextuality
как бы скорняжный цех, как бы прохладным заделался скорняком

Syntactic repetition and figura etymologica.

Синтаксический параллелизм и этимологическая фигура речи.

sound stylistic device rhythm
прохладным заделался скорняком

A reference to the expression “холодные сапожники” (cold shoemaker) that once described shoemakers working outside with poor tools, but is also figuratively used to mean “a person who is not passionate about what they do.” The etymology of “skornyak” (leather goods manufacturer) links this profession with “boots” (скорьнь).

phraseologism language character
На поверку

Colloquial set expression: actually, the reality is. Ilya is explaining that he did various activities (rather than shoemaking or treating leather) in order to earn for a living: “paintin and sellin various inflatable balloons from a pharmacy and inventin squeak-squaks.”

phraseologism register/style explanatory character
изобретал и уйди-уйди

Sokolov clarifies: “Ilya here uses the word invented in a humorous sense, in the sense of: made, mastered. And God knows who actually invented this silly toy” (personal communication, August 21, 2023).

Соколов уточняет: “Илья здесь использует слово изобретал в шутливом смысле, в значении: делал, мастерил. А кто на самом деле изобрел эту глупейшую игрушку - бог весть” (личная переписка, 21 августа 2023).

explanatory character
уйди-уйди

A toy from the early twentieth century that uses a balloon to make noises when air is released similar to “уйди-уйди” (go away, go away).

explanatory
перепалок с властями предержащими, промыслил патент

Alliteration (p, r, l).

Аллитерация (п, р, л).

sound stylistic device
Каким макаром

Set expression: what, how, how the heck, in which way.

phraseologism
статья одиннадцатая

A variation on the expression “дело десятое” (it doesn’t matter, neither here nor there).

phraseologism
кот наплакал

Set expression: a smidge, not much. Animal motif.

motif phraseologism
перелицовывать

To re-sew, making the back side face up. Sewing motif.

motif
поднаторел

Colloquial: to brush up on, become skilled.

register/style
поднаторел и на инструментах

Throughout the novel various words are used to describe the instruments Ilya plays, though it’s, of course, unlikely that he’s carrying all of them around.

music
ищи-свищи

Set expression: it’s as good as gone.

phraseologism
ищи-свищи

Alliteration.

Аллитерация.

sound stylistic device
непоседу

Colloquial: a fidgety person.

register/style
вольготно

Colloquial: freely.

register/style
рискну заметить, раскинулись

Alliteration (risk/rask, nu).

Аллитерация (риск/раск, ну).

sound stylistic device
в поисках радостей

A reference to the 1939 film “In Search of Joy” (watch it here) or the 1957 play of the same name by Viktor Rozov (read the original here).

intertextuality
заморозки, то жаворонки

Rhyme.

Рифма.

rhyme
жаворонки

Skylark. According to popular tradition, the arrival of this bird indicates that winter is over. There are also different incantations, for example: “Larks, larks! Come to us! Bring us a warm summer! Take away the cold winter. The cold winter has bored us, frozen our hands and feet.” Rachel Warren Chadd and Marianne Taylor write: “Chirps, trills and whistles, rising and falling in a rhythmic, minutes-long sequence are the hallmark of the Eurasian Skylark […] hearing its song, as the bird flutters high above a flower meadow or grassland, is the most exhilarating summer experience. […] In mythology and literature it is often linked to daybreak, and its exuberant singing also makes the bird a symbol of joy – both ideas captured in Shakespeare’s Sonnet 29 as the despairing subject thinks of his loved one […] ‘To a Skylark’ by Percy Bysshe Shelley similarly reflects its literary image as a blessed, joyful bird.” (236–237). However, despite its appeal and folkloric heritage, the “Eurasian Skylark and its relatives have also suffered horrific abuse,” including widespread hunting and inclusion in cruelly complex recipes such as “lark tongue pie” (237–238). For additional notes on the lark’s literary reputation, see Rowland, Birds 97–101. Animal motif.

motif intertextuality folklore
Заберешься на гору хлама передохнуть — дух займется: сторонушка хоть куда

Throughout the novel, the characters feel compelled to move upward and/or are dragged downward.

theme
хоть куда

Colloquial expression: first-rate, excellent, terrific.

phraseologism register/style
ветошница

Dated/colloquial: ragpicker.

register/style
граблями мусор гребет

Figura etymologica.

Этимологическая фигура речи.

sound stylistic device
сучара

Term of abuse: bitch (dog). Animal motif.

motif register/style
сучара трехпалая

Even dogs are invalid in this novel.

explanatory
ковыряется

Colloquial: to rummage.

register/style
шантрапа

Low: riff-raff, scum.

register/style
чинариков

Colloquial: not fully smoked cigarettes.

register/style
никто никому ничего

Alliteration, figura etymologica.

Аллитерация, этимологическая фигура речи.

sound stylistic device
человек человеку тут человек

A play on the Latin proverb “Homo homini lupus” (Man is a wolf to man). Ilya suggests here that people here treat each other respectfully. However, we know that is not the case. Animal-human motif. Ostanin also suggests that it’s a reference to the Soviet slogan “Человек человеку — друг, товарищ и брат” (Man is to man a friend, comrade, and brother, 100).

motif intertextuality foreign
человек человеку тут человек

Figura etymologica.

Этимологическая фигура речи.

stylistic device sound
дымки отечества повсеместно

A reference to Soviet-made cigarettes. Ostanin notes several allusions: Homer’s Odyssey (Russian/English), Gavrila Derzhavin’s 1798 poem “Afra” (Russian), and Alexander Griboyedov’s 1823 play Woe from Wit (Russian/English) (100). There is also a 1980 film with with the same name.

foreign phraseologism intertextuality
то восстание

Sokolov clarifies that “most likely, Ilya is referring to the coup d’état that took place in the year 1917 and was called the Great October Socialist Revolution. Uprisings occurred in other years, but all of them in his imagination merged into one insignificant event. Generally speaking, history is a vague and uninteresting thing for Ilya” (personal communication, August 26, 2023).

Соколов уточняет, что “скорее всего, Илья имеет в виду госпереворот, случившийся в семнадцатом году и названный Великой октябрьской социалистической революцией. Восстания происходили и в другие годы, но все они в его воображении слились в одно малозначительное событие. Вообще говоря, история для Ильи штука туманная и не интересная” (личная переписка, 25 августа 2023).

explanatory character Russia
куда ни плюнь

Set expression: no matter where you look.

phraseologism
да ну его

Set expression: screw it! to hell with it!

phraseologism
и рожна чужого он не взыскующий

He does not seek out foreign or alien adventures.

explanatory
рожна

Dated: a pointed stake. A wolf trap. Animal-human motif.

motif register/style
взыскующий

Dated: to see, search.

register/style
В те же кварталы составил приличную, если выразиться, крышкотеку, собрание, то есть, разноцветных закруток от саморазличных микстур

These are the bits and pieces Ilya has picked up in the dump.

explanatory
крышкотеку

Neologism: крышка (lid) + библиотека (library). крышка is also used to mean one’s death or end: Мне крышка = I’m done for, I’m screwed. Thus, here it might also be a collection of death. Likewise, крышка might also mean cap or cork, as Ilya mentions “mixtures” and “perfumes” which, as Venichka Yerofeev, made iconic in his novel Moskva-Petushki, were drunk as alcohol in hard times.

theme neologism
Вы

The inspector, Sidor Fomich Pozhilykh, to whom Ilya is addressing his letter of complaint.

explanatory character
советами и приветами

Rhyme.

Рифма.

rhyme
западная

Western, possibly, meaning Ukrainian here.

explanatory
ветошница

Dated/colloquial: ragpicker.

register/style
ветошница, тетка в  теле, благовоспитанная и с опытом, а годков тянула с хвостиком на шестьдесят — деликатес, да и только

Alliteration (t, s, p, m).

Аллитерация (т, с, п, м).

sound stylistic device
в  теле

Set expression: to have meat on one’s bones, chunky.

phraseologism
годков тянула с хвостиком на шестьдесят — деликатес, да и только

In his third novel, Palisandriia (translated into English as Astrophobia by Michael Henry Heim) Sokolov will recount the life and times of Palinsandr’ Dalberg, a Kremlin orphan with a preference for older women. See Matich “About Palisandriia” for a summary of the text. Read the novel here.

intertextuality
с хвостиком

Set expression: and then some, a bit more.

phraseologism
позадавнее

Neologism created out of “poza-“ (used for example in “posavchera”, day before yesterday) and “davnee” (low: “things happened long ago”).

neologism
увлечение с ней выгорело мимолетное, как случилось, впрочем, и с ее внучатой опечной или вроде того, в чем, понятно, винюсь, если требуется, задним числом

The narrative becomes confused again: This description matches Orina’s description of the furrier she encounters in her youth in chapter 10 (R220/E123).

intratextuality
внучатой опечной

Ostanin suggests “опекаемая внучка” (granddaughter-ward) (100).

explanatory
задним числом

Set expression: in hindsight.

phraseologism
вожделеем

Literary/dated: to lech, lust after.

register/style
взятки гладки

Set expression: can’t be held accountable, can’t get something from a person.

phraseologism
взятки гладки

Alliteration (iatki/adki).

Аллитерация (ятки/адки).

sound stylistic device
дуриком

Low: in vain.

register/style
Фордыбачила

Colloquial: to resist, object, be rude.

register/style
сторонилась

Literary: to avoid, dodge.

register/style
копнешь

Low: to go further, to see into, to penetrate.

register/style
не в себе

Set expression: off one’s trolley, crazy in the head.

phraseologism
ветошница

Dated/colloquial: ragpicker.

register/style
дойдет так дойдет

Rhythm through repetition.

Ритм через повтор.

rhythm
девулю

Low: girl.

register/style
шкуркой какой

Alliteration.

Аллитерация.

sound stylistic device
отмездрил

Ilya cleaned the hide.

explanatory
на склоне судьбы

Usually “na sklone let/dnei”: as old age is approaching. Here Ilya is worried as fate is approaching.

phraseologism
Фомич

The inspector, Sidor Fomich Pozhilykh, to whom Ilya is addressing his letter of complaint. Patronymic: son of Foma (Thomas).

character
задвинул задвижку

Alliteration (zadvi).

Аллитерация (задви).

sound stylistic device
невзначай

Colloquial: accidentally, by chance, in passing, accidentally.

register/style
чем лукавый не шутит

Variation on the set expression: чем черт не шутит (you can never tell, anything may happen, the devil has his ways). Лукавый (crafty, the Evil One) replaces черт (devil).

phraseologism
по расчету

Implied “brak”: marriage of convenience.

language
без ко́рысти

Set expression: no strings attached, platonically.

phraseologism
применился к невзрослой волнительно и сгоряча

That is, Ilya took advantage of the girl (Orina).

explanatory
когда под карбасом

This scene is mentioned by Orina in chapter 8 (R211/E108).

intratextuality
карбасом

Dialectical: karbass, a medium rowing and fishing sailboat. Boat motif.

motif register/style
по гроб

Set expression: по гроб жизни (to one’s dying day, forever, big time).

phraseologism
матросят

Colloquial: debauch.

register/style
матросят укромно мою малолетнюю какие-то речники

The narrative becomes confused again: This description matches Orina’s description of the sailors she encounters in her youth in chapter 10 (R220/E124).

intratextuality
речники

Workers on the river, but also riffle beetles. Animal-human motif.

motif
сквозь пальцы

Implied “smotriu”: to deliberate avoid seeing what one do not want to see.

phraseologism
дело их молодое, правое

A variation on lines from Soviet Vice-chairman of the Council of People’s Commissar and People’s Commissar for Foreign Affairs Vyacheslav M. Molotov’s June 22, 1941 speech on the occasion of the German invasion: “Our cause is just” (Ostanin 101). Read the original here and an English translation here.

intertextuality
поматросят

Colloquial: debauch.

register/style
Орина

Orina, along with her variants, is the primary female character in the novel. In a sense, she is the only female figure in Between Dog and Wolf. As D.B. Johnson summarizes, the “promiscuous heroine Orina-Mariia is a train dispatcher, a princess in her dispatcher’s tower, who entertains her coworkers in her bed. Some of her orgiastic trysts take place near the train tracks to which her lovers tie her meddling husband Il’ia. Orina, in at least one time dimension, is killed by a train as she belatedly tries to save Il’ia who loses his leg” (“Twilight Cosmos” 647). Ilya is obsessed with this woman, and this passion “is the ultimate source of the woes that befall Il’ia, the itinerant grinder. It is his passion for the faithless slut Orina that brings about his misfortunes: the loss of his leg, his wandering life as a drunken grinder, and the grisly events that lead to his death” (643). Orina, alternatively called Maria, exists in the book also in another version, as ta dama, that dame, “a mysterious woman who appears along the river seeking Il’ia and, failing to find him, takes away a new lover each time […]. Her chance lovers return days later, sexually depleted and without interest in life. They usually die by their own hand” (645). In this figure (which embodies “virtually all female figures in the book,” D.B. Johnson, “Sasha Sokolov’s Between Dog and Wolf and the Modernist Tradition” 211), Sokolov merges two of his major literary themes: sex and death. Thus, Orina, Maria, that dame (ta dama, ta devochka, ta bobylka, ta babulya — all linked by the demonstrative “ta”), “Life Everlastin,” and death in general make up a unique polymorphic character. Smith notices that this female figure “does not appear at all in the verse. The episode of the sexual encounter between this figure and the sailors, which reoccurs obsessively in the prose, is correspondingly absent from the verse passages” (333). Olga Matich suggests the existence of a literary subtext for Sokolov’s novel: “Pilniak’s lesser known story Mother Earth (Mat’ syra zemlia 1927) about the violent confrontation between a naive young Bolshevik and an archaic Volga peasant community at the time of the Civil War. It is a kind of love story between the city-bred Bolshevik and the horse-tanner and young earth mother Arina, impaled by the Cossacks in one of the story’s many violence-ridden episodes. A variation on the Scythian juxtaposition of nature and culture, the story also depicts Arina’s maternal love for a fox cub, whom she tries to tame, thinking it is a wolf” (“Sasha Sokolov and His Literary Context” 312). The name Orina may also carry an echo of Pushkin’s famous nurse Arina Rodionovna (Toker 353). Mario Caramitti proposes three recurring hypostases of ta dama across Sokolov’s novels: a first hypostasis is that of a “mysterious woman carrying an obscure menace and/or sexual temptation”; a second hypostasis is that of an “apparently better defined and concrete woman being the object of desire for the main character”; and the third hypostasis is that of a “child-woman, often mentally retarded, often victim of violences, who touches upon a slightly more sublimated erotic sphere” (“Amore e morte” 114). Caramitti also adds that in the novel one of ta dama’s victims, before or after committing suicide, explicitly calls her “вечная жизнь” (Life Everlastin): “it is precisely in the coitus with eternity, in a region of oblivion that it is most difficult to place on this side or on the other side of the Lethe, that the male protagonist finds the widest surface of contact with this protean female entity of now vast symbolic implications” (118). Among Orina’s many lovers and among the men who take advantage of her, there is also Yakov, her son, who is in a way “re-enacting the role of the lame Oedipus” (Johnson, “Sasha Sokolov’s Between Dog and Wolf and the Modernist Tradition” 212). In chapter 14, Orina’s patronymic is said to be “Ignat’evna” (daughter of Ignatii): the name Ignatii possibly comes from the Latin “ignis” (fire) (R258/E190). Given that Orina is depicted here through her lust, such a patronymic seems apt. Her last name is said to be alternatively Neklina and Paklina (Spacklin, in translation): “You were called around the barracks Orina Neklina, and to whom do you belong now, to what kind of, let’s suppose, Spacklin, ah?” (R246/E169). On the border with Ukraine, close to Mariupol’ and to Chekhov’s hometown Taganrog, there is Rostov district named Neklinovsky. Paklia and paklina are regional terms indicating different things: a left-handed person, an unhandy and clumsy person, a bony hand, a piece of hemp or coarse fiber, messy hair. The terms паклен and неклен are named for the Tatar maple (note the slight differences in the spelling between the tree names and Orina’s surnames: Неклина, Паклина). As Sokolov explains, “Apparently, the author of the Notes and Ilya know or have heard about a man named Paklin. Ilya says that Arina’s last name was Neklina, probably after one of her men. And now, years later, Ilya assumes, she lives with someone else, whose last name suggests to him the tree’s other name” (personal communication, July 7, 2023).

character intertextuality intratextuality theme
сводили с рельс

Took off course, derailed, made uncomfortable. Train motif.

explanatory motif
карбасом

Dialectical: karbass, a medium rowing and fishing sailboat. Boat motif.

motif register/style
тряпицам

Colloquial: rag.

register/style
елозя

Colloquial: to crawl, fidget.

register/style
по местам обнажения

On uncovered parts of his body.

explanatory
мух

Fly. Animal motif.

motif
Успению

Assumption. August 15/28. Celebration of Mary Mother of God’s death and bodily assumption into Heaven.

religion bible time
Жил да был

Set expression: there once was, once upon a time.

phraseologism
дыре

Colloquial: backwater, dump.

register/style
уключины

The device used to hold an oar in place on a boat. Ilya mentions “rowlocks crying” in chapter 8 (R206/E105). Boat motif.

intratextuality motif
мизгирькрестовик

The folk name of a species of spiders belonging to the family of wolf spiders (not a coincidental choice). Animal motif.

motif
Все он днище, как небо высокое

Antithesis.

Антитеза.

register/style
Насекомых отлавливал я и в тенеты к нему кидал.

An6GD.

Ан6ГД.

metrical pattern
тенеты

The spider’s web is compared to a hunting trap. Animal motif.

explanatory motif
Паша

Diminutive form of Pavel.

character
Паша, грядый, Паук ты мой, Петр

“Spider” (паук, pauk) is sometimes used as a nickname for Pavel/Pasha due to the phonetic similarity. Animal-human motif.

explanatory motif
Паша, грядый, Паук ты мой, Петр племяннику из деревни писал

Alliteration (p, t, l).

Аллитерация (п, т, л).

sound stylistic device
Паша, грядый, Паук ты мой, Петр племяннику из деревни писал, я не видел скушней события, чем январь без дрождей, доставляй — кровь из носу

Here, Ilya returns to the events at the beginning of chapter 4, in which Pavel writes to Pyotr and the latter struggles to find the letter zhe (ж) in the yeast (дрожжи) (R173–174/E43–44).

intratextuality
Паук

Colloquial: greedy person. Animal motif.

motif
Петр

Pyotr/Fyodor/Yegor. Pyotr, “one smart aleck from Sloboda” (R173/E43), is Pavel’s uncle and is sent by his nephew in Gorodnishche to find yeast (when the story is retold in chapter 14, it is the uncle asking Pavel to get yeast). He is alternatively called Fyodor and Egor: the choice seems to be guided by the presence of the vowels “e/ë” and “o.” The name Pyotr, from Greek, means “stone.” The apostle Peter (Simon Peter), in origin a fisherman, is considered the first Christian Pope. Peter denied Jesus three times during the events of the crucifixion, as Jesus had predicted (see Matthew 26:69–75). Fyodor (Theodore) means “God’s gift.” The name Egor is a variation of the name Georgy (George), from the Greek “farmer.” He was immortalized as a saint through the legend of the Dragon (Saint George the Dragon-slayer). In chapter 10 this character is challenged to hang himself, which results in his suicide.

character intratextuality foreign religion
кровь из носу

Set expression: at all costs, by hook or crook, even if it kills you, no matter what.

phraseologism
Сердцем верю, он продолжал, сердцем знаю

Rhythm through repetition.

Ритм через повтор.

rhythm
умишко

Diminutive: small intellect.

register/style
не привезешь ведь; ахти нам в таком разе, пьяницам

The characters are hoping to use the yeast to produce alcohol, which explains why they are so desperate in its absence. Alcohol theme.

explanatory theme
ахти нам

Dated/dialectical: woe is us.

register/style
Павел

Foma Pogibel’ is one of the two oarsmen who carry people (dead or alive) across the river (a variation of the Charon Greek myth). The other oarsman is Eryoma (diminutive of Eremei, Jeremiah). However, in Note XXXI the oarsman is called Pavel, just like the character who sends his uncle Pyotr to get yeast in Gorodnishche. As underlined by one of the epigraphs in Sokolov’s first novel, A School for Fools, the biblical name of Pavel is somehow interchangeable: “Saul, who is called Paul” (see Acts 13:9–10). As for Foma, he carries a biblical name, too (Thomas), whose Aramaic origin suggests the idea of the “twin.” This apostle is famous as “Doubting Thomas” due to his denial of the resurrection of Jesus, according to the Gospel of John (see John 20:24–31). In the Orthodox tradition, the Sunday following Easter is called “Thomas Sunday”: the day when Christ appeared to his disciples; it took seeing Jesus’ body for Thomas to name him “My Lord and my God.”

character intertextuality bible religion
Фенистом

Here, the Finist substitutes for the common pigeon. See the fairy tale “The Feather of Finist the Falcon” (or “Finist the Falcon”) collected by Aleksandr Afanas’yev. Read the original here and an English translation here. As Margaret Ziolkowski points out, “much as the grinder [Ilya] is crippled by a train because his wife’s lovers tie him to the track, Fenist cuts his wings when his beloved’s jealous sisters fasten knives and needles to her windowstill. Yet Fenist does ultimately find martial bliss, while Il’ia loses his wife when she futilely attempts to rescue him” (414). Animal motif.

intertextuality motif
Илюша

Diminutive of Ilya.

character register/style
сударь

Dated: sir.

register/style
пророк ты наш

Ilya is frequently compared—by the narrator and by himself—to the prophet Ilya/Elijah, who is commonly associated with lightning and thunder.

intertextuality bible religion character
втемяшилось

Low: usually used with “в голову” (to get stuck in one’s head). An echo of the expression “в темя клюет” repeated twice in chapter 4: “Турман Петра в темя клюет” (R174/E43), “турман Петруху в темя так не клевал, как они осу” (R182/E57).

register/style intratextuality
Петром

Pyotr/Fyodor/Yegor. Pyotr, “one smart aleck from Sloboda” (R173/E43), is Pavel’s uncle and is sent by his nephew in Gorodnishche to find yeast (when the story is retold in chapter 14, it is the uncle asking Pavel to get yeast). He is alternatively called Fyodor and Egor: the choice seems to be guided by the presence of the vowels “e/ë” and “o.” The name Pyotr, from Greek, means “stone.” The apostle Peter (Simon Peter), in origin a fisherman, is considered the first Christian Pope. Peter denied Jesus three times during the events of the crucifixion, as Jesus had predicted (see Matthew 26:69–75). Fyodor (Theodore) means “God’s gift.” The name Egor is a variation of the name Georgy (George), from the Greek “farmer.” He was immortalized as a saint through the legend of the Dragon (Saint George the Dragon-slayer). In chapter 10 this character is challenged to hang himself, which results in his suicide.

character foreign intratextuality religion
браги

Home brew. Alcohol theme.

theme
и с буквой помог

This refers to the moment at the beginning of chapter 4, in which Ilya’s grinding wheel breaks and consequently presents Pavel and Pyotr with the missing letter zhe (ж) in the form of the broken wheel (R173–174/E43–44).

intratextuality
деньжат

Diminutive for money.

register/style
ибо

Literary/dated: because, for.

register/style
Заволчье

Instead of indicating the territories that serve as setting for the novel as “Zavolzh’e” (Transvolga), the author creates this neologism (Transwolf-river) on the basis of his alternative spelling of the Volga River as “Volch’ia,” Wolf river.

setting location Russia
предивному

Religious: miraculous.

register/style
оных

Dated: the very, the aforementioned.

register/style
сапог

Boots with high tops. D.B. Johnson has identified more than twenty different types of shoes across Sokolov’s three novels: “bashmaki, botforty, boty, botinki (polubotinki), cheboty, chizmy, chubury, galoshi (kaloshi), gety, ichigi, kedy, klogi, lapti, mokrostupy, obuvi (obuvki), sapogi, sandalii, tapochki (polutapochki), shlepantsy, shtiblety, tapti, tufli, valenki. The list may easily be extended with appurtenances such as socks, stockings, footcloths, gaiters, skates, crutches, and artificial legs” (“The Galoshes Manifesto” 156). Regarding Between Dog and Wolf, he notes that Ilya’s last name immediately evokes Cinderella’s vair slippers. Johnson observes that “the footwear motif is Sokolov’s tribute, both conscious and unconscious, to the tradition in Russian literature represented by his predecessors – Ivan Bunin and Valentin Kataev” (179). In an interview with A. and N. Voronel’, Sokolov calls Bunin, along with Gogol, his “contemporaries, collaborators along a chain, older masters” (Voroneli, “Ia khochu” 184). Shoe motif.

Вид обуви с высоким голенищем. Изображено ниже:

Мотив обуви.

motif intertextuality
катанок

Colloquial: valenki. Traditional Russian winter felt boots. D.B. Johnson has identified more than twenty different types of shoes across Sokolov’s three novels: “bashmaki, botforty, boty, botinki (polubotinki), cheboty, chizmy, chubury, galoshi (kaloshi), gety, ichigi, kedy, klogi, lapti, mokrostupy, obuvi (obuvki), sapogi, sandalii, tapochki (polutapochki), shlepantsy, shtiblety, tapti, tufli, valenki. The list may easily be extended with appurtenances such as socks, stockings, footcloths, gaiters, skates, crutches, and artificial legs” (“The Galoshes Manifesto” 156). Regarding Between Dog and Wolf, he notes that Ilya’s last name immediately evokes Cinderella’s vair slippers. Johnson observes that “the footwear motif is Sokolov’s tribute, both conscious and unconscious, to the tradition in Russian literature represented by his predecessors – Ivan Bunin and Valentin Kataev” (179). In an interview with A. and N. Voronel’, Sokolov calls Bunin, along with Gogol, his “contemporaries, collaborators along a chain, older masters” (Voroneli, “Ia khochu” 184). Shoe motif.

motif register/style intertextuality
сном кобылы рябой

Set expression: nonsense.

phraseologism
подвизается

High: to strive, move toward. The subject is winter, which is approaching “like nonsense” (or a dream) while they still have no yeast.

register/style time
Раздобыл

Colloquial: to procure.

register/style
песку

As at the end of the chapter, Ilya refers to sand used to seal ink on paper to avoid smears.

explanatory
снеговая бобылка

Instead of снеговая баба (snow woman, i.e., snowman).

explanatory
бобылка

Colloquial: an unmarried, lonely (peasant) woman. She will make several appearances throughout the novel and is associated with Orina.

Разговорное: незамужняя, одинокая женщина-крестьянка. Она встречается далее в романе и обычно ассоциируется с Ориной.

character register/style
схватила форменную капель

That is, as Ostanin notes, she has caught a cold and begun to drip from her nose (101).

explanatory
бокогрея

Dated: February. бок (side) + греть (to warm). As Boguslawski translates it, “side-warmer,” meaning a shift in weather that will warm your sides. A reference to St. Sidor Bokogrei, whose day is celebrated on May 14/27. He was given this name, because it was said that bitterly cold northern winds would stop blowing on this date. Likewise, swifts and swallows would fly to Sidor with the approach of warm weather. However, people caution against taking the appearance of the first bird as a sure sign of the cold’s departure, similar to the following clause. Read his saint’s life here. The addressee of Ilya’s letter is, of course, Sidor Fomich Pozhilykh. Animal motif.

character intertextuality motif time religion
марток оставит без порток

Set expression: March will leave you without pants. The meaning is that March, as a transitional month between winter and spring, brings with it some challenges: occasional unexpected shifts in weather, low resources before the harvest.

time phraseologism
порток

Colloquial: pants, trousers.

register/style
Фениста

See the fairy tale “The Feather of Finist the Falcon” (or “Finist the Falcon”) collected by Aleksandr Afanas’yev. Read the original here and an English translation here. As Margaret Ziolkowski points out, “much as the grinder [Ilya] is crippled by a train because his wife’s lovers tie him to the track, Fenist cuts his wings when his beloved’s jealous sisters fasten knives and needles to her windowstill. Yet Fenist does ultimately find martial bliss, while Il’ia loses his wife when she futilely attempts to rescue him” (414). Animal motif.

intertextuality motif
Павлу

Foma Pogibel’ is one of the two oarsmen who carry people (dead or alive) across the river (a variation of the Charon Greek myth). The other oarsman is Eryoma (diminutive of Eremei, Jeremiah). However, in Note XXXI the oarsman is called Pavel, just like the character who sends his uncle Pyotr to get yeast in Gorodnishche. As underlined by one of the epigraphs in Sokolov’s first novel, A School for Fools, the biblical name of Pavel is somehow interchangeable: “Saul, who is called Paul” (see Acts 13:9–10). As for Foma, he carries a biblical name, too (Thomas), whose Aramaic origin suggests the idea of the “twin.” This apostle is famous as “Doubting Thomas” due to his denial of the resurrection of Jesus, according to the Gospel of John (see John 20:24–31). In the Orthodox tradition, the Sunday following Easter is called “Thomas Sunday”: the day when Christ appeared to his disciples; it took seeing Jesus’ body for Thomas to name him “My Lord and my God.”

character intertextuality bible religion
дядей

Pyotr. Pyotr/Fyodor/Yegor. Pyotr, “one smart aleck from Sloboda” (R173/E43), is Pavel’s uncle and is sent by his nephew in Gorodnishche to find yeast (when the story is retold in chapter 14, it is the uncle asking Pavel to get yeast). He is alternatively called Fyodor and Yegor: the choice seems to be guided by the presence of the vowels “e/ë” and “o.” The name Pyotr, from Greek, means “stone.” The apostle Peter (Simon Peter), in origin a fisherman, is considered the first Christian Pope. Peter denied Jesus three times during the events of the crucifixion, as Jesus had predicted (see Matthew 26:69–75). Fyodor (Theodore) means “God’s gift.” The name Egor is a variation of the name Georgy (George), from the Greek “farmer.” He was immortalized as a saint through the legend of the Dragon (Saint George the Dragon-slayer). In chapter 10 this character is challenged to hang himself, which results in his suicide.

character foreign intratextuality religion
Ильи

Ilya is Between Dog and Wolf’s protagonist and the author of what he calls the Zaitil’shchina, a long letter with epic traits (starting from its title) addressed to Inspector Pozhilykh in which he comments on the theft of his crutches (he has only one leg) and, more generally, describes life along the Volga River. Johnson defines Ilya’s letter as “semiliterate ramblings,” aptly suggesting the style and register the reader will encounter in the novel (“Sokolov’s Between Dog and Wolf and the Modernist Tradition” 212). However, this character expresses at the same time a highly poetic and imaginative gaze. Ilya frequently associates himself with the biblical prophet Elijah, a figure folklorically linked with thunderstorms and which in Slavic tradition acquired some of the characteristics of the pagan God of the sky and thunder, Perun. Ilya is closely related to other key characters of the novel: he describes his troubled relationship with Orina (alternatively called Maria and the Dame) with whom he has a son; in encountering Yakov (the focus of several chapters), he suggests the possibility of being his father. The Oedipal plot resulting from this triangle has been noted by scholars, such as Johnson, who writes that “the game warden Iakov lusts for his mother (reincarnate as a mentally defective girl) and kills his father-all without being aware of the identity of either” (“Twilight Cosmos” 644).

character intertextuality folklore
я не деньги пока точу — исцеления

Ilya grinds not for money but rather for “healing” (i.e., alcohol). Alcohol theme.

theme explanatory
паче

Archaism: even more so, more.

archaism register/style
на пропивон

Low: to be spent on drinking.

register/style
зашибать

Low: to get wasted. Alcohol theme.

register/style theme
принадлежности

That is, his crutches. Ilya accuses Pavel and the other hunters of stealing his crutches.

explanatory
вы и подобные вам преподобные

Ilya refers to the fact that Pavel, like many of the other hunters, share names with saints. “Prepodobnye refer to saints among monks who behaved like Jesus in fasting, prayer, and other acts.

religion bible
подобные вам преподобные спроворили

Alliteration (podobnye, p, v), figura etymologica.

Аллитерация (подобные, п, в), этимологическая фигура речи.

sound stylistic device
кутерьму

Colloquial: chaos, disorder. A variation on the expression “кутерьма буревая” used at the very end of chapter 4. According to Ostanin (42), this expression is a quotation from Nadezhda Pavlovich’s poem “Beregom, beregom, s razbegu…” Read the original here.

register/style intertextuality phraseologism
до доезжачего сведения довел

Alliteration (do).

Аллитерация (до).

sound stylistic device
доезжачего

Yakov.

character explanatory
ультимат

Neologism: ультиматум (ultimatum) + мат (obscenity).

neologism
келейно

Religious: out of church, at home. Ilya invites him not to wash dirty linen in public.

register/style
без вынесения на высокие кровли

A reference to Luke 12:3 (Boguslawski, “Annotations” 253).

religion bible intertextuality
не волк и не выжловка

Between dog and wolf.

theme
не волк и не выжловка

Alliteration (ne, v, l, k).

Аллитерация (не, в, л, к).

sound stylistic device
выжловка

A hound bitch. That is, a female hunting dog. Animal motif.

motif
се

Archaism: this.

archaism register/style
уступчивый, на возврат одного вместо двух

Ilya is ready to accept also only one of his crutches instead of both.

explanatory
светильники тела

The eyes. A reference to Matthew 6:22.

religion bible intertextuality
наблюдай, как бы не выбросило ненароком во внешнюю темноту

A death threat.

explanatory
выбросило ненароком во внешнюю темноту

A reference to Matthew 8:12. “Outer darkness” refers to the space into which nonbelievers will be cast out from the kingdom of Heaven.

religion bible intertextuality
Вам

The inspector, Sidor Fomich Pozhilykh, to whom Ilya is addressing his letter of complaint.

character explanatory
Паука

That is, Pavel/Pyotr/Fyodor. Animal-human motif.

motif character
не к ночи будет помянуто

Set expression: не к ночи будь помянут (speak of the devil).

phraseologism
как душу он мухам хоботом своим вынимал под ладьей

As Sokolov explains, “Ilya observes the spider’s actions toward the insects. In telling about the spider, Ilya associatively recalls the correspondence between Paul and Peter about yeast,” since “a person named Pavel may receive the nickname Spider: this is probably due to the spelling of the foreign variant of this name: Paul” (personal communication, July 29, 2023). Animal motif.

Как Соколов объясняет, “Илья наблюдает за его [паука] действиями по отношению к насекомым. Рассказывая о пауке, Илья ассоциативно вспоминает о переписке Павла и Петра по поводу дрожжей. Дело в том, что человек, названный Павлом, может получить прозвище Паук: вероятно, это связано со спеллингом иностранного варианта данного имени: Paul” (личная переписка, 29 июля 2023). Мотив животных.

explanatory character motif
мухам

Fly. Animal motif.

motif
хоботом

Proboscis.

explanatory
ладьей

A longship, such as those used by Vikings.

motif
Оря

Diminutive form of Orina. Orina, along with her variants, is the primary female character in the novel. In a sense, she is the only female figure in Between Dog and Wolf. As D.B. Johnson summarizes, the “promiscuous heroine Orina-Mariia is a train dispatcher, a princess in her dispatcher’s tower, who entertains her coworkers in her bed. Some of her orgiastic trysts take place near the train tracks to which her lovers tie her meddling husband Il’ia. Orina, in at least one time dimension, is killed by a train as she belatedly tries to save Il’ia who loses his leg” (“Twilight Cosmos” 647). Ilya is obsessed with this woman, and this passion “is the ultimate source of the woes that befall Il’ia, the itinerant grinder. It is his passion for the faithless slut Orina that brings about his misfortunes: the loss of his leg, his wandering life as a drunken grinder, and the grisly events that lead to his death” (643). Orina, alternatively called Maria, exists in the book also in another version, as ta dama, that dame, “a mysterious woman who appears along the river seeking Il’ia and, failing to find him, takes away a new lover each time […]. Her chance lovers return days later, sexually depleted and without interest in life. They usually die by their own hand” (645). In this figure (which embodies “virtually all female figures in the book,” D.B. Johnson, “Sasha Sokolov’s Between Dog and Wolf and the Modernist Tradition” 211), Sokolov merges two of his major literary themes: sex and death. Thus, Orina, Maria, that dame (ta dama, ta devochka, ta bobylka, ta babulya — all linked by the demonstrative “ta”), “Life Everlastin,” and death in general make up a unique polymorphic character. Smith notices that this female figure “does not appear at all in the verse. The episode of the sexual encounter between this figure and the sailors, which reoccurs obsessively in the prose, is correspondingly absent from the verse passages” (333). Olga Matich suggests the existence of a literary subtext for Sokolov’s novel: “Pilniak’s lesser known story Mother Earth (Mat’ syra zemlia 1927) about the violent confrontation between a naive young Bolshevik and an archaic Volga peasant community at the time of the Civil War. It is a kind of love story between the city-bred Bolshevik and the horse-tanner and young earth mother Arina, impaled by the Cossacks in one of the story’s many violence-ridden episodes. A variation on the Scythian juxtaposition of nature and culture, the story also depicts Arina’s maternal love for a fox cub, whom she tries to tame, thinking it is a wolf” (“Sasha Sokolov and His Literary Context” 312). The name Orina may also carry an echo of Pushkin’s famous nurse Arina Rodionovna (Toker 353). Mario Caramitti proposes three recurring hypostases of ta dama across Sokolov’s novels: a first hypostasis is that of a “mysterious woman carrying an obscure menace and/or sexual temptation”; a second hypostasis is that of an “apparently better defined and concrete woman being the object of desire for the main character”; and the third hypostasis is that of a “child-woman, often mentally retarded, often victim of violences, who touches upon a slightly more sublimated erotic sphere” (“Amore e morte” 114). Caramitti also adds that in the novel one of ta dama’s victims, before or after committing suicide, explicitly calls her “вечная жизнь” (Life Everlastin): “it is precisely in the coitus with eternity, in a region of oblivion that it is most difficult to place on this side or on the other side of the Lethe, that the male protagonist finds the widest surface of contact with this protean female entity of now vast symbolic implications” (118). Among Orina’s many lovers and among the men who take advantage of her, there is also Yakov, her son, who is in a way “re-enacting the role of the lame Oedipus” (Johnson, “Sasha Sokolov’s Between Dog and Wolf and the Modernist Tradition” 212). In chapter 14, Orina’s patronymic is said to be “Ignat’evna” (daughter of Ignatii): the name Ignatii possibly comes from the Latin “ignis” (fire) (R258/E190). Given that Orina is depicted here through her lust, such a patronymic seems apt. Her last name is said to be alternatively Neklina and Paklina (Spacklin, in translation): “You were called around the barracks Orina Neklina, and to whom do you belong now, to what kind of, let’s suppose, Spacklin, ah?” (R246/E169). On the border with Ukraine, close to Mariupol’ and to Chekhov’s hometown Taganrog, there is Rostov district named Neklinovsky. Paklia and paklina are regional terms indicating different things: a left-handed person, an unhandy and clumsy person, a bony hand, a piece of hemp or coarse fiber, messy hair. The terms паклен and неклен are named for the Tatar maple (note the slight differences in the spelling between the tree names and Orina’s surnames: Неклина, Паклина). As Sokolov explains, “Apparently, the author of the Notes and Ilya know or have heard about a man named Paklin. Ilya says that Arina’s last name was Neklina, probably after one of her men. And now, years later, Ilya assumes, she lives with someone else, whose last name suggests to him the tree’s other name” (personal communication, July 7, 2023).

character intertextuality intratextuality theme
Оря

Diminutive form of Orina. Orina, along with her variants, is the primary female character in the novel. In a sense, she is the only female figure in Between Dog and Wolf. As D.B. Johnson summarizes, the “promiscuous heroine Orina-Mariia is a train dispatcher, a princess in her dispatcher’s tower, who entertains her coworkers in her bed. Some of her orgiastic trysts take place near the train tracks to which her lovers tie her meddling husband Il’ia. Orina, in at least one time dimension, is killed by a train as she belatedly tries to save Il’ia who loses his leg” (“Twilight Cosmos” 647). Ilya is obsessed with this woman, and this passion “is the ultimate source of the woes that befall Il’ia, the itinerant grinder. It is his passion for the faithless slut Orina that brings about his misfortunes: the loss of his leg, his wandering life as a drunken grinder, and the grisly events that lead to his death” (643). Orina, alternatively called Maria, exists in the book also in another version, as ta dama, that dame, “a mysterious woman who appears along the river seeking Il’ia and, failing to find him, takes away a new lover each time […]. Her chance lovers return days later, sexually depleted and without interest in life. They usually die by their own hand” (645). In this figure (which embodies “virtually all female figures in the book,” D.B. Johnson, “Sasha Sokolov’s Between Dog and Wolf and the Modernist Tradition” 211), Sokolov merges two of his major literary themes: sex and death. Thus, Orina, Maria, that dame (ta dama, ta devochka, ta bobylka, ta babulya — all linked by the demonstrative “ta”), “Life Everlastin,” and death in general make up a unique polymorphic character. Smith notices that this female figure “does not appear at all in the verse. The episode of the sexual encounter between this figure and the sailors, which reoccurs obsessively in the prose, is correspondingly absent from the verse passages” (333).
