Olga Matich suggests the existence of a literary subtext for Sokolov’s novel: “Pilniak’s lesser known story Mother Earth (Mat’ syra zemlia 1927) about the violent confrontation between a naive young Bolshevik and an archaic Volga peasant community at the time of the Civil War. It is a kind of love story between the city-bred Bolshevik and the horse-tanner and young earth mother Arina, impaled by the Cossacks in one of the story’s many violence-ridden episodes. A variation on the Scythian juxtaposition of nature and culture, the story also depicts Arina’s maternal love for a fox cub, whom she tries to tame, thinking it is a wolf” (“Sasha Sokolov and His Literary Context” 312). The name Orina may also carry an echo of Pushkin’s famous nurse Arina Rodionovna (Toker 353). Mario Caramitti proposes three recurring hypostases of ta dama across Sokolov’s novels: a first hypostasis is that of a “mysterious woman carrying an obscure menace and/or sexual temptation”; a second hypostasis is that of an “apparently better defined and concrete woman being the object of desire for the main character”; and the third hypostasis is that of a “child-woman, often mentally retarded, often victim of violences, who touches upon a slightly more sublimated erotic sphere” (“Amore e morte” 114). Caramitti also adds that in the novel one of ta dama’s victims, before or after committing suicide, explicitly calls her “вечная жизнь” (Life Everlastin): “it is precisely in the coitus with eternity, in a region of oblivion that it is most difficult to place on this side or on the other side of the Lethe, that the male protagonist finds the widest surface of contact with this protean female entity of now vast symbolic implications” (118). Among Orina’s many lovers and among the men who take advantage of her, there is also Yakov, her son, who is in a way “re-enacting the role of the lame Oedipus” (Johnson, “Sasha Sokolov’s Between Dog and Wolf and the Modernist Tradition” 212). In chapter 14, Orina’s patronymic is said to be “Ignat’evna” (daughter of Ignatii): the name Ignatii possibly comes from the Latin “ignis” (fire) (R258/E190). Given that Orina is depicted here through her lust, such a patronymic seems apt. Her last name is said to be alternatively Neklina and Paklina (Spacklin, in translation): “You were called around the barracks Orina Neklina, and to whom do you belong now, to what kind of, let’s suppose, Spacklin, ah?” (R246/E169). On the border with Ukraine, close to Mariupol’ and to Chekhov’s hometown Taganrog, there is Rostov district named Neklinovsky. Paklia and paklina are regional terms indicating different things: a left-handed person, an unhandy and clumsy person, a bony hand, a piece of hemp or coarse fiber, messy hair. The terms паклен and неклен are named for the Tatar maple (note the slight differences in the spelling between the tree names and Orina’s surnames: Неклина, Паклина). As Sokolov explains, “Apparently, the author of the Notes and Ilya know or have heard about a man named Paklin. Ilya says that Arina’s last name was Neklina, probably after one of her men. And now, years later, Ilya assumes, she lives with someone else, whose last name suggests to him the tree’s other name” (personal communication, July 7, 2023).

character intertextuality intratextuality theme
раззуживали

Colloquial: to egg on, excite, instigate, irritate.

register/style
изложинах

Dialectical: ravine.

register/style
В будни получки, в аванца ль пятницы

These words will be repeated shortly below in modified form. This episode is also mentioned in chapter 8 (R211/E107).

intratextuality
получки

Low: payday, paycheck.

register/style
в знаменитых ольхах за линией

These words will be repeated shortly below.

intratextuality
ольхах

Alder. Plant motif.

motif
гужевались

Colloquial: to party, have fun.

register/style
ремеслух

Low: vocational school, or in general craftsmanship.

register/style
Слабоваты вы, Орина Игнатьевна, как выяснилось, на передок

Set expression: слаба на передок (sex starved, an easy lay). Notice also the move to the formal register (“vy” + name and patronymic here) instead of the informal “ty” and the diminutive above. Sex theme.

phraseologism theme
Орина Игнатьевна

This is the only mention in the book of Orina’s patronymic (daughter of Ignatii). A certain Ignatii Vartolomeich is mentioned in chapter 5 in the historical “Gogolian” scenes. Orina, along with her variants, is the primary female character in the novel. In a sense, she is the only female figure in Between Dog and Wolf. As D.B. Johnson summarizes, the “promiscuous heroine Orina-Mariia is a train dispatcher, a princess in her dispatcher’s tower, who entertains her coworkers in her bed. Some of her orgiastic trysts take place near the train tracks to which her lovers tie her meddling husband Il’ia. Orina, in at least one time dimension, is killed by a train as she belatedly tries to save Il’ia who loses his leg” (“Twilight Cosmos” 647). Ilya is obsessed with this woman, and this passion “is the ultimate source of the woes that befall Il’ia, the itinerant grinder. It is his passion for the faithless slut Orina that brings about his misfortunes: the loss of his leg, his wandering life as a drunken grinder, and the grisly events that lead to his death” (643). Orina, alternatively called Maria, exists in the book also in another version, as ta dama, that dame, “a mysterious woman who appears along the river seeking Il’ia and, failing to find him, takes away a new lover each time […]. Her chance lovers return days later, sexually depleted and without interest in life. They usually die by their own hand” (645). In this figure (which embodies “virtually all female figures in the book,” D.B. Johnson, “Sasha Sokolov’s Between Dog and Wolf and the Modernist Tradition” 211), Sokolov merges two of his major literary themes: sex and death. Thus, Orina, Maria, that dame (ta dama, ta devochka, ta bobylka, ta babulya — all linked by the demonstrative “ta”), “Life Everlastin,” and death in general make up a unique polymorphic character. Smith notices that this female figure “does not appear at all in the verse. The episode of the sexual encounter between this figure and the sailors, which reoccurs obsessively in the prose, is correspondingly absent from the verse passages” (333). Olga Matich suggests the existence of a literary subtext for Sokolov’s novel: “Pilniak’s lesser known story Mother Earth (Mat’ syra zemlia 1927) about the violent confrontation between a naive young Bolshevik and an archaic Volga peasant community at the time of the Civil War. It is a kind of love story between the city-bred Bolshevik and the horse-tanner and young earth mother Arina, impaled by the Cossacks in one of the story’s many violence-ridden episodes. A variation on the Scythian juxtaposition of nature and culture, the story also depicts Arina’s maternal love for a fox cub, whom she tries to tame, thinking it is a wolf” (“Sasha Sokolov and His Literary Context” 312). The name Orina may also carry an echo of Pushkin’s famous nurse Arina Rodionovna (Toker 353). Mario Caramitti proposes three recurring hypostases of ta dama across Sokolov’s novels: a first hypostasis is that of a “mysterious woman carrying an obscure menace and/or sexual temptation”; a second hypostasis is that of an “apparently better defined and concrete woman being the object of desire for the main character”; and the third hypostasis is that of a “child-woman, often mentally retarded, often victim of violences, who touches upon a slightly more sublimated erotic sphere” (“Amore e morte” 114). Caramitti also adds that in the novel one of ta dama’s victims, before or after committing suicide, explicitly calls her “вечная жизнь” (Life Everlastin): “it is precisely in the coitus with eternity, in a region of oblivion that it is most difficult to place on this side or on the other side of the Lethe, that the male protagonist finds the widest surface of contact with this protean female entity of now vast symbolic implications” (118). Among Orina’s many lovers and among the men who take advantage of her, there is also Yakov, her son, who is in a way “re-enacting the role of the lame Oedipus” (Johnson, “Sasha Sokolov’s Between Dog and Wolf and the Modernist Tradition” 212). In chapter 14, Orina’s patronymic is said to be “Ignat’evna” (daughter of Ignatii): the name Ignatii possibly comes from the Latin “ignis” (fire) (R258/E190). Given that Orina is depicted here through her lust, such a patronymic seems apt. Her last name is said to be alternatively Neklina and Paklina (Spacklin, in translation): “You were called around the barracks Orina Neklina, and to whom do you belong now, to what kind of, let’s suppose, Spacklin, ah?” (R246/E169). On the border with Ukraine, close to Mariupol’ and to Chekhov’s hometown Taganrog, there is Rostov district named Neklinovsky. Paklia and paklina are regional terms indicating different things: a left-handed person, an unhandy and clumsy person, a bony hand, a piece of hemp or coarse fiber, messy hair. The terms паклен and неклен are named for the Tatar maple (note the slight differences in the spelling between the tree names and Orina’s surnames: Неклина, Паклина). As Sokolov explains, “Apparently, the author of the Notes and Ilya know or have heard about a man named Paklin. Ilya says that Arina’s last name was Neklina, probably after one of her men. And now, years later, Ilya assumes, she lives with someone else, whose last name suggests to him the tree’s other name” (personal communication, July 7, 2023).

character intertextuality intratextuality theme
неровно к сладкому дышите

Set expression: неровно дышать (to have a hankering for).

phraseologism
гребень

A key image in Ilya and Orina’s relationship. He gives it to her, and she lies about losing it on the train tracks. Introduced in chapter 1 (R156/E12). Comb motif.

motif intratextuality
кашинской

Kashin — a town in the Tver Oblast on the Kashinka River (a tributary of the Volga). As Ostanin explains, Ilya here refers to a vodka created in 1898 by a liquor-vodka factory in Kashin (102). Boguslawski adds: “According to a popular belief, even the greatest drunk wouldn’t drink that vodka without saying ‘God save us’” (“Annotations” 253). Alcohol theme.

location Russia theme
злоблудучая

Neologism created on the basis of the words “zlo” (evil) and “blud” (sexual debauchery).

neologism
фря

Derogatory: arrogant woman.

register/style
Илию

Ilya refers to himself in the third person. Ilya is Between Dog and Wolf’s protagonist and the author of what he calls the Zaitil’shchina, a long letter with epic traits (starting from its title) addressed to Inspector Pozhilykh in which he comments on the theft of his crutches (he has only one leg) and, more generally, describes life along the Volga River. Johnson defines Ilya’s letter as “semiliterate ramblings,” aptly suggesting the style and register the reader will encounter in the novel (“Sokolov’s Between Dog and Wolf and the Modernist Tradition” 212). However, this character expresses at the same time a highly poetic and imaginative gaze. Ilya frequently associates himself with the biblical prophet Elijah, a figure folklorically linked with thunderstorms and which in Slavic tradition acquired some of the characteristics of the pagan God of the sky and thunder, Perun. Ilya is closely related to other key characters of the novel: he describes his troubled relationship with Orina (alternatively called Maria and the Dame) with whom he has a son; in encountering Yakov (the focus of several chapters), he suggests the possibility of being his father. The Oedipal plot resulting from this triangle has been noted by scholars, such as Johnson, who writes that “the game warden Iakov lusts for his mother (reincarnate as a mentally defective girl) and kills his father-all without being aware of the identity of either” (“Twilight Cosmos” 644).

character folklore intertextuality
купина

Dated: bush. Typically used in the phrase Неопалимая купина (Burning Bush). According to the Book of Exodus, Moses was given his charge to lead the Israelites out of Egypt at the Burning Bush.

religion bible register/style intertextuality
сумерки

Between dog and wolf.

theme
непотребное

Dated: obscenity.

register/style
сумасброды

Colloquial: screwball, ill-advised person.

register/style
малахольной

Orina. Low: nut job, crazy person.

register/style
отыграться

Low: to compensate for a loss.

register/style
потакая

Colloquial: to indulge.

register/style
В будень путейской получки, в аванца ль пятницу

A repetition of a few lines above.

intratextuality
получки

Low: payday, paycheck.

register/style
дербалызнул

Colloquial: to knock back. Alcohol theme.

register/style theme
подобрал чего-то железное у депо и пожду в знаменитых ольхах за линией

Ilya picks up a piece of iron in order to ambush the men that Orina has been sleeping with.

explanatory
ольхах

Alder. Plant motif.

motif
стрекулисты

Low: cheat, swindler.

register/style
в  шестнадцать мальчишеских

According to Ostanin, a reference to Yakov Shvedov’s 1936 song “The Eaglet” (102). Read the lyrics here. Listen to a recording here.

music intertextuality
профурсетку

Low/slang: working girl, slut.

register/style
лобную поляну любви

A play on “Лобное место” — Cavalry, the site of Jesus’ crucifixion. Also, a location in central Moscow where executions were traditionally held. Once again death and sex are associated.

Russia foreign religion theme
лобную поляну любви

Alliteration (l, b).

Аллитерация (л, б).

sound stylistic device
кургана

Kurgan — a tumulus or burial mound that covers a grave.

explanatory
нехристем

Low: disbeliever; a person with no conscience.

register/style
залили они буркалы

Set expression: залить глаза (to get hammer, drink to the point of having one’s eyes float).

phraseologism
буркалы

Low: eye.

register/style
кто во что горазд.

Set expression: кто во что горазд (each in his own fashion and as hard as he can, everyone is doing whatever he feels like). Here: sex. Sex theme.

phraseologism theme
мерекаю

Dated/low: to think, imagine.

register/style
пора не пора, иду со двора

Set expression: пора-не пора, иду со двора (ready or not, here I come!).

phraseologism
пора не пора, иду со двора

Rhyme.

Рифма.

rhyme
поспешишь — насмешишь

Set expression: поспешишь — людей насмешишь (haste makes waste, one step at a time, fools rush in).

phraseologism
поспешишь — насмешишь

Rhyme.

Рифма.

rhyme
погожу

Colloquial: to wait.

register/style
чтоб не соврать

Set expression: not going to lie, let me see.

phraseologism
восемь тысяч четыреста двадцать два

Ostanin suggests that Ilya’s train ticket number calls to mind both George Orwell’s 1984 (1948) and the number of letters in the Jewish alphabet (103). However, Sokolov says: “This figure does not correlate with anything. It only hints at how dear the memory of Meadow Saturday is to Ilya: he has forever memorized the relatively complex number of that ticket” (personal communication, July 29, 2023). Railroad theme.

Останин предлагает обратить внимание на то, что номер железнодорожного билета Ильи напоминает и роман 1984 Джорджа Оруэлла (1948) и количество букв в еврейском алфавите (103). Однако, Соколов говорит: “Это цифра ни с чем не соотносится. Она лишь намекает на то, сколь дорога Илье память о Луговой Субботе: он навсегда запомнил сравнительно сложный номер того билета” (личная переписка, 29 июля 2023).

intertextuality theme
Луговая Суббота

Emblematic of paradise. There is a Meadow Saturday located off the Irtysh River. A reference to Gennady Karpunin’s 1975 Meadow Saturday, or, The Believable and Unbelieable Adventures of Vasya Morkovkin. This book, a sort of modern fable, is the only one addressed to children written by the Siberian poet and literary critic Gennady Karpunin (1939-1998), famous for his works devoted to The Tale of Igor’s Campaign. The story, full of curious characters such as its hero Vasya, concentrates on the theme of nature, whose beauty must be preserved by humans, and it addresses issues of scientific and technological progress (placed in the Soviet context) and its interaction with nature and human beings. Karpunin’s education as physicist emerges in the scientific humor contained in the book. A character in the novel defines Meadow Saturday as follows: “It’s a major holiday of flowers and grass, a honey-harvest day. Do you hear bumblebees and bees buzzing? That means the clover has bloomed. Honey collected on this day is the best. It will cure any cold. This is the day of flood-meadows, the celebration of pastures. Take a look at the modest shepherd’s purse growing along the roadside, even it blooms on this wonderful day. This is a day of warm earth, fragrant chernozem, a field road, and a ringing lark. That’s what a Meadow Saturday is!” Read the original here.

intertextuality location Russia
Принял свое участье

Set expression: принять участие (to take part in).

phraseologism
Принял свое участье в Илье настоящий картон, очень принял

Rhythm through repetition.

Ритм через повтор.

rhythm
Илье

Ilya is Between Dog and Wolf’s protagonist and the author of what he calls the Zaitil’shchina, a long letter with epic traits (starting from its title) addressed to Inspector Pozhilykh in which he comments on the theft of his crutches (he has only one leg) and, more generally, describes life along the Volga River. Johnson defines Ilya’s letter as “semiliterate ramblings,” aptly suggesting the style and register the reader will encounter in the novel (“Sokolov’s Between Dog and Wolf and the Modernist Tradition” 212). However, this character expresses at the same time a highly poetic and imaginative gaze. Ilya frequently associates himself with the biblical prophet Elijah, a figure folklorically linked with thunderstorms and which in Slavic tradition acquired some of the characteristics of the pagan God of the sky and thunder, Perun. Ilya is closely related to other key characters of the novel: he describes his troubled relationship with Orina (alternatively called Maria and the Dame) with whom he has a son; in encountering Yakov (the focus of several chapters), he suggests the possibility of being his father. The Oedipal plot resulting from this triangle has been noted by scholars, such as Johnson, who writes that “the game warden Iakov lusts for his mother (reincarnate as a mentally defective girl) and kills his father-all without being aware of the identity of either” (“Twilight Cosmos” 644).

character folklore intertextuality
настоящий картон

According to Ostanin, Ilya’s reserved-seat ticket (104).

explanatory
Луговая Суббота

Emblematic of paradise. There is a Meadow Saturday located off the Irtysh River. A reference to Gennady Karpunin’s 1975 Meadow Saturday, or, The Believable and Unbelieable Adventures of Vasya Morkovkin. This book, a sort of modern fable, is the only one addressed to children written by the Siberian poet and literary critic Gennady Karpunin (1939-1998), famous for his works devoted to The Tale of Igor’s Campaign. The story, full of curious characters such as its hero Vasya, concentrates on the theme of nature, whose beauty must be preserved by humans, and it addresses issues of scientific and technological progress (placed in the Soviet context) and its interaction with nature and human beings. Karpunin’s education as physicist emerges in the scientific humor contained in the book. A character in the novel defines Meadow Saturday as follows: “It’s a major holiday of flowers and grass, a honey-harvest day. Do you hear bumblebees and bees buzzing? That means the clover has bloomed. Honey collected on this day is the best. It will cure any cold. This is the day of flood-meadows, the celebration of pastures. Take a look at the modest shepherd’s purse growing along the roadside, even it blooms on this wonderful day. This is a day of warm earth, fragrant chernozem, a field road, and a ringing lark. That’s what a Meadow Saturday is!” Read the original here.

intertextuality location Russia
Фомич

The inspector, Sidor Fomich Pozhilykh, to whom Ilya is addressing his letter of complaint. Patronymic: son of Foma (Thomas).

character
мало того что

Set expression: not only.

phraseologism
лугами обрамлена, и пожалуй что даже и заливными. И ливенка в них заливается

Alliteration (l, liv). Figura etymologica.

Аллитерация (л, лив). Этимологическая фигура речи.

sound stylistic device
ливенка

A diminutive form of ливень (torrential rain) and/or a livenka accordion, typically used in folk music from the town of Livny.

music Russia
мордобитий

Low: scuffle, punch-up.

register/style
извозчики с водовозами, но ведь и то зеваючи

Alliteration (z, v, ch).

Аллитерация (з, в, ч).

sound stylistic device
теньке

Diminutive: little shadow.

register/style
судари

Dated: sir.

register/style
кущи

Foliage or thicket. Or dated: tent, hut.

register/style
во здравие

Dated expression: to your heart’s content.

phraseologism
передряги

Colloquial: scrape, fight, trouble, mess.

register/style
Луговой Субботе

Emblematic of paradise. There is a Meadow Saturday located off the Irtysh River. A reference to Gennady Karpunin’s 1975 Meadow Saturday, or, The Believable and Unbelieable Adventures of Vasya Morkovkin. This book, a sort of modern fable, is the only one addressed to children written by the Siberian poet and literary critic Gennady Karpunin (1939-1998), famous for his works devoted to The Tale of Igor’s Campaign. The story, full of curious characters such as its hero Vasya, concentrates on the theme of nature, whose beauty must be preserved by humans, and it addresses issues of scientific and technological progress (placed in the Soviet context) and its interaction with nature and human beings. Karpunin’s education as physicist emerges in the scientific humor contained in the book. A character in the novel defines Meadow Saturday as follows: “It’s a major holiday of flowers and grass, a honey-harvest day. Do you hear bumblebees and bees buzzing? That means the clover has bloomed. Honey collected on this day is the best. It will cure any cold. This is the day of flood-meadows, the celebration of pastures. Take a look at the modest shepherd’s purse growing along the roadside, even it blooms on this wonderful day. This is a day of warm earth, fragrant chernozem, a field road, and a ringing lark. That’s what a Meadow Saturday is!” Read the original here.

intertextuality location Russia
в текущем существовании

Time flows unnaturally in the novel. One possible implication here is that Ilya has or will experience(d) other existences. Ashcheulova, linking Sokolov’s writing to that of Valentin Kataev (1897–1986), comments on this theme of “transformations and displacements in time and space” that “create an image of life and death that endlessly repeat” (“Tvorchestvo” 137). For more on Sokolov and Kataev, see Borden’s “Time, Backward!: Sasha Sokolov and Valentin Kataev” and “Toward a Postmodern ‘Bad’: Sasha Sokolov.”

time intertextuality
И завязал узелок. На галстуке

The reference to Albatrasov the sailor in the next sentence brings to mind Coleridge’s The Rime of the Ancient Mariner (read it here), in which a sailor is compelled to wear an albatross he has killed around his neck in penance. Addressing the latter subtext’s image of a bird wrapped around a sailor’s neck in penance, José Vergara writes, “Albatrosov is an embodiment of Ilya’s perceived betrayal by Orina, who it is said, sleeps with a number of sailors under the aforementioned overturned boat on the banks of the Volga, as well as guilt over his own actions. Ilya takes on his sorrow when he meets Albatrosov on a train after his separation from Orina. The avian-sailor thus serves to remind Ilya of the past he cannot escape. […] The anthropomorphized bird imagery, in this way, underscores Ilya’s lingering psychological trauma, both that which he himself caused and that which he received” (“Flap” 372). Animal-human motif.

intertextuality character motif
завязал узелок

Set expression: to try to remember something.

phraseologism
завязал узелок

Alliteration (z, l).

Аллитерация (з, л).

sound stylistic device
матрос-Альбатросовым

This name calls to mind two famous poetic “albatrosses”: Baudelaire’s (read it here) and Coleridge’s from The Rime of the Ancient Mariner (read it here). Addressing the latter subtext’s image of a bird wrapped around a sailor’s neck in penance, José Vergara writes, “Albatrosov is an embodiment of Ilya’s perceived betrayal by Orina, who it is said, sleeps with a number of sailors under the aforementioned overturned boat on the banks of the Volga, as well as guilt over his own actions. Ilya takes on his sorrow when he meets Albatrosov on a train after his separation from Orina. The avian-sailor thus serves to remind Ilya of the past he cannot escape. […] The anthropomorphized bird imagery, in this way, underscores Ilya’s lingering psychological trauma, both that which he himself caused and that which he received” (“Flap” 372). Animal-human motif. In a 2004 interview with Mario Caramitti, Sokolov comments on the suggestion of art predicting life in mysterious ways mentioning this specific character: “In the winter of 1978 I was living in Michigan and working on my second novel. One of the characters in the book, named Al’batrosov, has a background as a stoker on a ship. I was outlining the character by modeling him on my half-brother, a sailor, who was aboard a freighter at the time. Without thinking about the possible consequences, I made Albatrosov’s fate take a turn for the worse: an explosion in the engine room takes off his arm. When the book came out, I learned that in the same days that I was writing that episode my brother lost an arm to an accident. This is, I would say, the cruelest and most disconcerting example in my practice as a writer. But on the whole what I write often comes true. More often, unfortunately, than I would like, since I generally write about unpleasant things” (“Sokolov, il fabbro pellegrino della prosa russa” 12). The same concept is described by the author in his 1981 essay On Secret Tablets: “things described in fiction come true; fate suggests to the neglected in spirit solutions that it has already found. And it does not make any difference whether the master creates life myths or they create him: the text has been recorded in the same place, on secret tablets. And nothing else but fate will answer all the questions and decide what will remain – silence or the word. And, if necessary, it’ll rip out our sinful tongues” (7).

intertextuality character motif self-reference author
матрос-Альбатросовым

Alliteration.

Аллитерация.

sound stylistic device
всех наверх

Set expression: all hands on deck!

phraseologism
оставив буфетец-вагон при пиковом интересе

Set expression: to leave empty-handed. They do not pay.

explanatory phraseologism
полубак

A shift occurs here as Ilya moves from the train to ship. The upper deck on a sailing ship. Boat motif. Railroad theme.

motif theme
пароходец

Steamboat. Boat motif.

motif
дебаркадера

From the French “débarcadère.” A loading dock on a peer used for loading and unloading boats. Boat motif.

motif foreign
прокантовались

Low: to hang about, linger.

register/style
заторчали

Colloquial: to stick around.

register/style
тушканчики

Jerboa. Animal motif.

motif
Луговой Субботой

Emblematic of paradise. There is a Meadow Saturday located off the Irtysh River. A reference to Gennady Karpunin’s 1975 Meadow Saturday, or, The Believable and Unbelieable Adventures of Vasya Morkovkin. This book, a sort of modern fable, is the only one addressed to children written by the Siberian poet and literary critic Gennady Karpunin (1939-1998), famous for his works devoted to The Tale of Igor’s Campaign. The story, full of curious characters such as its hero Vasya, concentrates on the theme of nature, whose beauty must be preserved by humans, and it addresses issues of scientific and technological progress (placed in the Soviet context) and its interaction with nature and human beings. Karpunin’s education as physicist emerges in the scientific humor contained in the book. A character in the novel defines Meadow Saturday as follows: “It’s a major holiday of flowers and grass, a honey-harvest day. Do you hear bumblebees and bees buzzing? That means the clover has bloomed. Honey collected on this day is the best. It will cure any cold. This is the day of flood-meadows, the celebration of pastures. Take a look at the modest shepherd’s purse growing along the roadside, even it blooms on this wonderful day. This is a day of warm earth, fragrant chernozem, a field road, and a ringing lark. That’s what a Meadow Saturday is!” Read the original here.

location intertextuality Russia
Насшибали

Colloquial: to knock down, scrounge.

register/style
полтинник

Colloquial: half-ruble, 50 copeck piece.

register/style
курево

Low: tobacco.

register/style
почапали

Colloquial: to set off.

register/style
Городнище

The main setting of the novel: a fictional town on the banks of the Volga River. Also called Gorodnishchi. Derived from the words for town (gorod) and beggar (nishchii). It is the “town of beggars.” Olga Matich writes: “If School for Fools was written against the background of youth prose, Sokolov’s next novel Between Dog and Wolf may be read as the author’s response to village prose, the literary rage of the seventies” (“Sasha Sokolov” 310). Vadim Kreid observes that Gorodnishche, a barracks village of beggars and thieves, resembles an “Anti-Kitezh” (Kitezh being the legendary, mythical city in Russian folklore that only the pure-hearted will have the chance to reach). In Gorodnishche, however, thieves rob beggars, while beggars beg thieves (“Zaitil’shchina” 213). According to Johnson, the living dwell Gorodnishche, while the dead reside on the other side of the river, in Bydogoshch (“Sokolov’s Between Dog and Wolf and the Modernist Tradition” 209). Johnson also mentions a statement by Sokolov himself: “Sokolov reports that the name is a blend of the dissolute eighteen-century town of Gorodnya described by A. N. Radishchev in his Journey from Petersburg to Moscow and a nearby town called Gorodishche. Thus the time layers of the sixteenth century, the eighteenth century, and a mythic present are all superimposed upon each other – a characteristic technique in the novel” (217).

location setting intertextuality folklore theme
как жизнь молодая

Set expression: how’s life treating you?

phraseologism
смекаете

Colloquial: to imagine, to think.

register/style
Поторохами

Misspelled “potrokh,” offal.

language
чрево

Womb or belly. By eating offal, they fill themselves organs.

explanatory
смекаем

Colloquial: to imagine, to think.

register/style
быть и, избыточествуя недугами, бывать

Figura etymologica.

Этимологическая фигура речи.

stylistic device
В день дорожной получки, в аванца ль день

These words appear in a slightly different form above. Alexander Boguslawski explains: “This almost obsessive return to the story is not surprising — its continuation describes one of the most important events in the novel: Il’ia is caught and tied to the rails like Orina’s fox before; in an attempt to save him, Orina loses her life, while he loses his leg” (“How Sokolov’s 219).

intratextuality
получки

Low: payday, paycheck.

register/style
чекалдыкнул

Colloquial: to drink up. Alcohol theme.

register/style theme
шалмане

Colloquial: dive bar, joint.

register/style
пропойцами

Colloquial: drunk, drunkard. Alcohol theme.

register/style theme
и ревную в купине с железом наперевес

Ilya returns to his narrative about waiting in the bushes with a piece of iron to ambush Orina’s lovers.

intratextuality
купине

Dated: bush. Typically used in the phrase Неопалимая купина (Burning Bush). According to the Book of Exodus, Moses was given his charge to lead the Israelites out of Egypt at the Burning Bush.

religion bible intertextuality register/style
Как выскочу, как выпрыгну

A reference to the folk tale “The Fox, the Hare, and the Rooster.” Read the original here and an English translation here. Animal motif.

intertextuality motif
Как выскочу, как выпрыгну

Syntactic repetition.

Синтаксический параллелизм.

rhythm
секирой

Traditionally, a poleaxe. In modern usage, according to Dal’, it can be used a synonym for “axe” in general, though with a poetic undertone.

register/style
ага, уличаю, ага! А они — ату меня, ату

Rhythm through repetition.

Ритм через повтор.

rhythm
ату

A command used by a hunter to direct a dog to attack: tally ho! sick him!

phraseologism
ату

A command used by a hunter to direct a dog to attack: tally ho! sick him!

phraseologism
задрыга

Low: used to express displeasure with someone (e.g., “jerk”).

register/style
сякой

Colloquial: bad, foolish, ugly.

register/style
влет

Colloquial/hunting terminology: in flight.

register/style
попутали мы тебя, бляха-муха? Попутали, плачу, околыши, застукали, молоточки в петличках

Alliteration (t, kh, p, k, l, ch).

Аллитерация (т, х, р, к, л, ч).

sound stylistic device
бляха-муха

Set expression: holy hell! damnit! bollocks!

phraseologism
муха

Fly. Animal motif.

motif
околыши

Cap bands — a band that encircles a hat (as in a sailor cap). Ilya refers to the sailors/hunters metonymically.

explanatory
молоточки в петличках

Sokolov explains: “Orina’s comrades, with whom she has a kind of relationship, are, in Ilya’s words, students of railroad craft schools,” who “wore and still wear a specific uniform. On the cockades of their caps and on the button loops of their coats there is a technical emblem, a sign: a crossed hammer and a French wrench, which, if you do not look closely, may appear to be a second hammer” (personal communication, August 25, 2023). Railroad theme.

Соколов объясняет: “Товарищи Орины, с которыми у нее известного рода отношения, являются, по слову Ильи, учащими путевых ремеслух”, которые “носили и носят соответствующую форму. На кокардах их фуражек и на петлицах их кителей - техническая эмблема, знак: скрещенные молоток и французский гаечный ключ, который, если особенно не присматриваться, может показаться вторым молотком” (личная переписка, 25 августа 2023).

explanatory theme
ан

Low: but in fact, used to express a contrary fact/view.

register/style
Измордовали

Colloquial: to beat black and blue, beat the living snot out of someone.

register/style
сидорову

Set expression: драть как Сидорову козу (to beat like Sidor’s goat, whip someone’s ass, beat mercilessly). Of course, the phrase draws a direct link to Sidor Fomich Pozhilykh. Boguslawski adds: “Some scholars derive the origin of this phraseological expression from the Arabic “sadar kaza (perhaps brought to Russia by the Mongols), a sentence that often involved punishment by beating with clubs” (“Annotations” 253). Animal motif.

motif phraseologism foreign
измызгали

Colloquial: to make dirty all over.

register/style
серому шлаку

This gray slag is also mentioned in Orina’s account of this event (R219/E121–122).

intratextuality
мурлом

Dialectical: same as морда (mug, face).

register/style
мизгирики

Spider (Lycosa singoriensis). Animal motif.

motif
принайтовливают

Sailing term, meaning to fix something by a knot. Boat motif.

language motif
неуемные

Low: powerfully, in a vigorous manner.

register/style
Льзя

Dated/low/dialectical: same as можно (permitted, may).

register/style
Льзя ли, гаврики, я страдал, что́ я — лисенок вам, что ли, какой

Blurred narratives: Here, Ilya is tied to the tracks and will lose his leg. Elsewhere, in chapter 10, it is Orina’s fox who is tied to the rails and killed (R219/E121–122). Animal-human motif.

intratextuality motif
гаврики

Low: unserious person, idler.

register/style
лисенок

Fox. Animal motif. Olga Matich reads Sokolov’s novel as an extended response to Boris Pilnyak’s short story “Mother Earth” (1927), as it shares confusion between a wolf and a fox, a character name Arina, and a setting on the Upper Volga, among other similarities (“Sasha Sokolov” 312–313). Read the original here. D. Barton Johnson adds: “The prose models that served for Shkola dlia durakov were obviously unsuitable for the setting and events of Mezhdu sobakoi i volkom. Apart from the obvious sections of literary parody in which Gogol’ is flagrantly apparent, it is difficult to point to direct stylistic sources. The first that comes to mind is the Andrei Belyi of Serebrianyi golub’ (The Silver Dove) with its (partial) peasant setting and its elaborate sound instrumentation. Sokolov, however, denies having read Belyi at this point. A more likely literary context is afforded by modernist Boris Pilniak […] Pilniak had recently been rehabilitated and his work was easily available. Sokolov recalls reading his work in 1975. Something of the same dark violence and fractured language is also to be found in the work of Pilniak’s adherent Andrei Platonov whose work was being rediscovered and republished in the late 1960s” (“Background Notes” (336–337).

motif intertextuality
грабками

Hands or fingers.

explanatory
пригнетают

Dated: to press down, oppress.

register/style
валенок

Traditional Russian winter felt boots. D.B. Johnson has identified more than twenty different types of shoes across Sokolov’s three novels: “bashmaki, botforty, boty, botinki (polubotinki), cheboty, chizmy, chubury, galoshi (kaloshi), gety, ichigi, kedy, klogi, lapti, mokrostupy, obuvi (obuvki), sapogi, sandalii, tapochki (polutapochki), shlepantsy, shtiblety, tapti, tufli, valenki. The list may easily be extended with appurtenances such as socks, stockings, footcloths, gaiters, skates, crutches, and artificial legs” (“The Galoshes Manifesto” 156). Regarding Between Dog and Wolf, he notes that Ilya’s last name immediately evokes Cinderella’s vair slippers. Johnson observes that “the footwear motif is Sokolov’s tribute, both conscious and unconscious, to the tradition in Russian literature represented by his predecessors – Ivan Bunin and Valentin Kataev” (179). In an interview with A. and N. Voronel’, Sokolov calls Bunin, along with Gogol, his “contemporaries, collaborators along a chain, older masters” (Voroneli, “Ia khochu” 184). Shoe motif.

motif Russia intertextuality
снегуру Норвегии

Ice skate from Norway. Mentioned in chapter 6 (R192/E76). According to Sokolov, “Norway was once considered the best in the production of iceskates. In Russia, cross-country skates from Norway were valued, and they were called Norways: long, high-speed. Another common name for cross-country skates is knives. Ilya compares the train with a Norwegian knife, that is, with a long skate. Skates with a wide skid and steeply curved socks are called snowshoes: because they can be ridden not only on ice, but also on packed snow, on roads, and pedestrian paths” (personal communication, August 21, 2023). An echo of the character Pavel Petrovich Norvegov from Sokolov’s first novel, A School for Fools.

explanatory intratextuality self-reference
пассатижами

Linesman’s pliers.

explanatory
слиняли

Colloquial: to skip, dash out, get the hell out of somewhere.

register/style
бояки

Colloquial: wimp, chicken.

register/style
скорого

Скорый поезд — express train. Railroad theme. Alternatively, this may be interpreted as an ellipsis for “konets”: жду скорого конца (i.e., death).

explanatory theme
стал ушедшее освежать

Ilya begins to “refresh his past,” meaning his life flashes before his eyes and he considers what he’s done with his life.

explanatory time
на этот раз

Again, the implication here is that Ilya has or will experience(d) other lives.

time theme
Так прикинул и эдак, а ничего, главным образом, характеристика

Ilya reckons that he’s lived an ordinary life and been a decent man.

explanatory
прикинул

Colloquial: to estimate, add up.

register/style
дромом, что говорится, не грабил

Sokolov points out that this expression can be linked with a famous line by Sergei Esenin: “Не злодей я и не грабил лесом” (I am not a villain nor a thief) (personal communication, July 29, 2023). Read the entire poem here and its English translation here.

Соколов подсказывает, что это выражение можно понять через ссылку на знаменитую строку Сергея Есенина: “Не злодей я и не грабил лесом” (личная переписка, 29 июля 2023). Стихотворение можно читать здесь.

intertextuality
сыпались сверху огарки небесных дел

When it was already dark, under the stars.

time
Оря

Diminutive form of Orina. Orina, along with her variants, is the primary female character in the novel. In a sense, she is the only female figure in Between Dog and Wolf. As D.B. Johnson summarizes, the “promiscuous heroine Orina-Mariia is a train dispatcher, a princess in her dispatcher’s tower, who entertains her coworkers in her bed. Some of her orgiastic trysts take place near the train tracks to which her lovers tie her meddling husband Il’ia. Orina, in at least one time dimension, is killed by a train as she belatedly tries to save Il’ia who loses his leg” (“Twilight Cosmos” 647). Ilya is obsessed with this woman, and this passion “is the ultimate source of the woes that befall Il’ia, the itinerant grinder. It is his passion for the faithless slut Orina that brings about his misfortunes: the loss of his leg, his wandering life as a drunken grinder, and the grisly events that lead to his death” (643). Orina, alternatively called Maria, exists in the book also in another version, as ta dama, that dame, “a mysterious woman who appears along the river seeking Il’ia and, failing to find him, takes away a new lover each time […]. Her chance lovers return days later, sexually depleted and without interest in life. They usually die by their own hand” (645). In this figure (which embodies “virtually all female figures in the book,” D.B. Johnson, “Sasha Sokolov’s Between Dog and Wolf and the Modernist Tradition” 211), Sokolov merges two of his major literary themes: sex and death. Thus, Orina, Maria, that dame (ta dama, ta devochka, ta bobylka, ta babulya — all linked by the demonstrative “ta”), “Life Everlastin,” and death in general make up a unique polymorphic character. Smith notices that this female figure “does not appear at all in the verse. The episode of the sexual encounter between this figure and the sailors, which reoccurs obsessively in the prose, is correspondingly absent from the verse passages” (333). Olga Matich suggests the existence of a literary subtext for Sokolov’s novel: “Pilniak’s lesser known story Mother Earth (Mat’ syra zemlia 1927) about the violent confrontation between a naive young Bolshevik and an archaic Volga peasant community at the time of the Civil War. It is a kind of love story between the city-bred Bolshevik and the horse-tanner and young earth mother Arina, impaled by the Cossacks in one of the story’s many violence-ridden episodes. A variation on the Scythian juxtaposition of nature and culture, the story also depicts Arina’s maternal love for a fox cub, whom she tries to tame, thinking it is a wolf” (“Sasha Sokolov and His Literary Context” 312). The name Orina may also carry an echo of Pushkin’s famous nurse Arina Rodionovna (Toker 353). Mario Caramitti proposes three recurring hypostases of ta dama across Sokolov’s novels: a first hypostasis is that of a “mysterious woman carrying an obscure menace and/or sexual temptation”; a second hypostasis is that of an “apparently better defined and concrete woman being the object of desire for the main character”; and the third hypostasis is that of a “child-woman, often mentally retarded, often victim of violences, who touches upon a slightly more sublimated erotic sphere” (“Amore e morte” 114). Caramitti also adds that in the novel one of ta dama’s victims, before or after committing suicide, explicitly calls her “вечная жизнь” (Life Everlastin): “it is precisely in the coitus with eternity, in a region of oblivion that it is most difficult to place on this side or on the other side of the Lethe, that the male protagonist finds the widest surface of contact with this protean female entity of now vast symbolic implications” (118). Among Orina’s many lovers and among the men who take advantage of her, there is also Yakov, her son, who is in a way “re-enacting the role of the lame Oedipus” (Johnson, “Sasha Sokolov’s Between Dog and Wolf and the Modernist Tradition” 212). In chapter 14, Orina’s patronymic is said to be “Ignat’evna” (daughter of Ignatii): the name Ignatii possibly comes from the Latin “ignis” (fire) (R258/E190). Given that Orina is depicted here through her lust, such a patronymic seems apt. Her last name is said to be alternatively Neklina and Paklina (Spacklin, in translation): “You were called around the barracks Orina Neklina, and to whom do you belong now, to what kind of, let’s suppose, Spacklin, ah?” (R246/E169). On the border with Ukraine, close to Mariupol’ and to Chekhov’s hometown Taganrog, there is Rostov district named Neklinovsky. Paklia and paklina are regional terms indicating different things: a left-handed person, an unhandy and clumsy person, a bony hand, a piece of hemp or coarse fiber, messy hair. The terms паклен and неклен are named for the Tatar maple (note the slight differences in the spelling between the tree names and Orina’s surnames: Неклина, Паклина). As Sokolov explains, “Apparently, the author of the Notes and Ilya know or have heard about a man named Paklin. Ilya says that Arina’s last name was Neklina, probably after one of her men. And now, years later, Ilya assumes, she lives with someone else, whose last name suggests to him the tree’s other name” (personal communication, July 7, 2023).

character intertextuality intratextuality theme
Лисом

Fox.Animal motif.

motif
Лисом бедненьким величала Илью несносного, проволоки откручивать принялась — и колотун ее бил

Blurred narratives: Here, Ilya is tied to the tracks and will lose his leg. Elsewhere, in chapter 10, it is Orina’s fox who is tied to the rails and killed (R219/E121–122). Animal-human motif.

intratextuality motif
величала

Poetic/low: to call, glorify, name.

register/style
Илью

Ilya refers to himself in the third person.

explanatory
колотун ее бил

Set expression: колотун бьёт (to get the shivers, shake like a leaf).

phraseologism
скорый

Скорый поезд — express train. Railroad theme. Alternatively, this may be interpreted as an ellipsis for “konets”: жду скорого конца (i.e., death).

explanatory theme
Оря

Diminutive form of Orina. Orina, along with her variants, is the primary female character in the novel. In a sense, she is the only female figure in Between Dog and Wolf. As D.B. Johnson summarizes, the “promiscuous heroine Orina-Mariia is a train dispatcher, a princess in her dispatcher’s tower, who entertains her coworkers in her bed. Some of her orgiastic trysts take place near the train tracks to which her lovers tie her meddling husband Il’ia. Orina, in at least one time dimension, is killed by a train as she belatedly tries to save Il’ia who loses his leg” (“Twilight Cosmos” 647). Ilya is obsessed with this woman, and this passion “is the ultimate source of the woes that befall Il’ia, the itinerant grinder. It is his passion for the faithless slut Orina that brings about his misfortunes: the loss of his leg, his wandering life as a drunken grinder, and the grisly events that lead to his death” (643). Orina, alternatively called Maria, exists in the book also in another version, as ta dama, that dame, “a mysterious woman who appears along the river seeking Il’ia and, failing to find him, takes away a new lover each time […]. Her chance lovers return days later, sexually depleted and without interest in life. They usually die by their own hand” (645). In this figure (which embodies “virtually all female figures in the book,” D.B. Johnson, “Sasha Sokolov’s Between Dog and Wolf and the Modernist Tradition” 211), Sokolov merges two of his major literary themes: sex and death. Thus, Orina, Maria, that dame (ta dama, ta devochka, ta bobylka, ta babulya — all linked by the demonstrative “ta”), “Life Everlastin,” and death in general make up a unique polymorphic character. Smith notices that this female figure “does not appear at all in the verse. The episode of the sexual encounter between this figure and the sailors, which reoccurs obsessively in the prose, is correspondingly absent from the verse passages” (333). Olga Matich suggests the existence of a literary subtext for Sokolov’s novel: “Pilniak’s lesser known story Mother Earth (Mat’ syra zemlia 1927) about the violent confrontation between a naive young Bolshevik and an archaic Volga peasant community at the time of the Civil War. It is a kind of love story between the city-bred Bolshevik and the horse-tanner and young earth mother Arina, impaled by the Cossacks in one of the story’s many violence-ridden episodes. A variation on the Scythian juxtaposition of nature and culture, the story also depicts Arina’s maternal love for a fox cub, whom she tries to tame, thinking it is a wolf” (“Sasha Sokolov and His Literary Context” 312). The name Orina may also carry an echo of Pushkin’s famous nurse Arina Rodionovna (Toker 353). Mario Caramitti proposes three recurring hypostases of ta dama across Sokolov’s novels: a first hypostasis is that of a “mysterious woman carrying an obscure menace and/or sexual temptation”; a second hypostasis is that of an “apparently better defined and concrete woman being the object of desire for the main character”; and the third hypostasis is that of a “child-woman, often mentally retarded, often victim of violences, who touches upon a slightly more sublimated erotic sphere” (“Amore e morte” 114). Caramitti also adds that in the novel one of ta dama’s victims, before or after committing suicide, explicitly calls her “вечная жизнь” (Life Everlastin): “it is precisely in the coitus with eternity, in a region of oblivion that it is most difficult to place on this side or on the other side of the Lethe, that the male protagonist finds the widest surface of contact with this protean female entity of now vast symbolic implications” (118). Among Orina’s many lovers and among the men who take advantage of her, there is also Yakov, her son, who is in a way “re-enacting the role of the lame Oedipus” (Johnson, “Sasha Sokolov’s Between Dog and Wolf and the Modernist Tradition” 212). In chapter 14, Orina’s patronymic is said to be “Ignat’evna” (daughter of Ignatii): the name Ignatii possibly comes from the Latin “ignis” (fire) (R258/E190). Given that Orina is depicted here through her lust, such a patronymic seems apt. Her last name is said to be alternatively Neklina and Paklina (Spacklin, in translation): “You were called around the barracks Orina Neklina, and to whom do you belong now, to what kind of, let’s suppose, Spacklin, ah?” (R246/E169). On the border with Ukraine, close to Mariupol’ and to Chekhov’s hometown Taganrog, there is Rostov district named Neklinovsky. Paklia and paklina are regional terms indicating different things: a left-handed person, an unhandy and clumsy person, a bony hand, a piece of hemp or coarse fiber, messy hair. The terms паклен and неклен are named for the Tatar maple (note the slight differences in the spelling between the tree names and Orina’s surnames: Неклина, Паклина). As Sokolov explains, “Apparently, the author of the Notes and Ilya know or have heard about a man named Paklin. Ilya says that Arina’s last name was Neklina, probably after one of her men. And now, years later, Ilya assumes, she lives with someone else, whose last name suggests to him the tree’s other name” (personal communication, July 7, 2023).

character intertextuality intratextuality theme
дусенька

Colloquial: sweetie, honey.

register/style
околышами

Cap bands — a band that encircles a hat (as in a sailor cap). Ilya refers to the sailors/hunters metonymically.

explanatory
вместях

Dialectal: together.

register/style
шпингалетами

Colloquial: kid, youth, lad, teenager.

register/style
было мне с тобой как земле с травой

Sokolov points out that “that is my phrase, stylized as a saying” (personal communication, July 29, 2023).

Соколов подчеркивает, что “это моя фраза, стилизованная под поговорку” (личная переписка, 29 июля 2023).

language
было мне с тобой как земле с травой

Kh3 + Ya2. Rhyme.

Х3 + Я2. Рифма.

metrical pattern rhyme
запамятуй

Dated/low: to forget.

register/style
минуло, зажило, зубы острые, хвост долгий

Syntactic repetition.

Синтаксический параллелизм.

rhythm
зубы острые, хвост долгий

Barbara Heldt observes of this scene in chapters 10 and 14: “The words about teeth and tail are repeated with the different that predlinnyi becoms dolgii, like the long memory of the event” (281). Orina likens her alleged bad behavior and excesses to animal qualities: sharp teeth and a long tail. On memory, D. Barton Johnson writes, “Since all times seem to exist more or less concurrently and variant versions of events exist both in fact and in potentia, memory in Sokolov’s works merges with imagination. The first person narrators not so much retell the past but imagine at different times variant pasts and futures. For Sokolov’s characters, memory is imagination, and imagination, the only reality” (“Sasha Sokolov’s Twilight Cosmos” 643). Animal-human motif.

motif explanatory theme intratextuality
лиса

Fox.Animal motif.

motif
смахивал

Colloquial: to resemble, look like a bit.

register/style
У сороки боли, твердит, у вороны боли, говорит, у Ильи заживи, заговоривает

A reference to the expression “У сороки боли, у вороны боли, а у (имя) всё заживи” (“The magpie is hurt, the crow is hurt, but (name) will feel all better”), used to comfort children who have hurt themselves. This reference also appears in Note XI (R196-197/E84–86), which begs the question: which came first — Yakov’s poem or Ilya’s letter? Animal motif.

motif intratextuality phraseologism structure
У сороки боли, твердит, у вороны боли, говорит, у Ильи заживи, заговоривает

Rhythm. Alliteration (r, t, z, v).

Ритм. Аллитерация (р, т, з, в).

rhythm sound stylistic device
сороки

Magpie. The magpie is traditionally known as a thieving bird: “Regarded almost universally as a symbol of ill-omen,” the “magpie’s incorrigible addiction to pilfering has no doubt contributed to its unpopularity” (Rowland, Birds 103–104). Animal motif.

motif folklore
вороны

Crow. Crows, like ravens, are often associated with death. Animal motif.

motif
Ильи

Ilya is Between Dog and Wolf’s protagonist and the author of what he calls the Zaitil’shchina, a long letter with epic traits (starting from its title) addressed to Inspector Pozhilykh in which he comments on the theft of his crutches (he has only one leg) and, more generally, describes life along the Volga River. Johnson defines Ilya’s letter as “semiliterate ramblings,” aptly suggesting the style and register the reader will encounter in the novel (“Sokolov’s Between Dog and Wolf and the Modernist Tradition” 212). However, this character expresses at the same time a highly poetic and imaginative gaze. Ilya frequently associates himself with the biblical prophet Elijah, a figure folklorically linked with thunderstorms and which in Slavic tradition acquired some of the characteristics of the pagan God of the sky and thunder, Perun. Ilya is closely related to other key characters of the novel: he describes his troubled relationship with Orina (alternatively called Maria and the Dame) with whom he has a son; in encountering Yakov (the focus of several chapters), he suggests the possibility of being his father. The Oedipal plot resulting from this triangle has been noted by scholars, such as Johnson, who writes that “the game warden Iakov lusts for his mother (reincarnate as a mentally defective girl) and kills his father-all without being aware of the identity of either” (“Twilight Cosmos” 644).

character folklore intertextuality
рванулся, рванулся

Rhythm through repetition.

Ритм через повтор.

rhythm
Налетел, искромсал, горячий, руки-ноги по белу свету поразметал

The train runs over Ilya and cuts off his leg. Railroad theme.

explanatory theme
искромсал

Colloquial: to mangle, hack up.

register/style
по белу свету

Set expression: all over.

phraseologism
Прибыло полку доходяг

Set expression: нашего полку прибыло (to grow larger). According to Boguslawski, a paraphrase of a line from the folk song “A my proso seiali” (We were sowing millet) (“Annotations” 254). Read it here. Listen it here.

phraseologism intertextuality music
Прибыло полку доходяг, принимай, командир, пополнение

That is, there’s another person close to death who needs medical attention. Prepare the hospital.

explanatory
доходяг

Low: goner, last legger, someone close to death.

register/style
сего

Archaism: this.

archaism register/style
Подплывает врачина в шапочке

A narrative inversion: Ilya is now back at the hospital.

explanatory
подруга

That is, Orina.

character explanatory
с ней худшее

The doctor claims that Orina has died.

explanatory
Костоправу — ступай полечись-ка сам

A reference to Luke 4:23 (Boguslawski, “Annotations” 4:23).

bible intertextuality religion
ка

Colloquial: suffix added to imperatives to express urgency.

register/style
ишь

Colloquial: just look!

register/style
бузил

Colloquial: to raise a ruckus, make a din.

register/style
шлепанцы

Slippers. Shoe motif. D.B. Johnson has identified more than twenty different types of shoes across Sokolov’s three novels: “bashmaki, botforty, boty, botinki (polubotinki), cheboty, chizmy, chubury, galoshi (kaloshi), gety, ichigi, kedy, klogi, lapti, mokrostupy, obuvi (obuvki), sapogi, sandalii, tapochki (polutapochki), shlepantsy, shtiblety, tapti, tufli, valenki. The list may easily be extended with appurtenances such as socks, stockings, footcloths, gaiters, skates, crutches, and artificial legs” (“The Galoshes Manifesto” 156). Regarding Between Dog and Wolf, he notes that Ilya’s last name immediately evokes Cinderella’s vair slippers. Johnson observes that “the footwear motif is Sokolov’s tribute, both conscious and unconscious, to the tradition in Russian literature represented by his predecessors – Ivan Bunin and Valentin Kataev” (179). In an interview with A. and N. Voronel’, Sokolov calls Bunin, along with Gogol, his “contemporaries, collaborators along a chain, older masters” (Voroneli, “Ia khochu” 184). Shoe motif.

motif intertextuality
хорохорился

Colloquial: to swagger, boast.

register/style
Гурий

Gury is one of the hunters living by the river. His death is described in detail in chapter 14: during an ice race, “a few verstas before the turn, Gury began gainin and the whipper-in fallin behind, but Gury aimed slightly more to the right than he should and fell into a polynya, an ice hole in the area of the fairway. […] he plopped in and right away got sucked under the ice.” Since his body cannot be found until spring, his funeral is organized “without his factual presence” (R260/E196). This episode is already briefly alluded to in chapter 1: “He was the one that adored scrapin and rollin over the slick on his sharps, which additionally resulted in us losin a client, and the undertakers, in contrast, findin one” (R150/E3).

character intratextuality
гонки гонять

Alliteration.

Аллитерация.

stylistic device sound
обшаркаю

Low: to wear out, rub out.

register/style
поставили на кон

Set expression: поставить на кон (to gamble, put skin the game). Animal motif.

phraseologism motif
поставили на кон вина

The hunters start arguing and set up a bet with alcohol as the prize. Alcohol theme.

theme explanatory
Столковались

Colloquial: to see eye to eye, agree.

register/style
обладая слепой дальнорукостью, как сейчас я их вижу

Ilya claims he can see this race in his mind clear as day.

explanatory
дальнорукостью

Neologism: дальнозоркость (far-sightedness) + близорукость (near-sightedness) = blindness.

neologism
тот в латаном, тот в перелатанном

Their clothes are patched and mismatched, in general disarray. Clothing motif.

motif explanatory
рвали когти

Set expression: рвать когти (cut and run, shove off).

phraseologism
ноздря в ноздрю

Set expression: neck and neck.

phraseologism
ноздря в ноздрю

Figura etymologica.

Этимологическая фигура речи.

sound stylistic device
портомойни

Dated: washhouse, laundry.

register/style
Слободской

In ancient Russia, a sloboda referred to a settlement found in Povolzhye, Central Russia, Belarus, or Ukraine. The term is derived from the word for freedom. These tax-free settlements came to an end in the early eighteenth century when the practice was abolished and the settlements became regular villages. Often these suburbs were eventually subsumed by nearby cities. Today, sloboda refers to a rural locality in various oblasts. Sokolov attests that a Sloboda can be found by the Volga River in Konakovskii raion (personal communication, June 7, 2023).

Russia location
протоки

Small river or canal.

explanatory
Кабацкого

An island named Kabatsky exists by Dudinka on the Enisey river, while Zarya is a peninsula in Arctic Siberia. The former is mentioned in chapter 10 (R223/E128).

location Russia intratextuality
И понеслись коньками резать лед

A reference to chapter 4 line 42 of Alexander Pushkin’s novel-in-verse Eugene Onegin (Ostanin 107). Read the original here and an English translation here.

intertextuality
вивучий

Low: whirling, like during a blizzard.

Просторечье: вьющийся, как во время метели или вьюги.

register/style
столько видели, сколько слышали

Syntactic repetition.

Синтаксический параллелизм.

rhythm
скромном будущем

Ilya uses “скромном” (modest) to modify the future. The sense is “the near future.”

time
сподобятся, может быть, поклевать

Indeed, in the next line, Gury will fall into an ice hole and become food for the fish.

explanatory
молись, рыбка большая и маленькая

A variation on a line from the folktale “Sister Fox and Gray Wolf”: “Ловись, рыбка, большая и маленькая!” (Catch, little fish, big and small!” Read the original here and an English translation here. Animal motif.

intertextuality motif
Гурий

Gury is one of the hunters living by the river. His death is described in detail in chapter 14: during an ice race, “a few verstas before the turn, Gury began gainin and the whipper-in fallin behind, but Gury aimed slightly more to the right than he should and fell into a polynya, an ice hole in the area of the fairway. […] he plopped in and right away got sucked under the ice.” Since his body cannot be found until spring, his funeral is organized “without his factual presence” (R260/E196). This episode is already briefly alluded to in chapter 1: “He was the one that adored scrapin and rollin over the slick on his sharps, which additionally resulted in us losin a client, and the undertakers, in contrast, findin one” (R150/E3).

character intratextuality
верст

An obsolete Russian unit of length equal to approximately .66 miles or 1.07 km.

Russia explanatory
принял Гурий немного правее, чем следовало, и угодил в полынью, в промоину в районе фарватера

In Note XXXI, Yakov reports that Gury dies from grief (R269/E209).

intratextuality
Гурий

Gury is one of the hunters living by the river. His death is described in detail in chapter 14: during an ice race, “a few verstas before the turn, Gury began gainin and the whipper-in fallin behind, but Gury aimed slightly more to the right than he should and fell into a polynya, an ice hole in the area of the fairway. […] he plopped in and right away got sucked under the ice.” Since his body cannot be found until spring, his funeral is organized “without his factual presence” (R260/E196). This episode is already briefly alluded to in chapter 1: “He was the one that adored scrapin and rollin over the slick on his sharps, which additionally resulted in us losin a client, and the undertakers, in contrast, findin one” (R150/E3).

character intratextuality
полынью

A hole in the ice of the frozen river.

explanatory
фарватера

Fairway — the part of the river that is navigable.

explanatory
ни при каких кондициях

A variant of the set expression ни при каких обстоятельствах (under no circumstances).

phraseologism
тетерь

A clumsy, stupid person, but also a black grouse. Animal motif.

motif
Гурия

Gury is one of the hunters living by the river. His death is described in detail in chapter 14: during an ice race, “a few verstas before the turn, Gury began gainin and the whipper-in fallin behind, but Gury aimed slightly more to the right than he should and fell into a polynya, an ice hole in the area of the fairway. […] he plopped in and right away got sucked under the ice.” Since his body cannot be found until spring, his funeral is organized “without his factual presence” (R260/E196). This episode is already briefly alluded to in chapter 1: “He was the one that adored scrapin and rollin over the slick on his sharps, which additionally resulted in us losin a client, and the undertakers, in contrast, findin one” (R150/E3).

character intratextuality
разнюнился

Low: to begin to cry.

register/style
Тризну

A wake or funeral feast in ancient Slavic tradition held before cremation. Gury’s wake is mentioned in chapter 14 (R241/E128).

explanatory intratextuality
волкобою

Sokolov explains: “in the old days, a hunter who beat wolves from a horse with a brush” (personal communication, June 7, 2023).

Соколов объясняет: “в старину охотник, бьющий Волков с лошади кистенем” (личное сообщение, 7 июня 2023).

explanatory language
без фактического его присутствия

That is, with his body missing.

explanatory
ребятня ли его бреднем вытянет

Ostanin notes a connection to Alexander Pushkin’s 1828 poem “The Drowned Man” (107). Read the original here and an English translation here.

intertextuality
бреднем

Dragnet — used to drag the bottom of a body of water in fishing.

explanatory
недосуг

Colloquial: lack of time.

time register/style
она, мадама эта, всецело прекрасная

Orina, the Dame. A reference to Alexander Blok’s 1901–1902 Verses on a Beautiful Lady. Read the original collection of poems here. Orina, along with her variants, is the primary female character in the novel. In a sense, she is the only female figure in Between Dog and Wolf. As D.B. Johnson summarizes, the “promiscuous heroine Orina-Mariia is a train dispatcher, a princess in her dispatcher’s tower, who entertains her coworkers in her bed. Some of her orgiastic trysts take place near the train tracks to which her lovers tie her meddling husband Il’ia. Orina, in at least one time dimension, is killed by a train as she belatedly tries to save Il’ia who loses his leg” (“Twilight Cosmos” 647). Ilya is obsessed with this woman, and this passion “is the ultimate source of the woes that befall Il’ia, the itinerant grinder. It is his passion for the faithless slut Orina that brings about his misfortunes: the loss of his leg, his wandering life as a drunken grinder, and the grisly events that lead to his death” (643). Orina, alternatively called Maria, exists in the book also in another version, as ta dama, that dame, “a mysterious woman who appears along the river seeking Il’ia and, failing to find him, takes away a new lover each time […]. Her chance lovers return days later, sexually depleted and without interest in life. They usually die by their own hand” (645). In this figure (which embodies “virtually all female figures in the book,” D.B. Johnson, “Sasha Sokolov’s Between Dog and Wolf and the Modernist Tradition” 211), Sokolov merges two of his major literary themes: sex and death. Thus, Orina, Maria, that dame (ta dama, ta devochka, ta bobylka, ta babulya — all linked by the demonstrative “ta”), “Life Everlastin,” and death in general make up a unique polymorphic character. Smith notices that this female figure “does not appear at all in the verse. The episode of the sexual encounter between this figure and the sailors, which reoccurs obsessively in the prose, is correspondingly absent from the verse passages” (333). Olga Matich suggests the existence of a literary subtext for Sokolov’s novel: “Pilniak’s lesser known story Mother Earth (Mat’ syra zemlia 1927) about the violent confrontation between a naive young Bolshevik and an archaic Volga peasant community at the time of the Civil War. It is a kind of love story between the city-bred Bolshevik and the horse-tanner and young earth mother Arina, impaled by the Cossacks in one of the story’s many violence-ridden episodes. A variation on the Scythian juxtaposition of nature and culture, the story also depicts Arina’s maternal love for a fox cub, whom she tries to tame, thinking it is a wolf” (“Sasha Sokolov and His Literary Context” 312). The name Orina may also carry an echo of Pushkin’s famous nurse Arina Rodionovna (Toker 353). Mario Caramitti proposes three recurring hypostases of ta dama across Sokolov’s novels: a first hypostasis is that of a “mysterious woman carrying an obscure menace and/or sexual temptation”; a second hypostasis is that of an “apparently better defined and concrete woman being the object of desire for the main character”; and the third hypostasis is that of a “child-woman, often mentally retarded, often victim of violences, who touches upon a slightly more sublimated erotic sphere” (“Amore e morte” 114). Caramitti also adds that in the novel one of ta dama’s victims, before or after committing suicide, explicitly calls her “вечная жизнь” (Life Everlastin): “it is precisely in the coitus with eternity, in a region of oblivion that it is most difficult to place on this side or on the other side of the Lethe, that the male protagonist finds the widest surface of contact with this protean female entity of now vast symbolic implications” (118). Among Orina’s many lovers and among the men who take advantage of her, there is also Yakov, her son, who is in a way “re-enacting the role of the lame Oedipus” (Johnson, “Sasha Sokolov’s Between Dog and Wolf and the Modernist Tradition” 212). In chapter 14, Orina’s patronymic is said to be “Ignat’evna” (daughter of Ignatii): the name Ignatii possibly comes from the Latin “ignis” (fire) (R258/E190). Given that Orina is depicted here through her lust, such a patronymic seems apt. Her last name is said to be alternatively Neklina and Paklina (Spacklin, in translation): “You were called around the barracks Orina Neklina, and to whom do you belong now, to what kind of, let’s suppose, Spacklin, ah?” (R246/E169). On the border with Ukraine, close to Mariupol’ and to Chekhov’s hometown Taganrog, there is Rostov district named Neklinovsky. Paklia and paklina are regional terms indicating different things: a left-handed person, an unhandy and clumsy person, a bony hand, a piece of hemp or coarse fiber, messy hair. The terms паклен and неклен are named for the Tatar maple (note the slight differences in the spelling between the tree names and Orina’s surnames: Неклина, Паклина). As Sokolov explains, “Apparently, the author of the Notes and Ilya know or have heard about a man named Paklin. Ilya says that Arina’s last name was Neklina, probably after one of her men. And now, years later, Ilya assumes, she lives with someone else, whose last name suggests to him the tree’s other name” (personal communication, July 7, 2023).

character intertextuality intratextuality theme
Василию Карабану

Vasily Karaban appears as the messenger who brings news of the phenomenon of Orina in the form of Everlastin’ Life or that Dame to the Volga community in which the novel is set. He is her first victim and, while he remains alive, he has shriveled up. His occupation, as Sokolov confirms, is unclear (personal communication, July 7, 2023). The name Karaban is of Turkic origin and can either be a surname or a nickname, a shortened version of Karabanov. It means “black mole” from “kara” (black) and “ban” (mole, birthmark). According to Turkic folklore, a black mole is a sign of happiness. Therefore, in the context of Between Dog and Wolf, it may be an ironic marker given Karaban’s fate (“Proiskhozhdenie familii Karabanova”).

character folklore foreign
Вечная Жизня

Orina, along with her variants, is the primary female character in the novel. In a sense, she is the only female figure in Between Dog and Wolf. As D.B. Johnson summarizes, the “promiscuous heroine Orina-Mariia is a train dispatcher, a princess in her dispatcher’s tower, who entertains her coworkers in her bed. Some of her orgiastic trysts take place near the train tracks to which her lovers tie her meddling husband Il’ia. Orina, in at least one time dimension, is killed by a train as she belatedly tries to save Il’ia who loses his leg” (“Twilight Cosmos” 647). Ilya is obsessed with this woman, and this passion “is the ultimate source of the woes that befall Il’ia, the itinerant grinder. It is his passion for the faithless slut Orina that brings about his misfortunes: the loss of his leg, his wandering life as a drunken grinder, and the grisly events that lead to his death” (643). Orina, alternatively called Maria, exists in the book also in another version, as ta dama, that dame, “a mysterious woman who appears along the river seeking Il’ia and, failing to find him, takes away a new lover each time […]. Her chance lovers return days later, sexually depleted and without interest in life. They usually die by their own hand” (645). In this figure (which embodies “virtually all female figures in the book,” D.B. Johnson, “Sasha Sokolov’s Between Dog and Wolf and the Modernist Tradition” 211), Sokolov merges two of his major literary themes: sex and death. Thus, Orina, Maria, that dame (ta dama, ta devochka, ta bobylka, ta babulya — all linked by the demonstrative “ta”), “Life Everlastin,” and death in general make up a unique polymorphic character. Smith notices that this female figure “does not appear at all in the verse. The episode of the sexual encounter between this figure and the sailors, which reoccurs obsessively in the prose, is correspondingly absent from the verse passages” (333). Olga Matich suggests the existence of a literary subtext for Sokolov’s novel: “Pilniak’s lesser known story Mother Earth (Mat’ syra zemlia 1927) about the violent confrontation between a naive young Bolshevik and an archaic Volga peasant community at the time of the Civil War. It is a kind of love story between the city-bred Bolshevik and the horse-tanner and young earth mother Arina, impaled by the Cossacks in one of the story’s many violence-ridden episodes. A variation on the Scythian juxtaposition of nature and culture, the story also depicts Arina’s maternal love for a fox cub, whom she tries to tame, thinking it is a wolf” (“Sasha Sokolov and His Literary Context” 312). The name Orina may also carry an echo of Pushkin’s famous nurse Arina Rodionovna (Toker 353). Mario Caramitti proposes three recurring hypostases of ta dama across Sokolov’s novels: a first hypostasis is that of a “mysterious woman carrying an obscure menace and/or sexual temptation”; a second hypostasis is that of an “apparently better defined and concrete woman being the object of desire for the main character”; and the third hypostasis is that of a “child-woman, often mentally retarded, often victim of violences, who touches upon a slightly more sublimated erotic sphere” (“Amore e morte” 114). Caramitti also adds that in the novel one of ta dama’s victims, before or after committing suicide, explicitly calls her “вечная жизнь” (Life Everlastin): “it is precisely in the coitus with eternity, in a region of oblivion that it is most difficult to place on this side or on the other side of the Lethe, that the male protagonist finds the widest surface of contact with this protean female entity of now vast symbolic implications” (118). Among Orina’s many lovers and among the men who take advantage of her, there is also Yakov, her son, who is in a way “re-enacting the role of the lame Oedipus” (Johnson, “Sasha Sokolov’s Between Dog and Wolf and the Modernist Tradition” 212). In chapter 14, Orina’s patronymic is said to be “Ignat’evna” (daughter of Ignatii): the name Ignatii possibly comes from the Latin “ignis” (fire) (R258/E190). Given that Orina is depicted here through her lust, such a patronymic seems apt. Her last name is said to be alternatively Neklina and Paklina (Spacklin, in translation): “You were called around the barracks Orina Neklina, and to whom do you belong now, to what kind of, let’s suppose, Spacklin, ah?” (R246/E169). On the border with Ukraine, close to Mariupol’ and to Chekhov’s hometown Taganrog, there is Rostov district named Neklinovsky. Paklia and paklina are regional terms indicating different things: a left-handed person, an unhandy and clumsy person, a bony hand, a piece of hemp or coarse fiber, messy hair. The terms паклен and неклен are named for the Tatar maple (note the slight differences in the spelling between the tree names and Orina’s surnames: Неклина, Паклина). As Sokolov explains, “Apparently, the author of the Notes and Ilya know or have heard about a man named Paklin. Ilya says that Arina’s last name was Neklina, probably after one of her men. And now, years later, Ilya assumes, she lives with someone else, whose last name suggests to him the tree’s other name” (personal communication, July 7, 2023).

character theme intertextuality intratextuality
раздор, недород

Alliteration.

Аллитерация.

sound stylistic device
недород

Regional: poor harvest.

register/style
пас

French: not.

foreign
встреваю

Low: to interfere.

register/style
Вам

The inspector, Sidor Fomich Pozhilykh, to whom Ilya is addressing his letter of complaint.

character explanatory
Вам

The inspector, Sidor Fomich Pozhilykh, to whom Ilya is addressing his letter of complaint.

character explanatory
Илью

Ilya refers to himself in the third person.

explanatory
горохового шута

Set expression: fool, buffoon, laughingstock.

phraseologism
с какой немыслимой стати

Set expression: с какой стати (for what reason, what for, why in the world).

phraseologism
очкариков

Colloquial: four-eyes (someone who wears glasses).

register/style
мозги мне запудрили

Set expression: пудрить мозги (to throw dust in one’s eyes, deceive, trick).

phraseologism
не среди ли вас тот, которого

The Dame (Orina) is searching for Ilya.

explanatory
по уши втюрившись

Set expression: втюриться по уши (to fall head over heels in love).

phraseologism
побывать с тобой каждый не прочь

A reference to Nikolai Nekrasov’s 1848 poem “Troika” (Boguslawski, “Annotations” 254). Read the original here and an English translation here.

intertextuality
не прочь

Set expression: to not mind, not be adverse to doing something.

phraseologism
Гурий

Gury is one of the hunters living by the river. His death is described in detail in chapter 14: during an ice race, “a few verstas before the turn, Gury began gainin and the whipper-in fallin behind, but Gury aimed slightly more to the right than he should and fell into a polynya, an ice hole in the area of the fairway. […] he plopped in and right away got sucked under the ice.” Since his body cannot be found until spring, his funeral is organized “without his factual presence” (R260/E196). This episode is already briefly alluded to in chapter 1: “He was the one that adored scrapin and rollin over the slick on his sharps, which additionally resulted in us losin a client, and the undertakers, in contrast, findin one” (R150/E3).

character intratextuality
туда же

It means that he is dead.

То есть он умер.

explanatory
чудь

A historical term used to describe Estonians and Finnish peoples.

explanatory
Ненаглядная

Colloquial: beloved, beautiful.

register/style
сей

Archaism: this.

archaism register/style
трен
