From French, traine.

foreign
очутилось

Colloquial: to find oneself.

register/style
боком. Беспокоюсь

Alliteration.

Аллитерация.

sound stylistic device
Оря

Diminutive form of Orina. Orina, along with her variants, is the primary female character in the novel. In a sense, she is the only female figure in Between Dog and Wolf. As D.B. Johnson summarizes, the “promiscuous heroine Orina-Mariia is a train dispatcher, a princess in her dispatcher’s tower, who entertains her coworkers in her bed. Some of her orgiastic trysts take place near the train tracks to which her lovers tie her meddling husband Il’ia. Orina, in at least one time dimension, is killed by a train as she belatedly tries to save Il’ia who loses his leg” (“Twilight Cosmos” 647). Ilya is obsessed with this woman, and this passion “is the ultimate source of the woes that befall Il’ia, the itinerant grinder. It is his passion for the faithless slut Orina that brings about his misfortunes: the loss of his leg, his wandering life as a drunken grinder, and the grisly events that lead to his death” (643). Orina, alternatively called Maria, exists in the book also in another version, as ta dama, that dame, “a mysterious woman who appears along the river seeking Il’ia and, failing to find him, takes away a new lover each time […]. Her chance lovers return days later, sexually depleted and without interest in life. They usually die by their own hand” (645). In this figure (which embodies “virtually all female figures in the book,” D.B. Johnson, “Sasha Sokolov’s Between Dog and Wolf and the Modernist Tradition” 211), Sokolov merges two of his major literary themes: sex and death. Thus, Orina, Maria, that dame (ta dama, ta devochka, ta bobylka, ta babulya — all linked by the demonstrative “ta”), “Life Everlastin,” and death in general make up a unique polymorphic character. Smith notices that this female figure “does not appear at all in the verse. The episode of the sexual encounter between this figure and the sailors, which reoccurs obsessively in the prose, is correspondingly absent from the verse passages” (333). Olga Matich suggests the existence of a literary subtext for Sokolov’s novel: “Pilniak’s lesser known story Mother Earth (Mat’ syra zemlia 1927) about the violent confrontation between a naive young Bolshevik and an archaic Volga peasant community at the time of the Civil War. It is a kind of love story between the city-bred Bolshevik and the horse-tanner and young earth mother Arina, impaled by the Cossacks in one of the story’s many violence-ridden episodes. A variation on the Scythian juxtaposition of nature and culture, the story also depicts Arina’s maternal love for a fox cub, whom she tries to tame, thinking it is a wolf” (“Sasha Sokolov and His Literary Context” 312). The name Orina may also carry an echo of Pushkin’s famous nurse Arina Rodionovna (Toker 353). Mario Caramitti proposes three recurring hypostases of ta dama across Sokolov’s novels: a first hypostasis is that of a “mysterious woman carrying an obscure menace and/or sexual temptation”; a second hypostasis is that of an “apparently better defined and concrete woman being the object of desire for the main character”; and the third hypostasis is that of a “child-woman, often mentally retarded, often victim of violences, who touches upon a slightly more sublimated erotic sphere” (“Amore e morte” 114). Caramitti also adds that in the novel one of ta dama’s victims, before or after committing suicide, explicitly calls her “вечная жизнь” (Life Everlastin): “it is precisely in the coitus with eternity, in a region of oblivion that it is most difficult to place on this side or on the other side of the Lethe, that the male protagonist finds the widest surface of contact with this protean female entity of now vast symbolic implications” (118). Among Orina’s many lovers and among the men who take advantage of her, there is also Yakov, her son, who is in a way “re-enacting the role of the lame Oedipus” (Johnson, “Sasha Sokolov’s Between Dog and Wolf and the Modernist Tradition” 212). In chapter 14, Orina’s patronymic is said to be “Ignat’evna” (daughter of Ignatii): the name Ignatii possibly comes from the Latin “ignis” (fire) (R258/E190). Given that Orina is depicted here through her lust, such a patronymic seems apt. Her last name is said to be alternatively Neklina and Paklina (Spacklin, in translation): “You were called around the barracks Orina Neklina, and to whom do you belong now, to what kind of, let’s suppose, Spacklin, ah?” (R246/E169). On the border with Ukraine, close to Mariupol’ and to Chekhov’s hometown Taganrog, there is Rostov district named Neklinovsky. Paklia and paklina are regional terms indicating different things: a left-handed person, an unhandy and clumsy person, a bony hand, a piece of hemp or coarse fiber, messy hair. The terms паклен and неклен are named for the Tatar maple (note the slight differences in the spelling between the tree names and Orina’s surnames: Неклина, Паклина). As Sokolov explains, “Apparently, the author of the Notes and Ilya know or have heard about a man named Paklin. Ilya says that Arina’s last name was Neklina, probably after one of her men. And now, years later, Ilya assumes, she lives with someone else, whose last name suggests to him the tree’s other name” (personal communication, July 7, 2023).

character intertextuality intratextuality theme
Фомич

The inspector, Sidor Fomich Pozhilykh, to whom Ilya is addressing his letter of complaint. Patronymic: son of Foma (Thomas).

character
тоскуючи

Old Church Slavonic form: to pine, grieve.

register/style archaism
приковылять

Colloquial: to hobble, limp. Ilya is missing a leg.

explanatory register/style
Крылобыл

Krylobyl is a key character dwelling in the world of the dead (living on the other shore of the Itil’ river). It is not surprising given his “speaking name” formed by the words “krylo” (wing) and “byl” (was, used to be). He is a hypostasis of an angelic creature guiding Ilya in his wanderings and suggesting to him ideas and reflections: in chapter 4 it will be Krylobyl who advances the idea of the origin of the “zhe” letter; it is Krylobyl in this chapter who Ilya describes as a “know-it-all” who “instructs,” the one “whom I trust, whom I praise.” In a sense, Krylobyl is Ilya’s Virgil or, even, Beatrice in his wandering across this very special Inferno, Purgatorio, and Paradiso. Toward the end of the novel, he will be addressed by the narrator in chapter 16 (R275/E220) and by Ilya in chapter 17 as “Fedot Fyodorov” (R279/E227).

character intertextuality intratextuality
кому доверяю, кого хвалю

Syntactic repetition.

Синтаксический параллелизм.

rhythm
Крылобыл

Krylobyl is a key character dwelling in the world of the dead (living on the other shore of the Itil’ river). It is not surprising given his “speaking name” formed by the words “krylo” (wing) and “byl” (was, used to be). He is a hypostasis of an angelic creature guiding Ilya in his wanderings and suggesting to him ideas and reflections: in chapter 4 it will be Krylobyl who advances the idea of the origin of the “zhe” letter; it is Krylobyl in this chapter who Ilya describes as a “know-it-all” who “instructs,” the one “whom I trust, whom I praise.” In a sense, Krylobyl is Ilya’s Virgil or, even, Beatrice in his wandering across this very special Inferno, Purgatorio, and Paradiso. Toward the end of the novel, he will be addressed by the narrator in chapter 16 (R275/E220) and by Ilya in chapter 17 as “Fedot Fyodorov” (R279/E227).

character intertextuality intratextuality
свет очей собственных

A variation on Psalm 13:3 — a call for understanding.

bible religion intertextuality
очей

Archaism: eyes.

archaism register/style
верните калеке калеково

Krylobyl commands the hunters to return Ilya’s crutches to him. A reference to Matthew 22:21 (Ostanin 107).

explanatory bible religion intertextuality
калеке калеково

A name given to blind wanderers who sing spiritual poems. Originally, the word did not refer to disabled or crippled beggars, as it does now, but rather to wanderers who visited holy places and sang songs. The term is derived from the Latin caligae, Since these wanderers often lived off of alms in the towns they visited (and occasionally settled in), the term took on the meaning of a disabled person who does the same in its modern usage. (Miller 27–28) Also mentioned in chapter 8 (R209/E103), chapter 9 (R214/E112), and chapter 10 (R223/E129). D.B. Johnson has identified more than twenty different types of shoes across Sokolov’s three novels: “bashmaki, botforty, boty, botinki (polubotinki), cheboty, chizmy, chubury, galoshi (kaloshi), gety, ichigi, kedy, klogi, lapti, mokrostupy, obuvi (obuvki), sapogi, sandalii, tapochki (polutapochki), shlepantsy, shtiblety, tapti, tufli, valenki. The list may easily be extended with appurtenances such as socks, stockings, footcloths, gaiters, skates, crutches, and artificial legs” (“The Galoshes Manifesto” 156). Regarding Between Dog and Wolf, he notes that Ilya’s last name immediately evokes Cinderella’s vair slippers. Johnson observes that “the footwear motif is Sokolov’s tribute, both conscious and unconscious, to the tradition in Russian literature represented by his predecessors – Ivan Bunin and Valentin Kataev” (179). In an interview with A. and N. Voronel’, Sokolov calls Bunin, along with Gogol, his “contemporaries, collaborators along a chain, older masters” (Voroneli, “Ia khochu” 184). Shoe motif.

foreign intratextuality motif Russia intertextuality
калеке калеково

Figura etymologica.

Этимологическая фигура речи.

sound stylistic device
искомого след простыл

The crutches can’t be found.

explanatory
след простыл

Set expression: to vanish into thin air, the trail went cold.

phraseologism
Может, пропито, может, кинуто за ракитов куст, может, просто уплыло вниз

Rhythm through repetition.

Ритм через повтор.

rhythm
кинуто за ракитов куст

Ostanin notes this is a reference to the Russian epic tale “Volga and Mikula Selyaninovich,” in which the hero discards his plow behind a willow (107). Read the original here.

intertextuality
ракитов куст

This type of willow is often mentioned in Russian folklore. According to the myth, it grew on the very first rock on Earth, which was thrown out of the sea by a fish. Birds and animals living on this bush boast magic powers and can foresee the future. In literature, we find it in Nekrasov’s Who is Happy in Russia? (3rd part, ch. 5): the heroine laments her bitter fate while sitting on this bush. Read the original here and its English translation here. Plant motif. This bush was already mentioned in chapter 1.

Этот вид ивы часто упоминается в русском фольклоре. Согласно мифу, он вырос на самом первом камне на Земле, который выбросила из моря рыба. Птицы и животные, живущие на этом кусте, обладают магической силой и могут предвидеть будущее. В литературе мы находим его в романе Некрасова Кому на Руси жить хорошо? (3-я часть, гл. 5): героиня думает о своей горькой судьбе, сидя на этом кусте. Читайте текст здесь. Мотив растений. Этот куст упоминается снова в главе 14.

folklore motif intertextuality intratextuality
Илье

Ilya here refers to himself in the third person. Ilya is Between Dog and Wolf’s protagonist and the author of what he calls the Zaitil’shchina, a long letter with epic traits (starting from its title) addressed to Inspector Pozhilykh in which he comments on the theft of his crutches (he has only one leg) and, more generally, describes life along the Volga River. Johnson defines Ilya’s letter as “semiliterate ramblings,” aptly suggesting the style and register the reader will encounter in the novel (“Sokolov’s Between Dog and Wolf and the Modernist Tradition” 212). However, this character expresses at the same time a highly poetic and imaginative gaze. Ilya frequently associates himself with the biblical prophet Elijah, a figure folklorically linked with thunderstorms and which in Slavic tradition acquired some of the characteristics of the pagan God of the sky and thunder, Perun. Ilya is closely related to other key characters of the novel: he describes his troubled relationship with Orina (alternatively called Maria and the Dame) with whom he has a son; in encountering Yakov (the focus of several chapters), he suggests the possibility of being his father. The Oedipal plot resulting from this triangle has been noted by scholars, such as Johnson, who writes that “the game warden Iakov lusts for his mother (reincarnate as a mentally defective girl) and kills his father-all without being aware of the identity of either” (“Twilight Cosmos” 644).

explanatory character folklore intertextuality
что за беда

Set expression: what does it matter, makes no difference.

phraseologism
Илье

Ilya here refers to himself in the third person. Ilya is Between Dog and Wolf’s protagonist and the author of what he calls the Zaitil’shchina, a long letter with epic traits (starting from its title) addressed to Inspector Pozhilykh in which he comments on the theft of his crutches (he has only one leg) and, more generally, describes life along the Volga River. Johnson defines Ilya’s letter as “semiliterate ramblings,” aptly suggesting the style and register the reader will encounter in the novel (“Sokolov’s Between Dog and Wolf and the Modernist Tradition” 212). However, this character expresses at the same time a highly poetic and imaginative gaze. Ilya frequently associates himself with the biblical prophet Elijah, a figure folklorically linked with thunderstorms and which in Slavic tradition acquired some of the characteristics of the pagan God of the sky and thunder, Perun. Ilya is closely related to other key characters of the novel: he describes his troubled relationship with Orina (alternatively called Maria and the Dame) with whom he has a son; in encountering Yakov (the focus of several chapters), he suggests the possibility of being his father. The Oedipal plot resulting from this triangle has been noted by scholars, such as Johnson, who writes that “the game warden Iakov lusts for his mother (reincarnate as a mentally defective girl) and kills his father-all without being aware of the identity of either” (“Twilight Cosmos” 644).

explanatory character intertextuality folklore
вынь да положь

Set expression, meaning that what is required must be done without delay and at any cost.

phraseologism
Заторчал, заторчал

Colloquial: to get stuck.

register/style
Заторчал, заторчал

Repetition.

Повтор.

rhythm sound
Слобода

In ancient Russia, a sloboda referred to a settlement found in Povolzhye, Central Russia, Belarus, or Ukraine. The term is derived from the word for freedom. These tax-free settlements came to an end in the early eighteenth century when the practice was abolished and the settlements became regular villages. Often these suburbs were eventually subsumed by nearby cities. Today, sloboda refers to a rural locality in various oblasts. Sokolov attests that a Sloboda can be found by the Volga River in Konakovskii raion (personal communication, June 7, 2023).

Russia location
Вышелбауши

A reference to the expression “Выше лба уши не растут” meaning that one has limits to what they can do. First mentioned in chapter 8 (R207/E101).

intratextuality phraseologism
Городнище

The main setting of the novel: a fictional town on the banks of the Volga River. Also called Gorodnishchi. Derived from the words for town (gorod) and beggar (nishchii). It is the “town of beggars.” Olga Matich writes: “If School for Fools was written against the background of youth prose, Sokolov’s next novel Between Dog and Wolf may be read as the author’s response to village prose, the literary rage of the seventies” (“Sasha Sokolov” 310). Vadim Kreid observes that Gorodnishche, a barracks village of beggars and thieves, resembles an “Anti-Kitezh” (Kitezh being the legendary, mythical city in Russian folklore that only the pure-hearted will have the chance to reach). In Gorodnishche, however, thieves rob beggars, while beggars beg thieves (“Zaitil’shchina” 213). According to Johnson, the living dwell Gorodnishche, while the dead reside on the other side of the river, in Bydogoshch (“Sokolov’s Between Dog and Wolf and the Modernist Tradition” 209). Johnson also mentions a statement by Sokolov himself: “Sokolov reports that the name is a blend of the dissolute eighteen-century town of Gorodnya described by A. N. Radishchev in his Journey from Petersburg to Moscow and a nearby town called Gorodishche. Thus the time layers of the sixteenth century, the eighteenth century, and a mythic present are all superimposed upon each other – a characteristic technique in the novel” (217).

location setting intertextuality theme folklore
на блевотине пес

An allusion to 2 Peter 2:22 or Proverbs 26:11. The meaning is that the unfaithful will return to their sinful life. Animal motif.

motif bible religion intertextuality
Полюбуйтесь, к слову сказать, сколько их возле нашего заведения в оцепленьи дежурствует

Elena Kravchenko writes: “[W. H.] Auden’s ekphrasis, especially his references to The Census and The Slaughter, is scattered throughout Sokolov’s text. Shimmering through its portrayal of the desolate state of humanity, its images of frozen river and skating, the ekphrasis re-emerges in Il’ia’s ‘allegory’ of existence: in what appears to be an elaboration of Auden’s dogs that ‘go on with their doggy life’” (The Prose 63).

intertextuality
к слову сказать

Set expression: by the way, as an aside, as it so happens.

phraseologism
выдвиженцев

A worker who has been promoted. Associated with the Soviet economic regime. In other words, the hunters wait around for someone who is looking to celebrate. Alcohol theme.

explanatory theme
эти псы собачьи катяхи свои леденелые глодать принимаются да языки показывают

That is, the hunters begin behaving like dogs. Animal-human motif.

motif explanatory
катяхи

Colloquial: turd.

register/style
макароны по-флотски

“Macaroni Navy-style” — a dish made of pasta (usually macaroni), stewed ground meet, onions, salt, and pepper. Served in the navy but also became very popular after WWII during times of poverty.

explanatory
гривенник

Ten-kopeck piece.

explanatory
ждуны

Colloquial: waiter, someone who waits.

register/style
слопают

Low: to scarf up.

register/style
хмелеют

Low: to drink. Alcohol theme.

theme register/style
прямо на людях

In front of people, publicly.

explanatory
торной

Dated: beaten, well-trodden.

register/style
иноходью

Gait. Often used to describe animals’ (horses’) movement. Animal-human motif.

motif
тошниловке

Colloquial: a drinking hole, that which causes nausea. Alcohol theme.

theme
Ау

Colloquial: hello?, an exclamation to get attention.

register/style
скроется с глаз

Set expression: скрыться с глаз (to fade from view, lay low, disappear).

phraseologism
на самом юру

Set expression: in plain view.

phraseologism
детвора

Colloquial: kids (a group of), children.

register/style
стопарю

Low: same as стопка (shot glass). Alcohol theme.

theme register/style
Илье

Ilya here refers to himself in the third person. Ilya is Between Dog and Wolf’s protagonist and the author of what he calls the Zaitil’shchina, a long letter with epic traits (starting from its title) addressed to Inspector Pozhilykh in which he comments on the theft of his crutches (he has only one leg) and, more generally, describes life along the Volga River. Johnson defines Ilya’s letter as “semiliterate ramblings,” aptly suggesting the style and register the reader will encounter in the novel (“Sokolov’s Between Dog and Wolf and the Modernist Tradition” 212). However, this character expresses at the same time a highly poetic and imaginative gaze. Ilya frequently associates himself with the biblical prophet Elijah, a figure folklorically linked with thunderstorms and which in Slavic tradition acquired some of the characteristics of the pagan God of the sky and thunder, Perun. Ilya is closely related to other key characters of the novel: he describes his troubled relationship with Orina (alternatively called Maria and the Dame) with whom he has a son; in encountering Yakov (the focus of several chapters), he suggests the possibility of being his father. The Oedipal plot resulting from this triangle has been noted by scholars, such as Johnson, who writes that “the game warden Iakov lusts for his mother (reincarnate as a mentally defective girl) and kills his father-all without being aware of the identity of either” (“Twilight Cosmos” 644).

explanatory character folklore intertextuality
памятуя

Dated: to remember, recall.

register/style
прикровенном

Dated: secret, hidden.

register/style
сижу, маломошть, под соснами, соседок в соблазн

Alliteration (s).

Аллитерация (с).

sound stylistic device
маломошть

Archaism: weak person, enfeebled.

register/style archaism
соснами

Pine. Plant motif.

motif
в соблазн ввожу

A reference to Matthew 16:23.

religion bible intertextuality
чело

High: forehead.

register/style
дятел

Woodpecker. The woodpecker has traditionally played roles “as the god-sent bird in the ancient sacred grove; as the bird who […] cared for Romulus and Remus, and as the oracular bird of Mars, god of war” (Rowland, Birds 180). It is also said that the woodpecker can knock out anything blocking its nest in a tree. While there doesn’t seem to be any such obstruction here, Ilya implies that the bird has knocked down the snow that falls on his head. Animal motif.

motif explanatory symbol
достукаешься

To get what one deserves but also to finish knocking (like a woodpecker).

language
удод

The hoopoe appears several times throughout the novel, mostly in Yakov’s poems (R167, 168, 169, 233, 236, 262, 280/E31, 32, 33, 34, 35, 145, 149, 199). José Vergara writes: “the hoopoe plays a key role in the story of Tereus in Ovid’s Metamorphoses. In this myth, the Thracian king rapes Philomela, his wife Procne’s sister, and cuts out her tongue to keep the secret. After Philomela manages to convey to Procne what happened, the sisters conspire to kill the latter’s son, Itys, and feed him to Tereus. Upon learning of their actions, Tereus in turn seeks them out, but before he can enact his revenge, the gods transform them all into birds: Procne into a swallow, Philomela into a nightingale, Tereus into a hoopoe. According to the folklore, the hoopoe’s hooting call is said to mean “where, where” in Greek – Tereus’s plea as he searches for his displaced family” (“Flap” 364–365). Throughout the novel, Ilya is associated with the hoopoe in that he also looks for his missing family. Therefore, Ilya reenacts this plot as he seeks out Orina and their son, Yakov. “He is displaced, like Tereus, in his various transformations and peregrinations, pursuing his idealized family,” Vergara continues, “but constantly mired by the imagery he uses and that is used to describe him” (“Flap” 366). Animal-human motif.

motif intratextuality foreign intertextuality
Сбили, сбили

Repetition.

Повтор.

rhythm sound
сбили с панталыку

Set expression: сбить с панталыку (to throw into confusion, drive crazy).

phraseologism
Илью

Ilya here refers to himself in the third person. Ilya is Between Dog and Wolf’s protagonist and the author of what he calls the Zaitil’shchina, a long letter with epic traits (starting from its title) addressed to Inspector Pozhilykh in which he comments on the theft of his crutches (he has only one leg) and, more generally, describes life along the Volga River. Johnson defines Ilya’s letter as “semiliterate ramblings,” aptly suggesting the style and register the reader will encounter in the novel (“Sokolov’s Between Dog and Wolf and the Modernist Tradition” 212). However, this character expresses at the same time a highly poetic and imaginative gaze. Ilya frequently associates himself with the biblical prophet Elijah, a figure folklorically linked with thunderstorms and which in Slavic tradition acquired some of the characteristics of the pagan God of the sky and thunder, Perun. Ilya is closely related to other key characters of the novel: he describes his troubled relationship with Orina (alternatively called Maria and the Dame) with whom he has a son; in encountering Yakov (the focus of several chapters), he suggests the possibility of being his father. The Oedipal plot resulting from this triangle has been noted by scholars, such as Johnson, who writes that “the game warden Iakov lusts for his mother (reincarnate as a mentally defective girl) and kills his father-all without being aware of the identity of either” (“Twilight Cosmos” 644).

character folklore intertextuality explanatory
сбоку припеку

Set expression: сбоку припёка (entirely out of place, unnecessary).

phraseologism
субботами

Ilya’s fascination with Meadow Saturday (above). Emblematic of paradise. There is a Meadow Saturday located off the Irtysh River. A reference to Gennady Karpunin’s 1975 Meadow Saturday, or, The Believable and Unbelieable Adventures of Vasya Morkovkin. This book, a sort of modern fable, is the only one addressed to children written by the Siberian poet and literary critic Gennady Karpunin (1939-1998), famous for his works devoted to The Tale of Igor’s Campaign. The story, full of curious characters such as its hero Vasya, concentrates on the theme of nature, whose beauty must be preserved by humans, and it addresses issues of scientific and technological progress (placed in the Soviet context) and its interaction with nature and human beings. Karpunin’s education as physicist emerges in the scientific humor contained in the book. A character in the novel defines Meadow Saturday as follows: “It’s a major holiday of flowers and grass, a honey-harvest day. Do you hear bumblebees and bees buzzing? That means the clover has bloomed. Honey collected on this day is the best. It will cure any cold. This is the day of flood-meadows, the celebration of pastures. Take a look at the modest shepherd’s purse growing along the roadside, even it blooms on this wonderful day. This is a day of warm earth, fragrant chernozem, a field road, and a ringing lark. That’s what a Meadow Saturday is!” Read the original here.

intertextuality location explanatory
Фомич

The inspector, Sidor Fomich Pozhilykh, to whom Ilya is addressing his letter of complaint. Patronymic: son of Foma (Thomas).

character
небытия вкусить нам не терпится

Ilya longes for death.

explanatory
побаиваться

Colloquial: to fear, be afraid.

register/style
перемелемся

From the expression “Всё перемелется — мука будет” (Everything will get milled over; there will be flour). An expression of the milling theme in the novel. Sokolov will play with this expression and the difference between му́ка (torment) and мукá (flour) several times.

От выражения: “Всё перемелется — мука будет”. Выражение темы мельницы в романе. Соколов неоднократно обыгрывает это выражение и созвучность муки (страдания) и муки (хлебопекарной).

theme phraseologism intratextuality language
Итиле

The Tatar name of the river Volga. The title of Ilya’s letter “Zaitil’shchina” is derived from this version of the river’s name. Ostanin also suggests a sound link between the rivers Itil’ and Lethe (Leta), the river of oblivion and forgetting, which also plays a major role in Sokolov’s first novel, A School for Fools (10).

location foreign language setting
людин

Ukrainian: person.

foreign
чужанин

Poetic/low: stranger, newcomer, alien.

register/style
околачивался

Colloquial: to kick one’s heels.

register/style
Джынжэрэла

Another variation on Ilya’s unusual last name, which is printed in more than ten different versions in the book. It carries allusions to Cinderella (see L. Toker’s essay, “Gamesman’s Sketches (Found in a Bottle),” CASS 21.3-4: 356).

Вновь, необычная фамилия Илья (которая встречается более 10 раз и в других графических-орфографических вариантах дальше в тексте). Намекается на сказку Золушки (по-английски Cinderella; cм. L. Toker, “Gamesman’s Sketches (Found in a Bottle),” CASS 21.3-4: 356).

intertextuality character
винище

A derogatory term for wine. Alcohol theme.

register/style theme
бобылок

Colloquial: an unmarried, lonely (peasant) woman. She will make several appearances throughout the novel and is associated with Orina.

Разговорное: незамужняя, одинокая женщина-крестьянка. Она встречается далее в романе и обычно ассоциируется с Ориной.

character register/style intratextuality
лобзал

Dated, poetic: to kiss.

register/style
промысел в отхожий

Seasonal work. Often handicrafts. Perhaps a reference to Mikhail Zoshchenko’s 1924 story “Seasonal Work.” Read the original here.

explanatory intertextuality
Крылобыл

Krylobyl is a key character dwelling in the world of the dead (living on the other shore of the Itil’ river). It is not surprising given his “speaking name” formed by the words “krylo” (wing) and “byl” (was, used to be). He is a hypostasis of an angelic creature guiding Ilya in his wanderings and suggesting to him ideas and reflections: in chapter 4 it will be Krylobyl who advances the idea of the origin of the “zhe” letter; it is Krylobyl in this chapter who Ilya describes as a “know-it-all” who “instructs,” the one “whom I trust, whom I praise.” In a sense, Krylobyl is Ilya’s Virgil or, even, Beatrice in his wandering across this very special Inferno, Purgatorio, and Paradiso. Toward the end of the novel, he will be addressed by the narrator in chapter 16 (R275/E220) and by Ilya in chapter 17 as “Fedot Fyodorov” (R279/E227).

character intertextuality intratextuality
пьянь кругом, пьян приходит, и пьян уходит

Syntactic repetition.

Синтаксический параллелизм.

rhythm
пьян приходит, и пьян уходит

A play on Ecclesiastes 1-4 (Ostanin 108). Alcohol theme.

intertextuality bible religion theme
все как есть

Set expression: no bones about it, warts and all.

phraseologism
ей по бакену

A variation of the set expression “komu po barabanu”: whatever, do not give a hoot about something.

phraseologism
безвылазно

Colloquial: without leaving.

register/style
кубарэ

Unusual (and mockingly foreign) word. It may derive from the word “kubar’”, informally used by students of the naval academy to define a ship cabin.

Необычное (и мнимо-иностранное) слово, наверное от разговорного морского термина “кубарь”, каюта.

foreign neologism location
кукуем

To cuckoo. Here: to survive, live on. Animal-human motif.

motif
жизнь наша вечная

Biblical phrasing, for example, John 10:28–30. Orina, along with her variants, is the primary female character in the novel. In a sense, she is the only female figure in Between Dog and Wolf. As D.B. Johnson summarizes, the “promiscuous heroine Orina-Mariia is a train dispatcher, a princess in her dispatcher’s tower, who entertains her coworkers in her bed. Some of her orgiastic trysts take place near the train tracks to which her lovers tie her meddling husband Il’ia. Orina, in at least one time dimension, is killed by a train as she belatedly tries to save Il’ia who loses his leg” (“Twilight Cosmos” 647). Ilya is obsessed with this woman, and this passion “is the ultimate source of the woes that befall Il’ia, the itinerant grinder. It is his passion for the faithless slut Orina that brings about his misfortunes: the loss of his leg, his wandering life as a drunken grinder, and the grisly events that lead to his death” (643). Orina, alternatively called Maria, exists in the book also in another version, as ta dama, that dame, “a mysterious woman who appears along the river seeking Il’ia and, failing to find him, takes away a new lover each time […]. Her chance lovers return days later, sexually depleted and without interest in life. They usually die by their own hand” (645). In this figure (which embodies “virtually all female figures in the book,” D.B. Johnson, “Sasha Sokolov’s Between Dog and Wolf and the Modernist Tradition” 211), Sokolov merges two of his major literary themes: sex and death. Thus, Orina, Maria, that dame (ta dama, ta devochka, ta bobylka, ta babulya — all linked by the demonstrative “ta”), “Life Everlastin,” and death in general make up a unique polymorphic character. Smith notices that this female figure “does not appear at all in the verse. The episode of the sexual encounter between this figure and the sailors, which reoccurs obsessively in the prose, is correspondingly absent from the verse passages” (333). Olga Matich suggests the existence of a literary subtext for Sokolov’s novel: “Pilniak’s lesser known story Mother Earth (Mat’ syra zemlia 1927) about the violent confrontation between a naive young Bolshevik and an archaic Volga peasant community at the time of the Civil War. It is a kind of love story between the city-bred Bolshevik and the horse-tanner and young earth mother Arina, impaled by the Cossacks in one of the story’s many violence-ridden episodes. A variation on the Scythian juxtaposition of nature and culture, the story also depicts Arina’s maternal love for a fox cub, whom she tries to tame, thinking it is a wolf” (“Sasha Sokolov and His Literary Context” 312). The name Orina may also carry an echo of Pushkin’s famous nurse Arina Rodionovna (Toker 353). Mario Caramitti proposes three recurring hypostases of ta dama across Sokolov’s novels: a first hypostasis is that of a “mysterious woman carrying an obscure menace and/or sexual temptation”; a second hypostasis is that of an “apparently better defined and concrete woman being the object of desire for the main character”; and the third hypostasis is that of a “child-woman, often mentally retarded, often victim of violences, who touches upon a slightly more sublimated erotic sphere” (“Amore e morte” 114). Caramitti also adds that in the novel one of ta dama’s victims, before or after committing suicide, explicitly calls her “вечная жизнь” (Life Everlastin): “it is precisely in the coitus with eternity, in a region of oblivion that it is most difficult to place on this side or on the other side of the Lethe, that the male protagonist finds the widest surface of contact with this protean female entity of now vast symbolic implications” (118). Among Orina’s many lovers and among the men who take advantage of her, there is also Yakov, her son, who is in a way “re-enacting the role of the lame Oedipus” (Johnson, “Sasha Sokolov’s Between Dog and Wolf and the Modernist Tradition” 212). In chapter 14, Orina’s patronymic is said to be “Ignat’evna” (daughter of Ignatii): the name Ignatii possibly comes from the Latin “ignis” (fire) (R258/E190). Given that Orina is depicted here through her lust, such a patronymic seems apt. Her last name is said to be alternatively Neklina and Paklina (Spacklin, in translation): “You were called around the barracks Orina Neklina, and to whom do you belong now, to what kind of, let’s suppose, Spacklin, ah?” (R246/E169). On the border with Ukraine, close to Mariupol’ and to Chekhov’s hometown Taganrog, there is Rostov district named Neklinovsky. Paklia and paklina are regional terms indicating different things: a left-handed person, an unhandy and clumsy person, a bony hand, a piece of hemp or coarse fiber, messy hair. The terms паклен and неклен are named for the Tatar maple (note the slight differences in the spelling between the tree names and Orina’s surnames: Неклина, Паклина). As Sokolov explains, “Apparently, the author of the Notes and Ilya know or have heard about a man named Paklin. Ilya says that Arina’s last name was Neklina, probably after one of her men. And now, years later, Ilya assumes, she lives with someone else, whose last name suggests to him the tree’s other name” (personal communication, July 7, 2023).

bible religion intertextuality intratextuality theme
Вами

The inspector, Sidor Fomich Pozhilykh, to whom Ilya is addressing his letter of complaint.

explanatory character
на боковую

Set expression: to hit the hay, hit the sack, time to sleep.

phraseologism
почайничать без всяких обиняков — почайпьем, почаевничаем

Repetition.

Повтор.

sound rhythm
без всяких обиняков

Set expression: без обиняков (in plain English, in no uncertain terms).

phraseologism
почайпьем

Low: to drink (tea) together.

register/style
донять

Colloquial: to harass, bother.

register/style
фантиков

Candy wrappers appear three times in the novel (R160, 248, 262/E 19, 174, 199).

motif intratextuality
извиняйте, в известных

Alliteration (izv).

Аллитерация (изв).

sound stylistic device
в известных торопях

Usually the word is written as “vtoropiakh” (hastily), but here Sokolov splits the prefix.

neologism
подлечился малость хозяйкиной милостью

That is, Ilya drank. Alcohol theme.

theme explanatory
откуда только фамилья подобная, где это я ее подцепил

On one level, Ilya here suggests that he “picked up” his surname in the sense that it’s not really his name. It’s an adopted identity, a mask. Indeed, he just admitted loving collecting things: “I’m a fan, I possess a passion for collectin” (R262/E196).

explanatory character
цыганский барон

A reference to Johann Strauss II’s operetta The Gypsy Baron (1885), which also deals with a hidden identity. Listen here.

intertextuality music foreign
песочком присыпать

Ilya refers to sand used to seal ink on paper to avoid smears.

explanatory
